PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coastline
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest, in the strongest possible terms, at the Federal Government's inaction to take legislative measures to protect our coast.

We the surfriders and TRACKS readers of Australia have watched our coastal treasures, the ecology, biodiversity and beauty of the Australian coast marred by urban development, poor planning and pollution, especially over the last 25 years.
The ALP has been in government for half that time and we've lost double our resources.
We (not so humbly) demand that you urge the Federal Government to act now to establish a national coastal agency with national powers to stop the destruction of our Australian coastline.
We also demand that the Federal Government recognise and include surfriders in the major decision making forums and call on you to contribute resources toward those who protect our surfing coast.
Finally, we demand that the environment be recognised in the Australian Constitution.
We are tired of waiting! You must act now. Please write to me and inform me of what you are going to do to save our surf.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to abolish Austudy for 16 year olds living at home; to erode Austudy payments in favour of student loans and to reduce the income thresholds for repayment of the loan supplement.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that the Independent Rate Age be decreased to 21 years immediately; that full Austudy payments be raised to the same level as unemployment benefits; and, that the taxable income threshold be increased to $8000 pa.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: TV Reception: Derwent Valley
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned residents of the Derwent Valley do hereby request that the Government take the necessary steps to immediately improve television reception in our area.

Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 22 September 1995 concerning the Determination of Technical Standard Notice TN5 of 1995, End-to-End Performance Network No. TS 27—1995.

You sought detailed advice to clarify some aspects of the proposed Standard, in particular the nature of the authority for Carriers "to regularly report to AUSTEL to demonstrate compliance with the standard" (Clause 5 of the Explanatory Statement), and also the avenues of review in the case of AUSTEL identifying non-compliance with the standard.

AUSTEL has power under the Telecommunications Act 1991 to require regular reporting by carriers on their compliance with the Standard. Under s45 it has power to do all things necessary or convenient to be done for, or in connection with, the performance of its functions. Sections 46 and 400 of the Act provide AUSTEL with power to direct carriers to provide it with information or documents relevant to the performance of its functions. Section 401 similarly enables AUSTEL to require the same of persons other than carriers. Relevant AUSTEL functions under the Act include the protection of the public interest [s38(1)], and reviewing and reporting on carrier performance [s4O].
It is also a condition of the Service Providers Class Licence that suppliers comply with AUSTEL's requirements relating to the giving of information and documents to AUSTEL.

In regard to the review of any adverse AUSTEL decisions about compliance, it has been AUSTEL's practice to attempt to deal with any compliance problems by negotiation before taking more formal measures to enforce a licence condition.

Legally, it is a licence condition that carriers comply with technical standards about network matters under s245. In order for AUSTEL to conclude that that condition had been breached, it would need to investigate under Part 15 of the Act. This could be either in response to a complaint, on AUSTEL's own initiative, or at the request of the Minister. As a result of such an investigation, under s343 AUSTEL can direct a carrier to remedy the licence condition contravention.

There are two types of appeal open to a carrier if it wishes to have an AUSTEL decision reviewed, namely through the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (AD(JR)) or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The nature of the appeal will determine which is the appropriate avenue for review.

In terms of AD(JR), aspects of AUSTEL's decision that could be subject to judicial review include: the decision to investigate, any aspect of the investigation, AUSTEL's findings, and the decision to give a direction under s343 of the Act. This review would relate to questions of law, not to the merits of AUSTEL's decision. The Act does not provide for merits review of such a decision by the AAT.

In relation to service providers who are not carriers, it is a condition of the Class Licence that they comply with technical standards about network matters [clause (5)]. Where a supplier breaches a condition of the licence, AUSTEL could take action to declare the service unlicensed under Subdivision E, Division 3, Part 10 of the Act [as per clause (9)]. Subdivision E incorporates natural justice requirements and a mechanism for AUSTEL to reconsider its decision to give such a declaration. AUSTEL can also go further and direct carriers and suppliers to disconnect or not to connect a service the subject of a declaration under Division 4 of Part 10 of the Act. Any of these AUSTEL decisions, that is: to give a declaration; to confirm a declaration upon reconsideration, in connection with its investigation; or to give a direction; would also be reviewable under the AD(JR) Act.

Under s397(i)(d) of the Act there is provision for the AAT to review a decision made by AUSTEL under s230 concerning a decision to make a declaration that a service is unlicensed in the circumstances outlined in the above paragraph. However, the Act does not provide for AAT review of other AUSTEL decisions under Divisions 3 and 4 of Part 10.

AUSTEL has confirmed that there is a typographical error in paragraph 18 of the Explanatory Statement. The paragraph should refer to paragraphs 12 and 13 of the Statement as the Committee has suggested.
Yours sincerely

Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 22 September 1995 in which you seek advice on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances about the Employment Services (Participants) Determination No. 2 of 1995 and the Employment Services (Terminating Events) Determination No. 2 of 1995.

The Determinations were notified in the Commonwealth Gazette of 17 July 1995. The changed Determinations take account of Budget decisions relating to seasonal and part-time workers to enable these workers to choose to become participants in the case management system and a number of other changes which clarify and formalise existing policy, including access to case management for people covered by the Forest Industry Special Assistance Package and Labour Adjustment Packages (LAPs).
I provide the following information for the Committee's consideration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Status of strategies, packages and initiatives references in Clause 4 of the Participants and Terminating Events Determinations

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General's Department has been consulted on the status of the Determinations in relation to their reference to particular strategies, packages and initiatives. Its advice confirms that such references are to the strategy or initiative in existence from time to time and that such references are appropriate within the terms of the enabling provision.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The exercise and delegation of a Discretionary power under the Determinations

SPEECH.PARA: You noted that the Employment Services (Participants) Determination provides discretionary powers to classify a jobseeker as being at high risk of becoming long term unemployed, of being substantially adversely affected in employment as a result of a decision not to release a forest coupe from a protection list and of having a capacity to work certain hours.

Decisions made under these powers provide jobseekers with early access to DEET labour market programs and case management. It is hoped that with this early intervention any identified barriers jobseekers may have to finding employment will be overcome and they will not become long term unemployed. I believe that decisions classifying jobseekers in this way are not ones which could be considered adverse to them. In fact, the changed determinations extend the classes of persons who can obtain case management.

Similar provisions relating to the assessment of at high risk status were included in the Employment Services (Participants) Determination No. 1 of 1995 which the present Determination replaced. The provision for access to case management services by former forest industry workers and their partners is an additional measure in the present Determination.

You make reference to the Participants Determination in respect to a person having to work a certain number of hours. The only reference in the Participants Determination is to a part-time employee. In this regard the hours are a matter of fact and are either 20 or 35 hours for part-time workers. There is no exercise of a discretion on the part of the Employment Secretary.

If the reference was meant to relate to the provision in the terminating events for participants in the Disability Reform Package this reference was included in the Employment Services (Terminating Events) Determination No. 1 of 1995 which the present Determination replaced. The Determination reflects arrangements and decisions which are made, independent of the case management arrangements, through the Disability Reform Package Panel which is convened by the Department of Social Security and includes specialist membership from the Department of Human Services and Health and the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

Part 4.10 of the Employment Services Act 1994 (the Act) provides for internal and external merits review of certain decisions made under the Act. The external reviews are to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal which is established under the Social Security Act 1991. Section 145 of the Act provides that a "reviewable decision" includes a decision of the Employment Secretary or the CES under Part 4.2. Therefore, a decision taken in relation to the status of an individual as a participant in the case management system or in relation to terminating events affecting the individual is subject to merits review if the person is dissatisfied with the decision.

You have also inquired about the reference to the powers of the Employment Secretary in relation to the Terminating Events Determination, in particular paragraph 5.1(1) which provides for a terminating event to apply to a person not in receipt of job search allowance, youth training allowance or newstart allowance who:

PARA.TAB: (i)unreasonably delays entering into a Case Management Activity Agreement (CMAA), or
(ii)has not taken reasonable steps to comply with the terms of a CMAA.

SPEECH.PARA: For a person in receipt of allowance, a failure to comply with the above requirements may result in the imposition of a deferment period (see section 45 of the Act) and if the deferment period is of a certain length of time then a terminating event applies (see paragraphs 5.1(e), (f) and (g) of the Terminating Events Determination). A terminating event, however, is required for the situation where a participant is not in receipt of allowance and is unreasonably failing to comply with his or her reciprocal obligations. This is the purpose of paragraph 5.1(1).

In relation to subparagraph 5.1(1)(i), the decision about unreasonably delaying entering into a CMAA is, in effect, similar to that taken under section 44 of the Act which deals with the failure to negotiate a CMAA. The Employment Secretary's powers under that section are specifically delegable under section 47 of the Act. There is no specific provision concerning the delegation of the powers of the Employment Secretary under the Determination. However, I am advised that powers of the Employment Secretary under the instrument would be taken to be delegable under general law principles in that he or she would not be expected to exercise this power personally in each case and may appoint others to act for him or her (otherwise known as the Carltona doctrine from the case of Carltona Ltd v Commissioner of Public Works [1943] 2 A11 ER 560).

In relation to subparagraph 5.1(1)(ii), the decision about unreasonably delaying entering into a CMAA is not a decision taken under the Act (similar provisions in relation to persons in receipt of allowance are taken via the application by the provisions of the Social Security Act 1991 by the operation of section 45). Again, the powers of the Employment Secretary would be taken to be delegable under the Carltona principle.
Whether decisions under paragraph 5.1(1) are, in effect, taken under the Act or the Determination, they would be subject to merits review under Part 4.10 of the Act.
I hope that the above is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely

Dear Mal

I refer to your letter of 22 September 1995 indicating the concerns of Committee with new regulation 1.04(4B) of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (`SIS Regulations'). That regulation was inserted into the SIS Regulations by r.2.01 of Statutory Rule No. 240 of 1995. The Committee has queried whether the new regulation is inconsistent with the restriction on prescribing matters in regulations by reference to other instruments contained in s.49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 (AIA).
I note that that on 16 October 1995 you lodged a notice of a motion to disallow Statutory Rule No. 240 of 1995 (of which regulation 1.04(4B) forms a part).

New Schedule 1AA of the SIS Regulations lists a number of `exempt public sector schemes'. Such `exempt' State and Territory schemes are not required to comply with the SIS legislation per se, but rather with the principles it reflects (as set out in the Heads of Government Agreement entered into with respect to `exempt' schemes). The schedule is arranged by jurisdiction with schemes being identified by reference to the legislation under which they have been established (under the heading `schemes established by or under') or by name (under the heading `schemes established under trust deeds').
Regulation 1.04(4B) states: `If a scheme listed in Schedule 1AA is re-named, the reference to that scheme includes a reference to the scheme as re-named'.

The effect of s.49A of the AIA on proposed regulation 1.04(4B) was considered by the ISC and the Office of Legislative Drafting in the Attorney-General's Department during the course of the drafting process. The Attorney-General's Department considers that because regulation 1.04(4B) makes no reference to the instrument from which a changed name derives but refers, instead, directly to the fact of the name of the scheme having changed (an objective fact) s.49A is not infringed. For example a reference in regulations to a registered medical practitioner would not infringe s.49A while a reference to a person whose name is on a specified roll of registered medical practitioners would.

In light of the Attorney-General's Department view that regulation 1.04(4B) is valid, I seek your confirmation that the notice of motion to disallow Statutory Rule No. 240 of 1995 (of which the regulation is part) will not, in this case, be pursued.
Yours sincerely

Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 22 September 1995 concerning the measurement of the length of a ship under the Prawn Export Promotion Levies and Charges Regulations.

The Regulations were framed on the basis that a majority of the boats concerned are registered under the Shipping Registration Act 1981. In the small number of cases where there is likely to be a dispute over the length of a boat, it was considered equitable that the matter be settled by the authority which had already measured a majority of the boats that are subject to the prawn boat levy.

In this context, the Regulations were drafted with a view to keeping the dispute settlement procedure simple. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) is a Commonwealth agency whose charter enables it to provide, on request, services to the maritime industry on a commercial basis. If the Regulation contained a broader definition of the agencies entitled to carry out the measurement function, arrangements would need to be made through AMSA or other accredited organisations to confirm the credentials of the surveyor carrying out the task.

I am advised that AMSA operates on the basis of cost recovery from the users of its services and I understand that any other Organisation performing the same function would similarly charge for its services. The requirement that the boat owner meet these costs is consistent with the `user pays' principle.

Section 8 of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990 refers to the powers of the Minister administering that Act to give directions to AMSA. There would appear to be no need for any action of this type in relation to prawn boats as AMSA has indicated that it would carry out the abovementioned function as a routine service.

Regarding the insertion of an Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) provision in these Regulations, my understanding is that the primary point of reference for the measurement of boats is the Shipping Registration Act, which does contain AAT appeal provisions. However, in light of your Committee's concerns, I would propose that the matter be put beyond doubt by including a right of appeal to the AAT when the Regulations are next amended.
Yours sincerely

DEVELOPMENT ALLOWANCE AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1995
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN SPRING SITTINGS
Purpose of Bill:

There are currently limitations on the transfer of the Development Allowance benefit where ownership of a project is transferred to another entity after application for the allowance but before registration; and across different entity structures after registration but before pre-qualification for the Allowance. The amendments will allow all types of project restructures of a bona fide nature and for genuine commercial reasons, and which are conducive to completing the carrying out of the project. They will be retrospective and will apply from 1 January 1993, which is the date applications for the Development Allowance closed.
Reasons for seeking introduction and passage of the Bill in the 1995 Spring sittings:

PARA.TAB: The statutory deadlines for registration and pre-qualification for the Development Allowance mean that passage in the 1995 calendar year is essential.

A project must be registered for the Development Allowance before it can apply for a pre-qualification certificate which is a prerequisite for eligibility for the 10% tax deduction. All the issues which arise during consideration for registration need to be satisfied within sufficient time to allow a well prepared application for pre-qualification to be made. An application for a pre-qualification certificate is to be given to the Development Allowance Authority (DAA) before 1 August 1996.

The proposed amendments are likely to overcome the problems currently faced by companies that have restructured their projects during the development stage and on the proviso that the amendments are made in time to meet the key dates of the Act. Under the Act as it currently stands, an entity that has changed the structure of a project prior to registration is unlikely to satisfy these requirements.

It is essential therefore, and time critical, that the amendments on project restructures are both introduced and passed in the Spring sittings. Otherwise they may not be passed until the Autumn sitting in 1996, in which event, the DAA may not be able to register projects and allow sufficient time for applicants to prepare and lodge valid applications for pre-qualification.

The DAA has no power to accept an application for pre-qualification prior to registration. There is also no discretion for the DAA to accept an application for pre-qualification after the 31 July 1996 deadline. Unless the amendments are passed early, applicants that would otherwise be eligible under the amended provisions may miss out on the Development Allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: INDUSTRY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
A BILL TO AMEND THE INDUSTRY COMMISSION ACT
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN SPRING SITTINGS
Purpose of Bill:
To increase the flexibility of the Commission's operations by three minor amendments:

The first amendment allows for Commissioners to be appointed on a part-time basis in addition to the current full-time basis. This will increase the Commission's chances of attracting suitably qualified people on a permanent part-time basis. The Commission has had difficulties in attracting a more diverse range of applicants. In particular, these changes will allow the Commission to recruit more women Commissioners and those who hold other positions and are unwilling to become full-time Commissioners.

The second amendment will increase the maximum number of Commissioners, other than the chairman, from eight to eleven. This necessarily follows the first amendment, as the Commission will need to maintain the same level of resources at the Commissioner level, requiring more Commissioners in total if there are to be part-time appointees.

The third amendment will allow one Commissioner, in emergency situations, to constitute a quorum for public hearings rather than the current two. This will allow the Commission to continue its normal public hearing processes where two Commissioners cannot be present.
Reasons for seeking introduction and passage of the Bill in the 1995 Spring Sittings:

The urgency of this Bill is related to the amendment which allows the Government to appoint Commissioners on a permanent part-time basis. Due to a serious illness, a current Commissioner is having great difficulty sustaining full-time appointment. Under the current Act, this Commissioner is only able to work part-time by being downgraded to an Associate Commissioner, with very detrimental effects on work entitlements, including superannuation. The proposed amendment would allow the Commissioner to be reappointed on a part-time basis. This would reduce the Commissioner's workload—with benefits to health—but without any significant erosion of existing employment conditions.

Because of the serious nature of the Commissioner's illness, it is essential and time critical that this amendment be introduced and passed in the Spring Sittings to ensure that this person is not penalised simply because of the inflexibility of the relevant provisions of the Industry Commission Act.
WORKING TITLE OF BILL: SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
Purpose of bill:
The Bill will make miscellaneous amendments to superannuation legislation. The main purposes being to:

PARA.TAB: improve and refine the complaints handling system within the superannuation industry; and
ensure no legislative gaps arise as a result of the expiry of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's ability to issue temporary modification declarations; and
ensure the ISC has sufficient supervisory powers to protect members.

SPEECH.PARA: Reasons for seeking introduction and passage of the bill in the 1995 Springs Sittings:

PARA.TAB: The Bill will contain provisions to amend the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal so as to enable it to deal more efficiently and directly with complaints regarding life office superannuation products and medical evidence complaints involving life office decisions. The Government has made a commitment that the Tribunal will be able to deal effectively and efficiently with medical evidence complaints from 1 November 1995 and wishes to honour its commitment by ensuring that the necessary amendments to enable the Tribunal to deal with such complaints in an effective and efficient manner are in place by that date;

The bill will also `transfer' a number of temporary modification declarations made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner under Part 29 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SIS Act) into the actual body of the SIS Act itself. The SIS Act provides that these temporary declarations (which in effect represent part of the Act) will cease to have effect from 30 June 1996. Unless legislation to replace these declarations is included in the SIS Act well in advance of this date then serious disruption could be caused to significant parts of the superannuation industry. For example, many small (less than 5 member) funds would suddenly, and inappropriately, be classified as `public offer funds' and the trustee of such funds (which is often `mum or dad') would need to become a corporate trustee, be approved by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and meet stringent financial backing requirements (such as having $5 million in net tangible assets). It is considered essential that these amendments are passed in the Spring Sittings to avoid problems of this sort emerging and to provide the necessary comfort to industry well in advance of the 30 June 1996 cut off date. This will ensure industry does not (to the likely detriment of members) begin rearranging its affairs because of a belief that the amendments will not be in place by 30 June 1996.

The remaining amendments in the Bill are also time critical if the supervisory system is to be sufficiently strong to protect members. For example, included in these amendments are measures to address two significant gaps which have been found in the ISC's supervisory powers:

TAB.TAB: the ISC needs the power to apply to a court for appointment of a receiver where this is necessary to protect members, and
the ISC needs the power to require external auditors to check on fund compliance with the requirements of the SIS legislation.

COMMONWEALTH BANK SALE BILL 1995
Commonwealth Banks (Sale and Transitional Arrangements) Bill 1995
Purpose of Bill:

The Bill will make substantial amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 and relatively minor amendments to the Banking Act 1959 and the Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972. The main purpose of the Bill is to facilitate the Government's decision to sell its remaining 50.4 per cent shareholding in the CBA and to provide various transitional arrangements for the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Bank.
Reasons for seeking introduction and passage of the Bill in the 1995 Spring Sittings

PARA.TAB: The proposed Bill is currently listed for introduction in the 1995 Winter Sittings. However, the need to resolve a number of fundamental transitional issues with the Commonwealth Bank has delayed the drafting of the proposed Bill. As a consequence, it is not possible for the Bill to be drafted in time for the 1995 Winter Sittings.

It is critical for the Bill to be passed by the end of calendar 1995 to allow the Task Force on Asset Sales to effect the sale in the first half of 1996. SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1995
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN SPRING SITTINGS

The proposed Customs Tariff Bill 1995 will give effect to the extensive classification changes in the Harmonised Commodity Description and Coding System of the World Customs Organisation. The changes affect 1/3 of the current Customs Tariff Act 1987, and this Bill will effectively introduce a new Tariff Bill, in much the same way as the current 1987 Tariff replaced the 1982 Tariff following a similar international harmonisation exercise.

Parliamentary consideration of the Bill this Sittings is necessary primarily because of the 6 month lead time which this legislation requires before its commencement. The world Customs Organisation, of which Australia is an active member, is committed to a 1996 commencement of the new harmonised description and classification system. Australia has indicated its preparedness to have the new system in by 1 July 1996.

To accommodate that mid-year commencement, the Bill will need to be in place by at least 1 January 1996. Not only will the importing community require this lead time to make the necessary computer software and documentary changes resulting from the Bill, but in addition, there is a need to check and revalidate the 120,000 tariff advices which importers hold on the tariff classification of goods, together with the checking and re-execution of the 10,000 Tariff Concession Orders currently on hand to allow the duty free entry of goods.
BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN SPRING SITTINGS
The proposed Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 (the Bill) will:

PARA.TAB: (i) validate certain untabled Ministerial declarations, and decisions made and things done in reliance on those declarations, made under the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 and the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985; and

(ii) amend the eligibility criteria under the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Act 1994, as announced in the 1995-96 Budget, to enable existing fuel ethanol producers to claim bounty on post 1 July 1994 production on the same basis as new ethanol producers.

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction and passage of this Bill in the Spring Sittings is necessary to ensure that the integrity of the Computer and Machine Tools and Robots bounty schemes is maintained and that Commonwealth officers are not obliged to recover any unauthorised bounty payments made in reliance on those declarations, when it was clearly the Government's intention that the payments should be made.

The amendments to the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Act 1994 are a 1995-96 Budget measure intended to apply in relation to all fuel ethanol production after 1 July 1994. The Government considers that it is desirable that this proposal be implemented before the end of 1995 so as not to further delay bounty payments of up to $280,000 in respect of eligible 1994-95 production and to attract greater industry participation in the 3 year scheme which is designed to compliment the Government's national lead abatement strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: Reasons for introduction and passage in the Spring Sittings
Introduction and passage in the Spring Sittings is required because of the number of measures which have commencement dates of 9 May 1995 or earlier.

Seven measures (various capital gains tax amendments, trust losses, research and development, horticulture plantations, franking credits/profit shifting, demutualisation of life and general insurance companies, forestry plantations) have a commencement date of 9 May 1995, and therefore have an impact on 1994-95 income tax returns. For this reason early passage of these measures is critical.

The occupational clothing register amendments relate to the cessation of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority on 29 February 1996. Responsibility for maintaining the clothing register is to transfer to Ausindustry after this date. Without the passage of legislation by 29 February, there will be no legislative backing for the administration of the occupational clothing register from that date.

Three other measures have early commencement dates. The company tax franking account amendments apply to the 1995-96 franking year. The new franking accounts could commence as early as 1 July 1995. The capital gains tax taxable Australian assets measure has a commencement date of 19 September 1985 and the capital gains tax rollover for approved deposit funds measure commences on 12 January 1994. Because of retrospective application dates, it is important that these measures receive passage as early as possible.
CUSTOMS TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1995
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN SPRING SITTINGS

Each of the Bills proposes to incorporate into legislation outstanding Customs or Excise Tariff proposals, including those which implemented this year's Budget changes to the duty rates on tobacco products and light fuel oil.

Under the respective sections of the Customs Act 1901 and Excise Act 1901 (Sections 226 and 114 refer), tariff proposals are required to be incorporated into legislation within 12 months of their tabling in the Parliament, or the close of the session of Parliament in which the proposals were introduced, whichever first happens. If this does not occur, the proposals are of no effect, and the duty collected under them is subject to return.

Parliamentary consideration of the Bills this Sittings is necessary because of the substantial amount of duty which has been collected under the proposals to date, and which could be put at risk if incorporation is not to proceed. If the incorporation into legislation is deferred until next year due to the postponement of the debate on the relevant Tariff Amendment Bills, the amount of duty which will have been collected could be in excess of $100 million.

(ii)Spearhawk Pty Ltd, according to its latest annual return, is in fact a totally-owned subsidiary of Sephrenia Pty Ltd, a company owned by Mr and Mrs Constantinidis, so that Sephrenia is the ultimate holding company of the Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd,

(iii)Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd is now claimed, in recently-tendered documents, to own the Tamworth piggery, formerly owned by the Keating-Constantinidis piggery group, from which three workers were sacked in June 1994 after their successful complaint that they had been paid less than the award wage while Mr Keating was a half-owner,

(iv)attempts by these men to get redress for their wrongful dismissal have been frustrated and delayed by the false claim that their employer was a company called Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd, a name that has never existed on the ASC company records; and

(v)Mr Constantinidis has advised the ASC that Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd was, in fact, not a company but only a division of the Brown and Hatton Group (the Keating-Constantinidis group) which ran the Tamworth piggery until 30 June 1994; and

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses its concern that the ASC has taken no action against Mr Constantinidis in respect of false declarations in various documents that a non-existent company was the employer at Tamworth, so falsely protecting the piggery from those industrial relations law requirements that apply to employers of 15 or more workers and delaying and frustrating the three sacked workers in their attempts to get a fair hearing about their wrongful dismissal.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee on the proposed sale of ANL Ltd, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure honourable senators and many other interested parties will be relieved to see that the committee has finally been able to present its report on this matter. This report has taken some considerable time in gestation. That delay is not necessarily the fault of the committee because originally, senators will recall, the committee was required to consider the outcome of the auditor's report on ANL as well. With that constraint placed upon us, we took the responsible attitude of starting our proceedings after the auditor's report was made available.

PARA.TAB: In receiving evidence, we were able to compile, and the report reveals, a chronology of events surrounding the conduct of the sale of ANL so far. I would say in passing that the matter is not yet concluded either. That chronology is presented in the report and may serve as being illustrative to some people.

The other matter the committee was able to address was what it actually is that is being sold. That is not as simple as it might first appear. To say that what is proposed for sale is the Australian National Line does not necessarily mean anything because several different people can have different ideas as to what the Australian National Line is. That fact brought on a great deal of discussion about what was the actual value of that property. At page 9, in conclusion 2.17, the report records:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee agrees that the various valuations of ANL that are available are not necessarily directly comparable, in that they are based on very different assumptions. The Committee does not intend to comment upon the validity of these assumptions, other than to say that there appears to be scope for disagreement among commercial experts.

I might interpolate that disagreement there certainly was, and that provided the committee with some degree of difficulty in determining the different assumptions and the different bases upon which those assumptions have been made. Our conclusion continued:

It does not appear, however, that the relevance of any one valuation can only be determined within the context of the assumptions upon which it is based. In the view of some members of the Committee, the `fire sale' assumptions of PWSB may have had a negative influence in determining the value of ANL and its assets.

That in some way gives a hint to the direction of the entire inquiry. We were presented with evidence from experts which was not always directly comparable. It was very challenging for the committee to have to deal with those differing opinions and, in many cases, facts based on different criteria, and resolving those differences was a matter the committee took very seriously.

PARA.TAB: The report consists of a report of the evidence that was given to us and an indication as to where further evidence can be examined by interested people. We drew conclusions from that evidence. I will highlight to the Senate this morning just a couple more of the conclusions that the committee was able to draw. At page 12, conclusion 3.16, we concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Given that a decision was made to sell ANL, the Committee is concerned that the sale process has lasted for over four years.
I think everybody should be concerned about the length of time this process has taken. Further, our conclusion reads:

The Committee appreciates the point made by Stephen Sedgwick, Secretary of the Department of Finance, that, in the initial stages, the Government may have needed to refine its options, and that this was the purpose of the scoping study. Nevertheless, the process was initiated via the scoping study in 1991. For a variety of reasons, the sale clearly has not proceeded in a timely fashion.

There are other conclusions that we reach about the process, the length of time that it took and how it was conducted. But another highlight, for example, is our conclusion 3.20 on page 13, where the committee agrees with the point made by the Australian National Audit Office that the board should have been provided with the PWSB report prior to its release. That is symptomatic of the problems that the committee was able to identify.

PARA.TAB: During its examination, the Australian National Audit Office found many instances where, if communication had been improved and if information had been shared, then some of the criticisms levelled at the process would not have applied. The committee could only but agree with those findings of the ANAO.

I will not take too much more time on this because I think that the report is particularly clear and plain and not particularly lengthy, so if any particular senator wanted to pursue it any further, he or she would be well rewarded with reading the report in its entirety. However, I point out that under our conclusions and recommendations in part 5 on page 15, the report reads:

The Committee believes that there is little to be gained from an assignment of `blame' for each difficult circumstance throughout the ANL sale process, although most members agree that more could have been done by the Department of Finance TFAS, and that both the actions of the Minister and the protracted decision making process of the Government were not helpful. The Committee believes that the Government can and should learn from this experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than labour the point, I think that speaks for itself. I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Before I call Senator Minchin, I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of a former long-serving and distinguished senator, former Senator Tony Mulvihill. It is good to see you here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee on the proposed sale of ANL is one of the more important reports produced by the Senate. I congratulate my colleague Senator Gibson for initiating this inquiry, as he did, some 11 months ago and congratulate the secretariat, in particular the secretary, Sue Morton, on its production.

PARA.TAB: It has, as the chairman said, been long in gestation but very valuable and I think is something that will be referred to for many years to come. I am pleased to see that it is, in fact, a bipartisan report with members of all parties signing up to it.

It is an important report because it documents for all time an extraordinary saga of incompetence on the part of the Labor government—incompetence over a four-year period of real soap opera proportions. Four years have elapsed since the government made the proper decision to sell ANL, yet this company is still not sold, which compares most unfavourably with the actions of various state governments, most of them Liberal, in their disposal of government assets properly, in due time and for good returns to the taxpayer.

This inquiry, of course, was prompted by the remarkable comments by the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, back in, I think, August of last year where he said, `You couldn't give it away', when he referred to ANL, a taxpayer owned asset. Of course, Laurie Brereton, Minister Brereton, as usual, is quite wrong. In fact, the government is giving ANL away. What will happen, presumably, some time around the end of this month is that P&O will take over ANL for virtually no return to the taxpayer whatsoever.

So Mr Brereton is wrong. We are giving ANL away. The taxpayer will get nothing for this company. The minister's statement back in August of 1994, which really was the catalyst for this inquiry, was incredibly improper and irresponsible for the person charged with the ownership and control of a major government asset.
Mr Bolitho, the former chairman, said the following. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the actions and statements of the Minister were a deliberate and substantial devaluation of the work of ANL and impairment of its sale prospects, and were deliberately and substantially damaging to the commercial reputations of the directors of the Board of ANL at that time.
It is very hard to disagree with that. The report says in its conclusion:
In the view of the majority of members—
I note that—
the statements—
made by Minister Brereton—

carried the potential to have a negative influence on the interests of the Commonwealth and they question the prudence of the Minister's conduct in making statements which were potentially damaging to the sale process without providing the full documentation relied upon to support those statements.

The real import of this report is how irresponsible Minister Brereton has been in his handling of this whole saga. He has been utterly incompetent in the handling of so many issues. We now have a major waterfront strike largely as a result of Minister Brereton's incompetence on industrial relations, his incompetence on the airport, et cetera. The sagas that are attached to this minister are unbelievable. I am amazed that he remains a minister in the government. It can only be as a result of particular friendships he has in New South Wales. His treatment of the former board, in particular, was disgraceful. That was referred to by Mr Bolitho.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we congratulate the former chairman, Mr Bill Bolitho, on his courage in taking a public stand on this issue. He could have just withered away after the extraordinary debacle back in August 1994 when the whole board was sacked. Instead he took a public stand. He stood up to this bullying government and this bullying minister and pointed out the drastic consequences of what the minister had done, the damage the minister had done to this national asset, ANL. He and his colleagues on that board have been treated in a most appalling way by the minister and the government.

It was clear to me and to other members, from both sides of the chamber, on this committee that Mr Bolitho is a man of great sincerity and integrity, a man who devoted many years of his life to building up this public asset. He took it over back in the early 1980s when it was obviously in a very sick state and devoted a decade of his life—full-time for what was a paltry part-time chairman's remuneration—to building up ANL. But ever since the government made the decision to sell the company back in 1991 it has been a downhill run for that company to the point now where we will get absolutely nothing back from the investment which people like Mr Bill Bolitho made in the company.

It must be tragic for him, in particular, to see what has happened to the company he chaired. It must be particularly galling for him to see what occurred after August 1994 when Mr Brereton's good friend the Hon. Neville Wran QC was made chairman of the company for what was initially six months but was then extended to 12 months. He was paid $300,000 for one year's part-time work to chair this company. As we learnt, poor old Mr Bolitho got $40,000 per year to work probably 80 hours a week to try to resuscitate the company. It must be very painful for Mr Bolitho to see what has occurred in the 12 months since he was summarily dismissed. The total bill for the Wran board was $816,000, which is nearly 20 per cent of the best we might get for the company. It will probably end up being about the same amount we will receive for the same company—an extraordinary amount of money doled out in one year to one board, two of whom coincidentally happen to be good friends of the minister.

This inquiry is a manual on how not to sell a government business. That is why it will stand in good stead for many years to come. Anyone who wants to know how you do not go about selling a business should read this report first. It documents the extraordinary saga. It is a dramatic example of this government's incompetence. There are many lessons to be learnt by the government, but this government will only be here for a few months, so it is a bit late for the government. There are many lessons to be learnt by the bureaucracy in how to go about a proper sale process under a responsible government.

The worst part of this whole saga is the extraordinary cost to the taxpayer. Millions upon millions of dollars have been washed away by the incompetence of the government largely as a result of its sordid and unhealthy relationship with the trade union movement in this country. Much of the problem derives from the relationship with the union movement, the government's incapacity to act in the national interest because of its regard for the special interests of one trade union in this case. Now we see the government standing on the sidelines in the face of the trade union movement shutting down the whole country. ANL is a particular example of this government's lack of regard for the national interest and its undue regard for the special interests of the trade union movement. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was also part of the initial process which got this inquiry under way. I noted at the time that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) was very angry. He said words to the effect that the world as we know it would fall apart, that there would be dreadful consequences for the sale of ANL and that it would all be my fault. Considering what has come out in the report—
—Don't you feel important?
—I do feel important. I feel that those words were very interesting considering the outcome of the report and the influence on the sale process that the minister himself has had.

PARA.TAB: A major interest of the Greens in giving support to the inquiry was to see whether it was possible—this is one regret that I have—to enable the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee to look at the wider public interest in dealing with the application of a government business enterprise. Unfortunately, that was not able to happen in this committee. There were obviously particular interests in the financial dealings of the committee. There was also a problem, as was mentioned, in relation to the tabling of the Auditor-General's report. It was always under the assumption that the inquiry would meet and have hearings after the Auditor-General's report.

We all realised that part of the problem was getting the Auditor-General's report authorised. A limited Auditor-General's report was able to be authorised because the minister would not allow a full Auditor-General's report to be undertaken. Eventually, after the sale of the ANL, we might get a full ANL report. It is unfortunate that there was not the cooperation of the minister at the time.

Because of the late arrival of the Auditor-General's report, the whole working of the committee was delayed. This means that some people in various maritime communities that I know in Western Australia who are concerned about the quality of the shipping issue were caught off guard. By the time the Auditor-General's report came out, the deadline for placing submissions to the committee had passed. Although there was a willingness by the committee to accept submissions after that, it really caught people off guard. There perhaps were not as many public submissions. The committee was then unable to organise to take those kind of concerns fully into consideration.

I continue to hope that we do not always continue to separate issues of the accountability of the public interest from the dollar interest. I hope that at some stage in the future this might be continued in another sense. A public administration and finance committee in this place should be able to factor in the possible social costs of the public interest into the way that they deliberate on an outcome.

Along the way, I had concerns with the way that the figures in the books of ANL have been used and manipulated. It was a real pity to see the lack of information that was provided to the people who ought to have known along the way, including the taxpayer. This is a government business enterprise. It brings into sharp focus the concerns that I and other people in this chamber have had about the level of accountability of government business enterprises to the parliamentary process; that is, back to the people who are the stockholders of such enterprises.

I am pleased to see that there is mention of concerns about shipping standards and safety. I am not saying that ANL was the best run shipping line in the world or perhaps even in Australia. My concern is that, if we lose any benchmarks for standards in Australia, the benchmark of good standard shipping becomes that of the best available. We have had a growing number of single voyage permits issued in Australia because there was no other available shipping.

There will be a competing down of standards. The consequence will be a competing down of the level of construction of ships, the crewing levels, the crewing standards, roster times for crews, ballast water treatment, use of oily waste or other standards.

What has happened in the shipping industry throughout the world is part of the internationalisation process as a result of the Uruguay Round of GATT. Ironically, the outcome will not mean greater competition internationally. The outcome seems to be fewer and fewer major players, whom we may well be held captive to.

This will have an impact on Australian shipping. It will have an impact on the services available. It means we may not have the choice of a benchmark for standards of environmental quality. As one of the witnesses said, to rely on the Australian Maritime Safety Authority is a bit like our relying on AQIS once the rules of international trade and international quarantine are adopted. It is like one person standing at the floodgate. That person has the choice of allowing things to happen and hoping for the best or letting things change and destroy the industry that exists.

I accept the inevitable. I am very sad to have to accept the inevitable. I hope my attempt at incorporating the wider public interest provisions in such an inquiry is not seen as an exercise that was tried and failed. I hope it will be repeated some time in the future and that we do not just plonk public interest into another committee and forget that everything we do economically has other implications and that we need to take them into our equations when we are making decisions such as the sale of our national assets.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the report of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee on the proposed sale of ANL. The first thing I should do is commend Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette for supporting the coalition on 8 December last year to get through the Senate the motion which resulted in this report which followed the investigation and uncovering of all the evidence of mismanagement by the government through this process.

PARA.TAB: It has been very well documented by my colleague Senator Minchin and by Senator Bell, the chairman of the committee. Even though the Australian Democrats did not support the original intention, I should also commend Senator Bell for the way in which he did that job. As Senator Minchin said, we ended up with a unanimous report setting out, perhaps in more bland language than the coalition would have liked, the facts about what went wrong in this shameful process of trying to sell a government enterprise over many years. I look across at the other side of the Senate and see that there are no government members of the committee to speak on this matter today.

The key point I stress to the Senate and to the Australian community is that this Labor government has been good at making noise and rhetoric but absolutely hopeless at managing the community's money. This classic example of endeavouring to sell an asset, going back well over four years, is an absolute indictment of people's mismanagement. The sad thing, and the evidence turned up by the committee shows this, is that the old board of the company basically indicated to the government back in November 1992 that there was a good chance of selling the company, probably for a figure greater than $100 million. The coalition has been in favour of selling ANL for many years. The community—the taxpayer—would have done well if that decision had been made then. Due to incompetence by the government, it was not made.

Since then over $100 million—by my estimate, about $111 million—of expenses have been incurred by the government and by the taxpayer; that is, losses by ANL, plus government inquiries, consultants, et cetera. So the total of over $200 million has gone down the tube, has been lost to the taxpayer, over this period of time. Again this is an absolute indictment of the way the Labor government manages taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Over $200 million. The key thing is that the process of managing the sale was absolutely flawed. A good example is the way the government managed the board that was charged under the Corporations Law with managing the company. The government set up a bureaucracy, the asset sales task force, to manage the sale. The chairman of that asset sales task force changed four times during the period of the Bolitho board. There was obvious conflict between the bureaucrats and the board, and the government did nothing to sort that out.

PARA.TAB: The Bolitho board kept pointing out to the government that, under the Corporations Law, they had a duty of care to look after the company and operate the company, and that they were trustees for the assets of the company; yet the government did not understand, because most of them have not been in business. Certainly, the bureaucrats involved did not understand. They went ahead trying to organise the sale without understanding the intricacies of the shipping industry and without conferring and being honest and open with the management and board of the company. Perhaps they were under direction from the ministers. We infer from reading the evidence that the ministers responsible have messed this up. But what has happened over several years has been an absolute indictment.

I bring to the attention of the Senate one classic example of the perceptions of mismanagement between the government and the board. I refer to the decision made by the government on 1 June 1993 to drop the condition of the sale of the company that there be Australian crewing and to drop it off the Australian register. The government made that decision on 1 June 1993, it now turns out, but it did not inform the board of the company until several months later. The government's agencies gave the committee advice that they believed they had given the advice.

I refer anyone interested in this to the documentary evidence set out very well in the submission by William Bolitho of 1 November this year, just recently, to the committee commenting on the Department of Finance's last submission to the committee. The documentary evidence by the previous chairman, Mr Bolitho, sets out very clearly that there were rumours around that the government had made this decision and there were hints to the company that the government had made this decision to drop the condition of Australian crewing. It turns out—and I quote page 6 of his submission—that `changes would be formally advised as soon as the unions can be locked in'. In the meantime, the government had been telling us that the board had been formally advised.

What did the chairman do? He wrote to both Minister Willis and Minister Collins on 25 August 1993 seeking clarification. What was the real situation? The board needed to know the real situation. There never was an answer; no answer from the ministers was received by the board. That is just a classic example, and there are many more. They happened all the time.

The lesson out of this is that this government is absolutely hopeless at managing the economy, hopeless at managing taxpayers' resources and absolutely hopeless at organising a commercial sale. As Senator Minchin said before, in the bill that is still before the chamber it looks as though we will be giving money to a company to get rid of the ANL shipping line.

The other point I wanted to make is that the decision by the government in February 1994 to change the articles of association of the company effectively meant that Minister Brereton was the chief executive of the company, because the articles were changed such that any decision by the board which effectively altered the value of the company had to have the minister's approval. That meant that the minister was the chief executive, if you like, and chairman of the company.

We have seen through this whole process that communication between the board and the minister was hopeless. He was not responding to correspondence or to requests for urgent decisions on what was happening with the company. So we have seen the company run downhill and taxpayers' money—by my estimate over $200 million—has been basically wasted over a four-year period because of the incompetent management of this asset.

I feel very sorry for everyone involved in the ANL saga, particularly the previous chairman Bolitho and the rest of his board which were doing a good job, but also the management of the company and all the employees. They must be extremely disappointed about all this process because if the sale had been effected cleanly and neatly early on, all Australians, including all employees of ANL, I am sure would be much better off today.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the committee, I too would like to make some brief remarks on the tabling of the report of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee entitled The proposed sale of ANL Ltd. As Senator Margetts said during her contribution to the debate, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), at the time when Senator Gibson very sensibly proposed that this matter be a subject for inquiry by the finance and public administration committee, went quite berserk, quite mad. He was not at all impressed that the house of review, the Senate, with its very well established and world renowned committee system should dare to even have a cursory glance at the sale process.

PARA.TAB: We know that Mr Brereton and his good friend the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) do not particularly like the Senate and they certainly do not like the idea of a Senate committee looking into one of their bits of executive action. During the inquiry I tried to tally up what this has really cost the Australian taxpayer. Senator Gibson has made the point today. He has had a very long and successful career in private enterprise. He is a respected company director and understands corporate finance a lot better than I do and probably better than most other senators. If he tells the Senate that the figure is in the order of $200 million, I will accept that as being a very accurate figure. In my own back of the envelope type additions on what it has probably cost the taxpayer, I estimated that it was well in excess of $100 million. But I do not say that those back of the envelope type calculations take into account all the losses and potential losses.

I make this point for one reason; and Senator Margetts has made a very good point about the social impact of these sorts of decisions. Privatisation during the 1980s, particularly the early 1980s, was painted by the Australian Labor Party as some sort of international right-wing conservative conspiracy to sell off great national assets. I well remember—and Senator Minchin will remember them—the sorts of advertisements that the Labor Party ran during the 1985 South Australian election. They were very successful by the Labor Party and peddled outright misinformation about the privatisation policies.

I remember the television advertisements during the 1987 federal election when the government had Graham Kennedy lampooning privatisation. They were very effective political advertisements, of course, but they bore no resemblance to the truth or the facts. If privatisation is handled properly it can achieve very important social benefits for the community but when it is handled badly the opposite is the case.

If the sale of ANL had proceeded in an efficient, sensible and competent manner—if we had a competent minister or series of ministers in charge of the sale process—the Australian public could have been $200 million better off in terms of net assets. That is a lot of money. That amount of money can do a lot of social good for the community. Senator Margetts and I may disagree on how we would spend that $200 million. That would be a very worthy discussion and is part of the mainstream debate in any democracy.

We could use the $200 million to repatriate debt, thus reducing the ongoing interest costs to the Commonwealth accounts and reducing private taxation. We could reduce the pressure on interest rates because the Commonwealth's borrowings would be lower. As a result, we would reduce the home loan repayments of thousands of individuals—particularly those on low incomes who cannot afford the massive interest rate increases that this government's policies have placed upon them. We could use the money to assist Aboriginal communities with much needed infrastructure to allow them to have clean water and improved environmental health. There are a whole lot of things that we could do.

But this $200 million has effectively been flushed down the drain. This is not the only occasion on which this government has flushed hundreds of millions of dollars down the drain. It is not so long ago that I stood up in this place, as a result of another inquiry by another Senate committee and by the Auditor-General, to reveal that even on one of the government's building construction projects—the Casselden Place building in Melbourne—the government had lost in excess of $100 million. The Senate has identified $300 million which has been wasted by this government in less than 12 months.

I shudder to think of other examples that we have not been able to see. The Senate does a remarkable job in scrutinising this government's waste and inefficiency. I am sure that the people in the gallery today would be horrified to know that this government, by the actions of three ministers—Laurie Brereton in the case of the ANL sale and Senator Bolkus and Senator McMullan in the case of the Casselden Place building—has flushed $300 million of their money down the drain. The government takes this money from the back pockets of taxpayers and flushes it down the drain on these sorts of wastes.

I think it is very important, as my colleagues on both sides of the chamber have said, that these sorts of reports stand on the public record. Unfortunately, very few people will ever get to read this report. Unfortunately, I suspect that the media may not give it the sort of attention that it deserves. We have only to look at Labor Party administrations in states like Western Australia and South Australia. Isn't it amazing how quickly we forget? Only a couple of years ago we had this lady, Dr Carmen Lawrence, as Premier of Western Australia, sitting at the cabinet table while decisions were made that cost Western Australian taxpayers billions of dollars in waste. Future generations of Western Australians will have to pay that money back.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same as Joan Kirner.

—I will get to Victoria. We will not forget Joan Kirner, the Premier of Victoria. In South Australia we had the John Bannon government that lost in excess of—Senator Minchin will correct me if I am wrong—$1 billion.
—Three billion dollars.

—Three billion dollars. How quickly we forget. In Victoria Joan Kirner was thrown out of office in absolute disgrace. She lost billions of dollars and also lost the State Bank of Victoria. All those governments were ignominiously thrown out of office by the electors. I am perplexed by the attitude of the national media. I do not blame them, but I think they should be more focused upon these matters. The federal government in Canberra has lost $300 million. It is probably not as big percentage-wise as some of the losses incurred by the government's incompetent state colleagues in Kirner, Lawrence and John Bannon. The loss in terms of the whole budget is probably not of that size, but $300 million is an enormous amount of money.

PARA.TAB: If you are the tax commissioner and you want to raise $300 million, you have to knock on a lot of doors and ask people to pay in a few thousand dollars each. Think of the low to middle income families out there who are struggling to survive under the highest interest rates in the world and the highest inflation in the world, yet this government loses $300 million in just two simple stuff-ups. That is all they are.

Mr Brereton is described in this report as clearly having a role in costing the Australian taxpayer in excess of $100 million and up to $200 million, as Senator Gibson said, through incompetence. He is actually incapable of being a minister and handling a sale like this, and this non-partisan cross-party report makes that quite clear. He is an incompetent minister who has stuffed up this process and cost the Australian taxpayer hundreds of millions of dollars; yet he is still in power. I really do hope that the national media do focus upon this—that they do a Four Corners report on ANL or that they do have a Sunday program analysis of it—because it needs to be exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Faulkner laughs. I do not think even Senator Faulkner would treat this flippantly because he comes from the Left of the New South Wales Labor party and he knows what Mr Brereton is like. He has had to deal with him throughout his political life, I suspect.
—I am very proud of being in the Left.

—I know you are proud of it; I respect you for it. Senator Faulkner knows what the government could do with $200 million or $300 million around the cabinet table. It could find much better ways of spending that money than flushing it down the drain on an incompetent handling of this sale. In conclusion, I want to get off the politics a little and just say to Senator Robert Bell, the chairman, that it was a good committee. I also want to thank Sue Morton, the exemplary secretary of that committee. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time I got the gong last night, I was talking about the fact that in Australia we are competing with companies which hire labour at a very low cost and impose exploitative conditions on seafarers. I suppose we could interpret better conditions for Australian sailors as inefficiency or uncompetitive conditions. I know some people may cast doubt on the assertion that I have just made, but I note there is a bill before this house that would give shipping companies a subsidy in relation to seafarers in recognition of the competitive difficulty of having to meet basic standards in relation to treatment of workers, when competitors do not, and where competitors engage in what can be only considered as extremely exploitative practices.

PARA.TAB: This has been an issue I have raised a number of times in different contexts; that is, that international competition and deregulation is often a mechanism for increasing corporate profit by increasing the exploitation of workers. The fact that there are no international labour standards means that the most exploitative allowable standard is the one that will be most profitable, hence, most competitive—that is if you do not take the possible implications of a major marine accident into account.

The fact that seafaring suffers the additional burden of essentially non-national ships being operated under flags of convenience means that shipping lines are often effectively under no obligation to anyone in relation to seafaring workers. It is not just a case of lower standards becoming the de facto international standards; it is a case of elimination of any standard at all. The imposition of standards by a nation like Australia is seen as a burden for which industry must be compensated if it is to survive.

Likewise, standards on the actual ships are an issue. We have seen that maintaining a regime of inspection and standards for ships operating in Australian waters is a very hit-and-miss affair, and a number of rust buckets seem to operate here, and occasionally, like the Kirki, they go down in our waters. I suppose that if ANL actually tried to maintain their ships at a reasonable level this would also impair their profitability.

I ask: if the government cannot operate a shipping line profitably because it must assure a reasonable standard of workers' rights, crewing levels and ship maintenance, what does that say about the shipping industry and about competition and about the ships operating in our waters? Is the solution to sell ANL so that labour, safety and environmental standards can be abandoned?

Is the problem something else? We have heard that one of the issues is that it is hard for ANL to find back loads from countries like Japan because of policies in those countries which restrict the ability of Australian ships to back load. If this is the case, or there are other reasons or barriers to effective trading, why not do something about this more directly instead of seeing this as a reason to abandon ownership of the shipping line?

It seems to me that Australia's negotiators, before we got down to the bottom line of the Uruguay Round of GATT, were just so keen that Australia be seen to be promoting the purest of pure free trade motives that we did not actually go in there fighting for the interests of Australian industry, the Australian environment and Australian jobs at that stage.

I find it peculiar indeed that Australia, surrounded by ocean, placed between the Pacific and the Indian oceans, with very direct access to Asia, the west coast of the Americas and India, and the east coast of Africa, with substantial social and political links with the South Pacific and the Indo-ASEAN area, cannot operate a shipping line. Yet English shipping companies can operate so successfully that they can buy ours.

I know that this bill will pass, ANL will be disposed of, and the government and opposition will be delighted. I also know it really does not have anything to do with profitability, since both the government and the opposition want to sell off government owned businesses, whether or not they are profitable. I ask: is the supposed failure of ANL to operate profitably due to a problem with ANL or of government operated enterprises, or is it due to a failure of government to have any commitment to the idea of a shipping line as a public asset? If I could see what our government's shipping policy is, in order to be able to judge how well we are doing on it, that would be great, but I do not think anyone in the last few years has seen it or has seen any evidence that we have a shipping policy or that we actually see the benefits of having the ability to use shipping for our own transport throughout our mostly coastal communities in Australia.

Why do the Greens (WA) feel that it is important to have a shipping line as a public asset? Shipping is important. It is certainly one of the most environmentally friendly and energy efficient means of long-haul bulk freight transport. There is no reason that is not used extensively to tie together the coastal communities of Australia, and we should recall that the huge majority of Australians live on the coast, generally in a few large communities. Instead of reliance on shipping and rail links, we see an increased reliance on and government support for the long-haul road freight. I might add that certainly overseas, even in ASEAN countries, we see a lot of reliance also on air freight, which from a greenhouse perspective is, of course, disastrous.

The reason shipping should remain a public asset is that it is one of the best ways to assure that an adequate and appropriate level of support for shipping can be maintained. It is a way of assuring consumer choice by assuring there is an option for shipping at a reasonable cost. Instead, we see the sell-off of Stateships and the national shipping line, which will put all decisions about shipping costs and availability firmly in the corporate board rooms in Britain and in North America and other seafaring nations.

In this debate we have heard that there will be some kind of grandfathering clause, that there will be a period of grace, if you like, whereby some of the obligations to Australian public interest may be maintained. But there is no guarantee, after that time expires, that those obligations will continue—that is, on those services that P&O will not be able to turn around to a profit, that they will continue at all. The Greens feel that this is inappropriate and almost certainly will lead to a situation in which shipping services will become less available or more expensive, or both, and as well will lower standards for seagoing labour, probably allowing for a reduction in the physical state of ships with a consequent increase in shipping accidents, including those which have major impacts on the marine and coastal environment.
