After all this, I am wondering whether there is the ability to reconsider the point I made in this debate yesterday—that is, the ability for us as a parliamentary process to think about asking those people who benefit most from cut-price shipping, from poorer standards of crewing or ships that have not been properly maintained—and to think about who should take that liability. That is all I have been asking for in the last couple of years, a liability regime which actually specifies who is liable to pay those costs of environmental harm about which we have no clear idea at the moment.

Do you know why we are not doing that? The reason is that it might make us uncompetitive. In the final analysis, I am wondering whether we can step back from that all-empowering belief in international competition to see what the possible impacts would be if we lost the ability to make some standards as part of what we want to see by way of protecting our environment and our coastal communities. In conclusion, the Greens will not support this bill or the principle of selling off ANL. Australia should have a strong maritime presence and the people should, through government, have a direct role in this.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today considering the ANL Sale Bill 1995. Of course, we have only just completed debate on and consideration of the Finance and Public Administration References Committee report which, as I said earlier, shows that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has been quite incompetent in his handling of this sale. The combined cost to the taxpayer of the government's incompetent and inept handling of this sale totals around $200 million in forgone revenue to the Commonwealth. I want to make a number of other comments on issues surrounding the sale today, including where the sale is at at the moment, as this bill deals specifically with the implementation of the recommendations of the Wran board and sets into place a legislative framework to ensure that the sale goes ahead.

PARA.TAB: The coalition, of course, does not want in any way to delay the passage of this legislation. We believe, after the ineptitude and incompetence of this government through being unsuccessful in selling ANL after four years, and having lost in the order of $200 million on this so-called privatisation, that any further delay will add insult to injury. The point I make is that Australian taxpayers and all senators should understand that one of the problems faced in this sale is an effective veto control by the maritime unions over the whole sale process.

I say at the outset that members of the Maritime Union have very legitimate interests about their conditions of employment, their job security and the future of the company that many of them have worked in for a long time. Beyond that, they should not, even though they do, have what is an effective veto right on the sale of this asset. I put it to the Senate that that veto has cost Australian taxpayers an enormous amount of money over the past four years.

During the Senate committee's consideration of ANL two or three weeks ago, I said to Kym Bills from the Department of Transport the day after the P&O maritime negotiations broke down that I would have imagined that the department and the government would be considering going to the unions with a package to ensure that their interests were effectively bought out. If I remember correctly, I put it to Mr Bills that I suspected the government would negotiate a package similar to the waterfront reform package that was negotiated a couple of years before in order to try to achieve improvements in efficiencies on Australia's waterfront. Mr Bills admitted that the government was working on this option basically to ensure that the sale could proceed and to take away the Maritime Union's effective veto over the sale.

I think we need to analyse not only the politics but also the financial implications of what the Maritime Union and the government are doing. We saw during the waterfront industry reform process that the government paid out to waterfront union members hundreds of millions of dollars. If I recall correctly, it was in the order of $450 million, but I stand to be corrected.

The concept was to ensure that the labour force on the waterfront was reduced and that there were efficiency gains on the waterfront in terms of work practices. We saw only last week in BIE's report on international comparisons of efficiency on waterfronts that, although Australia has had improvements on the waterfront, in the international race for productivity and waterfront efficiency Australia has actually slipped behind. Even though we have certainly made some improvements since the 1970s and early 1980s, in the 1990s we are comparatively further behind our international trade competitors than we were prior to the government spending hundreds of millions of dollars on that waterfront reform process.

One of the reforms that this government cannot come to grips with is competition within the labour market. This government has actually decreased competition in the labour market, particularly in the area of representation. This government has presided over a massive amalgamation of trade unions. In some industries in the past there may have been a number of unions representing workers and workers had a choice of who represented them. Now that choice has disappeared. Effectively, the Maritime Union has monopoly control over the waterfront and, in the case of ANL, monopoly control over the future of that organisation.

It is not a veto right that they should have. As I said earlier—and I am trying to strike a balance—the union and its members do have very legitimate interests in terms of their employment conditions, their employment tenure and their pay. Those things are very important to those men and their families—and I presume women in some circumstances. The Wran proposal for restructuring—option 2 I think it is—would result in somewhere between 400 and 500 of those men being made redundant. It is very important that they have some sort of assurance as to their future if that is the option the government is to take. I am sure under the P&O sale option that many of them have legitimate fears for their futures. They have families to house, clothe, educate and feed. They have a legitimate interest in these matters.

There are also other interests—that is, the future of the entity and the taxpayers' interest. It is clearly unfair for what is effectively a group of fewer than 1,000 people to hold the whole of the Australian community to ransom and, as I said in the previous debate, to effectively cost this nation in the order of $200 million. I do not blame the Maritime Union for costing us $200 million but it is a part of the problem.

We may have to lever our way out of this problem with the Maritime Union to avoid a national waterfront stoppage, which is the threat that hangs over this sale process. In other words, if we do not do what the Maritime Union wants, and it is not a shareholder in the entity, it will shut down the whole country. When you think about this sale, just remember that this is the nation we live in and that this is the national parliament of a nation that has one of the worst current account deficits in the industrialised world, worse than Mexico's.

We need to trade. We need to ensure that the goods and services we produce in this country and sell to the rest of the world get to the markets. An important part of that trade, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President McGauran, particularly as a National Party member, would understand, goes across the waterfront. A lot of the produce from regional Australia goes across the waterfront. A lot of our manufactured goods, as the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), who is at the table, would understand, go across the waterfront. I am sure he understands that it is absolutely vital to keep those ports open.

We have here a threat from the Maritime Union that says, `If you go down this path against our wishes we will close down all of those ports.' We have seen the impact of that closure in previous actions. To avert that threat, the government, on the admission of Mr Bills from the Department of Transport, is looking at spending in excess of $25 million—I think that is the figure that has been bandied around. If you want to pay out 400 or 500 maritime workers, and if you start calculating at $100,000 a head, it does not take long to get up to very high multimillion dollar figures, but this of course is a further cost to the taxpayer.

That is the real situation of where this negotiation is at the moment. It is a sad and sorry state that we have a small and potentially militant union effectively controlling the whole process here. I reiterate, for the third time, that those people have a legitimate interest in their own future and the future of their families but it is not legitimate, it is not fair, for that small handful of people, particularly the leaders of that union, to effectively hold a veto over this whole process and cost the Australian taxpayers potentially hundreds of millions of dollars.

We have arrived at the position we are in now because of the bungling incompetence of a series of ministers who have had to handle ANL. The latest minister, Mr Brereton, has shown his incompetence, and that has been well documented in the report that was tabled this morning.

At the hearings held by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration recently, I put it to Neville Wran, the interim broad chairman of ANL, that when the minister said `you couldn't give away ANL'—although commercial people looking at the books of ANL and contemplating purchasing it would look at the fundamentals of that organisation before they decided on what price they would be prepared to pay for it—he was really saying to the trade union movement, which has an effective control over this which is well understood by the government and well understood by people who have been involved in this process, that the unions do have an effective majority share, a golden share. They have a veto over the whole process. When Mr Brereton says `you couldn't give it away', the leaders of the Maritime Union say, `You ripper!'

Because that union is effectively the shareholder, even though it does not own any shares and has not paid for any shares, it has a stake in this. Mr Brereton has said to the shareholder with no shares—you might call the Maritime Union a Clayton's shareholder—`You can't give it away', and the union has thought to itself, `We are not going to let you give it away. In fact, it's going to cost you a lot of money to give it away and we're going to make sure it's going to cost, it's going to hurt and it's going to be painful.' As Senator Gibson said earlier this morning, the cost so far is a couple of hundred million dollars. When we see over the next few days what the negotiations between Mr Beazley, the Maritime Union and P&O throw up, we will see the next instalment on that $200 million loss.

As I said, the figures bandied around already are $24 million, $25 million. I suggest that when you are trying to pay off 400 or 500 maritime workers who are currently employed by ANL, the figures could be a lot higher than that. I suspect that the government will give some sort of ongoing commitment that, in the case that anyone loses their job over the next couple of years as a result of the sale, it will give some sort of ongoing redundancy package.

Just remember that the community has already forgotten the special tax deal that has been done for these people—a tax deal that no-one else in Australia could get. Now we are looking at spending tens of millions of dollars as a way of buying out the Maritime Union's interest in this organisation, an interest that they have not paid anything for. I do not deny that they have invested a lot of their time and their lives in being part of that organisation. I am sure many of those people, in fact the majority of them, work long and hard for ANL and that they are proud Australians and part of our great seafaring tradition. But, of course, they get remunerated very well for that work anyway. So what I am trying to say is that, quite clearly, the government will pay out an interest, however, that it has not paid any consideration for in the first place.

The coalition of course supports the speedy passage of this bill; but it cannot go through this parliament without those comments being made. This process has given privatisation a bad name in Australia. That is sad because it can be a very effective part of a strategy to make Australia more competitive and more effective, to make the government more efficient, to ensure that taxpayers get value for their tax dollars and to ensure, in the words of Senator Margetts, that the government's ability to deliver a good social policy is enhanced as well.

But this government, particularly in the example of the ANL sale, has made a disastrous mess of the sale process. As Senator Minchin said during the debate on the report that was tabled this morning, the report and this process will provide to the world—those merchant banks and public policy makers who look at privatisation and how to do it properly—a case study in how not to do it. It is an international disgrace. It is an international case study in what not to do when you go about trying to sell a public asset.

It is an asset on which we should have had a net gain for the Commonwealth's books. The effect of the sale process will actually be a net loss of around $200 million—a brilliant achievement by a government whose epitaph will read: incompetent, inefficient and bad economic managers. And I cannot wait to see that epitaph written.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This ANL Sale Bill makes all the necessary legislative provisions to enable the final sale of the national shipping line, ANL, but it really is, as my colleagues have been saying, the culmination of an unbelievably incompetent sale process over the last four years. Of course, more than four years later we are still at the point where it is not in fact sold. That is largely a result not only of the government's incompetence but of union intransigence which my colleague Senator Campbell has detailed.

PARA.TAB: As is known, while we voted against this bill in the lower House because of the process used to deal with the bill, we are not opposing the bill in the Senate. But the coalition does have a number of concerns about certain provisions in the bill and, as we said this morning in discussing the report on the sale process, we are very critical of the government's incompetent handling of the sale.

As to the bill itself, we have expressed our considerable concern about the appropriation of up to $15 million in this bill. A very wide discretion is given to the Minister for Finance as a result of this bill. Clause 67(1) of the bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may make payments totalling no more than $15 million that
(a) are required to be made by sale agreement, or;
(b) the Minister believes are necessary or desirable to facilitate the transfer from an ANL body of an asset, liability, right or obligation described in Schedule B to the sale agreement.

It is an extremely wide discretion for the Minister for Finance to spend $15 million. The government's second reading speech identified three elements to this Commonwealth contribution: firstly, it was to cover the contingency that relevant financiers may exercise change of ownership rights; secondly, it was to cover expenses related to the transfer of businesses out of ANL to yet another government corporation being set up here, Retainco; and, thirdly, to provide a contingency for worse than expected losses by ANL since March. I presume we will have to call on that contingency. The bill itself does not mention those preconditions and does not limit the appropriation to those three elements. We do not have any reliable assurance that it will not be spent on other matters vaguely connected to the sale process.

PARA.TAB: When this matter was discussed with departmental officers in our inquiry into the bill itself, the responses were inadequate. We were referred to a secret letter from the Minister for Finance to the shadow minister for privatisation containing a promise that the government would stick to the elements referred to in the second reading speech. So it is a nod and a wink as to the government promising to restrict itself in the appropriation of the $15 million. We believe that is an unsatisfactory approach to the handling of government moneys.

The bill also establishes the new Commonwealth entity Retainco, which is basically set up to soak up the parts of ANL which P&O does not want. Again, this bill initially provided an open-ended authority to the minister for the provision of funds to Retainco. We complained about that provision in the bill. We note that the government is proposing to amend the bill to limit that appropriation to $1 million, at least in the first instance. It may well cost us more down the track.

By establishing Retainco through this bill, the Commonwealth government is going to be stuck in the shipping business for at least another 10 years. We are led to believe that the sale of ANL will get the government out of the shipping business. That is not the case. Strictly speaking, the government is going to be stuck in this mire for about another 10 years and, as we know from this bill, with potential liabilities of $183 million, having already lost—as my colleagues have been saying—$200 million through this whole process. We will sell ANL but still have in taxpayers' hands a potential liability of $183 million. All we can get from the government is a hope that Retainco will be `cash neutral to the Commonwealth over the long-term' which, coming from this government, is not much of an assurance at all.

The sale could actually cost the taxpayer. I said this morning that Minister Brereton was wrong to say you could not give ANL away. What is likely to occur is that we will be giving ANL away, but it may be even worse than that. The former ANL chairman, the well rewarded Neville Wran, in evidence to our committee on 20 October said that the maximum net proceeds from this sale would be $4.9 million. He then put on the record what the government failed to do—the worst case scenario—that it might result in a net cost to the government, to the taxpayer, of $12.1 million. In other words, it could cost the taxpayer $12.1 million simply to sell ANL to P&O, which is a ludicrous, farcical situation and encapsulates what a nonsense this wholesale process has been.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that does not include the redundancy package we talked about.

—That is right. My colleague Senator Campbell has pointed out the costs of potential redundancy packages that may be involved. The $12.1 million to get it off our hands may be just the start of yet another downward spiral for the taxpayer. As has been said repeatedly this morning, it has taken us four long years just to get to this point. The sale was announced by the government with great fanfare in the 1991 budget. Four years later, we still have it. ANL has cost us a fortune, and the sale is still not certain. As we said about the report, it is a testament to the unbelievable incompetence of the government.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Campbell said, three state Liberal governments in Western Australia, Victoria and South Australia have been responsible for cleaning up the mess left by their previous state Labor governments. They have had to dispose of much bigger and much more complex assets in far less time simply to ensure that their states do not go bankrupt as a result of the incompetence of state Labor governments.

In my state of South Australia, the state Liberal government inherited the State Bank, which had lost $3,000 million over the course of the Labor government. The state Liberal government managed to sell that in less than 12 months for what turned out to be a very good price. It was a much more complicated and difficult process than a small shipping line, which this government cannot sell in four years.

This whole ANL process is nothing more than a sorry saga of government confusion over its objectives; a failure to communicate those objectives; an appalling treatment of the former board, as I said this morning; an ineffective and inefficient sale process; and, as my colleague Senator Campbell has pointed to, union blackmail and intransigence. The report we had this morning on this whole process is a classic example of how not to sell a government business. It has been a disgraceful waste of taxpayers' money. For me and my colleagues on this side, it is a demonstration of why governments should avoid involvement in businesses like shipping in the first place. I know that the representatives of the Department of Finance are sympathetic to that view. This is really all about why you should never get involved in business enterprises from a government point of view.
A very interesting report on this issue in the Canberra Times of 9 November really illustrates what we are talking about. That report, headed `ANL "hamstrung by interference"', says:

The Australian National Line had been hamstrung by years of government interference and the maintenance of Australian Public Service wages and conditions for ANL staff, according to Victorian academic Keith Trace.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:

. . . the fact that ANL management and employees had been subject to public-service conditions had impeded the line's operational flexibility and made it difficult to maintain an appropriate structure for senior management.

Quite an independent professor is summing up the problems of a government being involved in a commercial enterprise like shipping. Inevitably it gets caught up in a bureaucratic approach and the politicisation of its operations, as was pointed out by former chairman Mr Bolitho, where the government maintains quite uneconomic operations within the company for purely political reasons. Not only is this a testament to how not to sell a government business; it is a testament to why government should never get involved in these businesses in the first place.

PARA.TAB: As Price Waterhouse-Salomon Bros said in their 1994 report on ANL:

SPEECH.PARA: ANL has represented a poor investment over the past 12 years for the Commonwealth. Commonwealth injected $160.5m in equity between 1983 & 1995, yet received only $20.7m in Dividends between 1983 and present day.

That is an appalling return on its investment. As we have been saying this morning, the real indictment of the government is the sale process. It finally made the right decision in 1991 to sell the company. That was the right decision. Ever since then, it has acted wrongly.

PARA.TAB: As is now clear and as the department, if not the government, admits, the board should have been restructured in 1991. A board should have been appointed with the brief to sell the business. Instead, we have had this very long drawn out sale process with very confused objectives. We have had government gutlessness, which is all it can be called, in the face of a militant union, and there has been very poor treatment of the former board.

The Audit Office report makes fascinating reading. Its terms of reference on the sale were very limited. It was very hamstrung on what it could say, particularly about government action. It independently exposed some of the very big deficiencies in the whole process. I summarise its findings. The Audit Office found that the old board was effectively denied natural justice over its sacking by the minister, Laurie Brereton, in August 1984; that the old board should have been given the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Bros report; that there was inadequate documentation of departmental advice to ministers relating to that report; that the government sale objectives were unclear; that there was inadequate cooperation between the task force on asset sales, the transport department and ANL; that Minister Brereton's extraordinary statement of 22 August could have an eventual effect on the value of ANL, on the day to day operations of ANL and on the morale of the work force. The majority of the Senate committee which reported today has endorsed that finding and commented critically on Minister Brereton's extraordinarily irresponsible statement in August last year. Given the constraints that applied to the Audit Office, that report is damning of the government about the process.

Minister Brereton's actions and his statements on the sale have been absolutely hopeless. He is the great walking disaster of this government. I am amazed that they continue to tolerate him as a minister. He was drummed out of New South Wales politics after almost single handedly destroying the Wran government. Now he is almost single handedly destroying the Keating government.

He has overseen a disaster in industrial relations. We are now seeing the ramifications of that. He has been a disaster in relation to Sydney airport and in relation to ANL. His statement that you could not give away ANL must go down as one of the most irresponsible statements ever made by a minister. He has been proven wrong, because the government is giving it away.
The Canberra Times, in its editorial of 23 October, summed up the situation independently. These are not our words. The Canberra Times said about the whole process:

SPEECH.PARA: To say the Government's handling of the sale of ANL has been clumsy and inadequate would be an understatement. Not to put too fine a point on it, the Minister for Transport, Laurie Brereton, thoroughly misjudged the sensitivities involved and the Government has been made to live with the consequences.

PARA.TAB: Regardless of what the Government's final decision will be, Minister Brereton's off-the-cuff remark that the Government could not give the national shipping line away, will always overshadow the outcome and raise serious doubts about whether Australian taxpayers were allowed to get the best possible return from a national asset.

SPEECH.PARA: That sums up the disaster that Minister Brereton has presided over. That statement by Minister Brereton, which presumably had some machiavellian political motive to do with the Labor Party and the trade unions, was a response to the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Bros report. That report, as the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee discovered in its inquiry, cost the taxpayers half a million dollars.

PARA.TAB: The government effectively rejected that report. It recommended an informal liquidation of the company. The government rejected that, sacked the board, put Mr Wran in place and gave him and his fellows members of the board $816,000 to restructure the company. He got $300,000 for his part-time job. I noted this morning that Mr Bolitho, who spent 10 years of his life trying to build up this asset, got a paltry $40,000 a year. Mr Wran earned as much in one year as Mr Bolitho probably earned in his 10 years of chairmanship of the company.

The Wran board recommended the sale of the company, not a restructure, and that a restructure would have been a disaster. For the last 12 months we have had this incredible saga of differing objectives in relation to the company.

I conclude by noting with sadness that the whole process of selling this government asset has been a farce. As my colleague said, it is a tragedy because it could be used by some to give privatisation a bad name. What it really says is that the government should not have got into this business in the first place but that when it decided to sell the asset it should have sold it, instead of spending four years doing what this government has done and made a farce of the whole process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate on the sale of the Australian National Line. The sale is not without significance, at least in an historical aspect. The Commonwealth government first became a shipowner in interesting circumstances. That was during World War I when the Commonwealth seized and retained a number of enemy vessels. In 1916 it established the Australian Government Line. That is the history of ANL.

PARA.TAB: Since then the world has moved on, and privatisation has become a buzz word. The opposition supports the government's privatisation program in principle and has done so over the last 13 years of this government's reign. But, as Senator Campbell rightly pointed out, this government happens to give privatisation a very bad name indeed. Privatisation is a very simple concept; that is, not in all circumstances but in most circumstances, the private sector can run an enterprise better than the public sector. And that has been proven over and over again.

The revenue gained through privatisation is a benefit to the taxpayers. It can be utilised to reduce long-term debt and government can be free to get on to administer what it does best. So if that asset is sold efficiently, the Australian public obviously are better off. But we have a very sorry tale in asset sales by this government. They have not used properly what they have managed to sell. They have not used it to retire national debt and long-term debt. Rather, they have used it on current expenditure, feeding it into their budget deficit. As a result, the government have not once reached their target for asset sales, bar a successful partial float of the Commonwealth Bank. That is about the only successful sale they have had.

Since 1991 through to 1994-95, in each budget announcement they have never reached their target. In 1991 they budgeted for some $1 billion worth of asset sales and they reached a target of $162 million. In 1991-92, they budgeted for some $625 million worth of asset sales and they reached half that figure. In the 1992-93 budget, they budgeted for $1.6 billion worth of asset sales and they reached only $800 million. In 1993-94, a very ambitious $2.4 billion worth of asset sales were budgeted for, and they did not reach that figure either. We know only too well that the sale of Qantas appeared on each one of those budget estimates. It has only recently been sold. It took them four long years to sell off Qantas.

But nothing really matches the fiasco that we have in the sale of the Australian National Line. And a fiasco it is. Events in this ongoing saga have even surpassed the legislation we have before us today. We are told in the second reading speech by the Minister for Finance, Mr Kim Beazley—and I quote from his second reading speech to give an indication of how events have even surpassed the bill we have before the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANL Sale Bill makes the necessary legislative provision to facilitate the sale of the Commonwealth's shares in ANL Limited although agreement has been reached under which the finalisation of the sale to P&O Australia has been deferred until 31 October 1995—
Of course, we are in mid-November. It continues:

In order for the option of a sale to P&O to be quickly carried out at the completion of negotiations between unions and P&O, it will be necessary for the ANL Sale Bill to be passed by both Houses of Parliament by the end of October . . . Any further delay creates uncertainty, with the risk of consequent damage to ANL's market share in its various businesses.

Even today the truth is that no such agreement stands. We are still in a very uncertain stage of the sale of ANL. It is always potentially on the collapse list. The prospects of sale, I would say, are still unlikely before the next election or this side of Christmas.

PARA.TAB: Since the first announcement of the sale of ANL in the 1991 budget, we still have uncertainty and doubt about the sale of ANL. I am told that, each day the ANL sale is held up ticks by, it is costing taxpayers some $2 million. The Minister for Transport, Mr Laurie Brereton, must take the greater proportion of responsibility and blame for the problems that have surrounded this sale of the National Line.

As other speakers have pointed out, back on 22 August 1994, some 12 months ago, the minister made those now immortal comments of managerial inexcellence when he said, `You couldn't give it away.' Subsequently, he pulled the ANL off the sale list. Such damage was believed to have been done to the sale price by this comment that it was found necessary for the Senate finance and public administration references committee to establish an inquiry into whether the proposed sale of ANL was conducted with the prudence, integrity, skills and propriety necessary to protect its value. How could it be? The conclusions are obvious with the minister making those sorts of comments. The report was tabled today by Senator Bell. The majority view was the obvious, that those comments did do damage to the sale value of ANL. I quote from page 9 of that report:

SPEECH.PARA: In the view of the majority of members, the statements carried the potential to have a negative influence on interests of the Commonwealth and they question the prudence of the Minister's conduct in making statements which were potentially damaging to the sale process without providing the full documentation relied upon to support those statements.

It was the former chairman of the line, Mr Bolitho, who told that committee that the minister, by his comments, had destroyed a public asset worth some $100 million and, as he said, for no reason other than political expediency. Given this minister's history in political expediency you would have to attach a great deal of truth to Mr Bolitho's comments. It is not just a Senate committee or a former chairman of ANL who have pointed the bone at the minister; indeed, the Audit Office back on 6 December 1994 in a report tabled in the Senate said it is `clear that the actions and statements of those involved in the sale process can influence the perceptions of the market to the point where the seller will be perceived as a "distressed seller"'. That is the full effect of the minister's comments. It went on to say:

This is most likely to result in lower price for the asset. For this reason it is important that the public officials involved in the sale of Commonwealth assets at all times act with discretion in order not to prejudice the Commonwealth's position.

That report back in December 1994 sparked another report by the Auditor-General, under instruction from the Senate, and which was handed down in August this year. It was another report on the debacle of the ANL sale. Even after this very tortured path that the minister took when he sacked the ANL board and its chairman Mr Bolitho, took back control of ANL, appointed his two mates Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull and relaunched the sale of ANL, you would have to say today that there is still no great certainty that this sale is not going to hit the rocks again. As I said before, as each day ticks by and the unions hold off giving their full agreement and confirmation to this sale, the taxpayer loses $2 million.

PARA.TAB: That is the same union that is out on strike at the moment on another matter. They have a lot on their plate, this maritime workers union. As soon as they have finished their strike against CRA and the industrial relations system in this country, they will probably go out again on the sale of ANL. So this union really is holding the country to ransom. They have that many strikes banked up they cannot get out quickly enough.

The minister has found himself captive to this union, not just on industrial relations but on this matter too, with regard to privatisation. The union has been a party to this debacle. It has always been the desired option of the union not to sell ANL but to restructure it. In fact, it had some idea at one stage that it would buy shares in ANL. The shares that the union was going to buy in ANL, in the hope of keeping it propped up, were going to be paid for out of the workers' superannuation fund. That is how it was going to fund this idiotic purchase of ANL shares, but even the union dropped that idea. The imprimatur for the union's purchase of shares in ANL had the nod from the ACTU. All the blocking and delaying tactics by the union have had the imprimatur of the ACTU and Mr Kelty.

In September 1994 the union ran a crippling strike in protest against the ANL sale which shut down ports across Australia. The strike cost some $55 million. It was a crude but successful attempt to pressure the federal government into committing itself financially to the very wrecked Australian National Line. Since then the maritime union has put up every hurdle and every delaying tactic possible in an attempt to block this sale. To date the union has been successful.

In many respects the shambles that surrounds the ANL sale encapsulates the government's problems in completing the very necessary micro-economic reform required for an efficient and competitive economy. We have a union movement that is resistant to change and a government run by incompetent and expedient ministers. All this is at the cost of Australia's competitiveness. That is borne out in a recent report by the government's own Bureau of Industry Economics entitled International benchmarking overview 1995.

It was mentioned some time in debate yesterday that the government has already put the spin doctors on this report. The Bureau of Industry Economics is a government body reporting directly to the government. However, the government does not want to hear the truth. The report reveals that the delivery of many vital business inputs—including telecommunications, electricity and rail freight—is marred by low labour productivity. It warns that Australia risks falling even further behind the rest of the world if the government allows the pace of reform to slow. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Now is certainly not the time for reform fatigue.

The BIE report says that the waterfront and coastal shipping remains one of the key problem areas for Australia—and that is no surprise—with very long and variable unloading times and high prices characterising the movement of containers through our ports.

PARA.TAB: The report goes on to say that the rate of reform in coastal shipping has slowed in the past few years, with Australia's total vessel costs higher than the corresponding costs in all comparable countries except the United States and Japan. This was mainly due to manning costs which are some five to 17 per cent greater than the average costs of comparable countries, and three times greater than the lowest costs in Germany. Relatively high fuel prices, repair and maintenance costs and other operating costs, such as dry-docking, insurance and storage also make the industry struggle internationally and competitively.

There is a reason why ANL ships spend more time in dry dock than those of its rivals. Australian crews will not carry out maintenance, such as overhauling engines and scraping rust, while the ship is operating. It is estimated that, because of this, the direct and indirect costs run at some $1 million per year for each ANL ship. This is just one example of how inflexible work practices have wounded the national shipping line.

The truth is that consistent maritime strikes and low labour productivity compared with our competition are the major factors why it is now necessary to sell ANL. I accept that foreign owned lines run conditions that we would never concede to—the ships of shame—and where many of the workers are exploited. However, there is great room for improvement from the Australian work force. The Senate can only hope that this bill is of value in progressing the eventual sale of ANL and that, when the minister is less distracted on matters of industrial relations, which are now wreaking havoc in the economy, and when the Maritime Union returns to work after its five-day strike against Comalco, both parties will turn their minds back to the sale of ANL so that we have a successful conclusion to this fiasco.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating government business order of the day No. 1, ANL Sale Bill 1995. This is a debate which has run over several days. It is now for me to wind it up and conclude the second reading part of the debate. This is a bill from the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) for arrangements going to the sale of the Australian National Line.

PARA.TAB: In this debate, the opposition coalition have indicated that they will support the passage of this legislation. The Australian Democrats and the Western Australian Greens have indicated that they will oppose this legislation. Given that the government will vote for its own legislation, the bill will pass this chamber with the dissent of the Democrats and the Greens. In responding to the debate, I am mindful that this bill will carry and become law, and thus enable the Australian national shipping line to go ahead and be sold. That is a desirable outcome for reasons that I will go to in just a minute.

A number of senators have participated in this debate. I thank all of those who have made a contribution. ANL is, of course, a shipping line. Things that go to sea, dock alongside wharves and involve labour on board ships or on the wharf attract a great deal of controversy in this chamber. We have found that the vehicle of a debate about a sale bill has become an opportunity for a number of senators to express their views about matters shipping and waterfront—not all of those views being directly pointed at this bill. Nonetheless, it has provided a platform to make speeches about those things. It is not my intention to deal with those speeches in any detail, because they are beside the point. I think it is better to stick to the point.

The bill before the chamber has several key features. The main ones being that it includes savings and transitional provisions in respect of employee entitlements, similar to those made in respect of the previous major asset sales. It provides for the transfer of ANL assets, liabilities, rights and obligations that are not being purchased by P&O to the Commonwealth or a nominated wholly owned company—in this case, a company called RetainCo for the purposes of this bill. It provides a statutory government guarantee over the obligations of that company, RetainCo.

It makes provision for the protection of national interest issues arising from the sale of ANL and for the retention by the Commonwealth of a golden share in ANL. It enables the Commonwealth to enforce the rights relating to national interests by seeking injunctions from the Federal Court. It appropriates funds up to $15 million that may be necessary to meet any Commonwealth contribution required under the sale contract or to cover the expenses of transferring the assets and liabilities out of ANL. It appropriates any funds required in respect of working capital for the current financial year for RetainCo, or any former ANL companies transferred to the Commonwealth. I note that the government has agreed to move an amendment here, capping expenditure under this appropriation at $1 million. The bill will repeal automatically with effect from 1 January 1996 if the draft sale contract with P&O cannot be executed by 31 December this year. There is a number of other provisions in this bill. They are consequential to those objectives, and I will not reiterate them now.

In speaking to this bill, as I have said, a number of the arguments have been not to the point of the bill. If I can summarise the opposition arguments about this bill, they are easily categorised as, firstly, the government here is incompetent; secondly, the unions assert too much influence; and, thirdly, ANL has been mismanaged and mishandled. In summary, I think that is what the opposition has said of this bill and of this government.

Let me just deal with that very briefly. There is a mood in the air that Australia may have an election soon. One could say that if the Labor Party parted the Red Sea and marched its troops across, the opposition would attack the Labor Party for being incompetent, for being in the hands of the unions that represent those troops and for having mishandled the whole manoeuvre, because there have been reports that people have walked on water, so why did they go to the whole effort of parting the Red Sea when they should have, if they were competent, walked across the top of it? The political debate is just going a bit crazy, so allegations of incompetence are thrown about willy-nilly. I do not intend to dignify those allegations any more.

The Greens and the Australian Democrats have attacked this legislation from a slightly different view. They argue, and the government acknowledges the strength of this point, that Australia as a massive island continent requires a national shipping line. They go on from that point to argue, therefore, that this shipping line, owned by the Australian people, should not be sold.

I agree, and the government has the view, that Australia as an island continent requires the services of a national shipping line. The difference here is: who should own it—the government or private enterprise? We take the view that in these circumstances, where there is a private company interested in buying it, it can be appropriately sold with the government maintaining a golden share in that shipping line—ensuring that it is crewed by Australians, that it sails under an Australian flag and that its headquarters are in Australia—and the government will utilise that golden share to enforce those conditions. In those circumstances, we think it is appropriate to transfer the ownership from public assets to a privately owned operation.

I just use this occasion to respectfully point out the logical flaw in the argument of the Democrats and the Greens that yes, of course, we do need to service our coast, but who owns the vehicle that does that is another matter. That does not seem to have been addressed adequately in any of the criticism flowing from the crossbenches.

There is one other thing, which normally I would not get into. The Bureau of Industry Economics, in its most recent report on micro-economic reform, has been mentioned by a number of speakers. The Bureau of Industry Economics is a bureau within my portfolio. I am here, of course, in this debate representing the Minister for Finance and not my own portfolio, but my own portfolio of Industry, Science and Technology has within it the Bureau of Industry Economics. It reports to me, and it tabled last week a report card on Australia's progress to micro-economic reform.

I am, of course, familiar with that report. It has been massively abused and misrepresented. Some of that misrepresentation occurred in this debate here in this chamber again today. One ought to always look at these reports in context. This report sought to compare Australia's performance in various elements of its transport and services economy with the very best performed economies in the world. For example, in telecommunications, when the bureau looked around the world to find the cheapest telecommunications company, it compared Telecom to Iceland.

One of the economic commentators said, `Interesting comparison'. But only 250,000 people live in Iceland. Most of them live in Reykjavik, the capital, and the others live down the peninsula. To set up a telecommunications system for them does not adequately compare with setting up an Australian telecommunications system for 18 million people on this massive continent. The cost comparisons are not as simple but, certainly, Iceland has the most efficient telecommunications system. So we were comparing Australia with Iceland in that study. I might say that on telecommunications we came out of that study extremely well.

The subject here is shipping, and the waterfront has been dragged into it. Interestingly, those who have criticised Australia's waterfront performance in this debate neglected to mention that, in terms of bulk loading, the BIE study found that we have the most efficient waterfront in the world. If the waterfront was an Olympic Games event, Australia would have won the gold medal in bulk loading. No-one bothered to mention that in this debate; they only focused on the other area and drew the conclusion that the sky is about to fall in and that this country is doomed. I just want to get the record straight and in context.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being selective.

—If you are going to venture into this field and pretend that you are doing it logically and comprehensively, do it that way, otherwise be open to the allegation I now make, that there is selective quoting in order to make a case rather than a proper analysis of what are the circumstances. It is how you actually read this report. Certainly it found that progress on the waterfront on container movements had not matched earlier achievements. As someone said on the other side, `And therefore the whole thing has been a waste of time'. But it did not find that. When you take the whole of the period in which we as a government began the process of reforming the Australian waterfront and making it more efficient—no previous government had done so; when the opposition was in government it did not do it—then you see that considerable efficiency gains have been achieved over that whole time.

PARA.TAB: It is true that, from the report, there is a need to energise that further. But, when we look again at what is happening on the waterfront itself, we see deals being done for a massive reinjection of capital investment to improve the technology. It is not a matter of people working harder; it is a matter of people using the cranage and the massive technology needed to shift containers. If you have not got best technology you are not best efficient. The new capital investment coming onto the waterfront will lift the efficiency of Australia's waterfront rates, and they are the logical conclusions from the waterfront report.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Bob Collins thought three years ago, but it has not worked.

—It has worked. Read the report and you will see that it has worked. You want to read the report to suit your political view, not read the report to see what it says. Anyway, as I said, the only reason I diverted to that was because part of the debate touched on a matter in my portfolio which I thought, since I was the duty minister, I would make an observation about, but it is not related to this bill.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge that the opposition will support this bill and that the Democrats and the Greens will oppose it. The government, which originated the bill, will support it, so the bill will pass. I thank all senators who participated in the debate, although I do not agree with the way they have conducted themselves. I commend this bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 67, page 38, after subclause (2) insert the following subclause:

TAB.TAB: "(2A) The Minister may not enter into arrangements under subsection (2) that expose, or could expose, the Commonwealth to a liability totalling more than $1,000,000.".

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 16 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main provisions of the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill involve: a new mechanism to allow the allocation of commercial television broadcasting licences in solus markets; an improved mechanism to allow the allocation of commercial radio broadcasting licences in solus markets, particularly when licence area plans have not yet been written; changes to the pay television anti-siphoning provisions for significant televised events; clarification of the nature of cooperation allowed between satellite licensees A and B under their exemptions from the ownership and control restrictions of the principal act; and new 15 per cent deemed control provisions—in layman's terms the `Get Packer' amendments.

PARA.TAB: I will deal firstly with the first part which is relatively uncontroversial. The coalition supports the substance of the provisions for the allocation of commercial television broadcasting licences in solus markets. As far as commercial radio licences are concerned, under the old section 39 the ABA was required to allocate an additional commercial radio broadcasting licence to any solus incumbent, provided that there were at least two spare commercial radio licences. Legal advice to the ABA was that this condition could not be satisfied without the completion of a licence area plan.

Delays in the preparation of licence area plans in most areas of Australia have meant that no additional licences have been allocated to solus radio operators anywhere in the country. These amendments replace the old section 39. Apart from minor clarification of the circumstances under which an additional licence may be allocated, there are several significant changes.

Firstly, the ABA may not allocate an additional licence unless it is of the opinion that a suitable broadcasting spectrum is available. While existing frequency allotment plans lapse and ministerial reservations must be taken into account, the ABA may form such an opinion in their absence. These changes will allow the ABA to allocate additional commercial radio licences immediately rather than wait for the completion of a lap in a licence area. The ABA must attach technical conditions to an additional licence in the absence of a lap.

Secondly, the ABA may not allocate an additional licence in a licence area when there is excessive overlap between the area and a different service licensed in another area. The test for excessive overlap is being changed to make it easier for smaller commercial broadcasters to get an additional licence where their service area is substantially overlapped by another solus operator who is entitled to a second channel.

Thirdly, to encourage early applications for additional licences, prospective licensees will have 60 days after the proclamation of the amendments in which to lodge an application for an additional licence. Special provision is made for incumbent licensees to make an application later if they subsequently become eligible for an additional licence. Applications may also be lodged in anticipation of changes in relevant industry conditions which might make an incumbent licensee eligible for an additional licence.

These changes are long overdue. Since 1984, the government has been promising supplementary licences in solus markets. Now with an election in a few months the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, has undergone a death bed conversion and said that he will fix the problem by allocating additional commercial licences and, at the same time, allow the ABA to call for additional licence applications. The ABA process will continue. In theory, once they have completed an area they release the plan and they are able to call for supplementary licences, but to date only one licence has been granted.

The industry has long advocated these changes and whether it was because of obtuseness or ignorance, or a combination of both, the minister was simply blind to those calls until he attended the annual conference of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters several months ago at which time he was taken out into the backroom and basically bashed up. The industry made it clear to him that it was simply not prepared to stand by and see a process continue probably analogous to the pay television saga. That is, when we were in government in 1980 we gave the green light to pay television and 15 years later it is finally coming to fruition. The radio industry saw shades of a repetition of that fiasco, given that Michael Duffy had been talking about granting supplementary licences as long ago as 1984.

I suppose it is gratifying that the minister was persuaded to see reason, but it is disappointing that he could not have come to this conclusion without that political pressure being applied. Perhaps he was not getting any directions from his master's voice but the fact remains that at long last we have changes that are in the interests of the industry.

There is one area that I am aware of in northern New South Wales and southern Queensland where there can in fact be slight problems because of this necessary overlap provision. Having looked carefully at both the proposal and the counter-proposal which would follow from opposing this amendment, if we were to oppose it listeners in some areas would get one licence service, some would get two and some would get three depending on their area. Under this provision listeners will get at least two in every area. That ultimately is a more satisfactory and fairer outcome. In those circumstances, whilst I can understand the concerns that have been expressed, and in the interests of accommodating the consumers as much as possible, these amendments will do their best to achieve that outcome.

As far as the anti-siphoning provisions are concerned let me simply say that this has been yet another farce. I can recall that more than 12 months ago after a very exciting three-test cricket series in Pakistan it was suggested that the series should be taken off the anti-siphoning list. After stalling for some months, the minister finally said he would refer the matter to the ABA. The end result was that we did not even get a decision on whether that ought to be made available to the pay television operators for something like 12 months after the event. That is an absolute absurdity. Who knows what was going on in Mr Lee's head, but once again we finally have legislation that will at least address one aspect of the anti-siphoning legislation.

I can certainly understand why the Australian Democrats have moved their amendment to say that after a period of 24 hours has elapsed it ought to be then automatically available subject to the minister's gazetting and presumably explaining why there is a need for a further delay. The government's proposal is that after a period of seven days the program ought to be available. As I understand it, the principle reason for that delay is that some events go on over a period of days—Wimbledon goes for about two weeks—and, therefore, some greater period of time is needed to ensure that you are not actually running day one when day seven is in play.

It is not a clear-cut solution, and I do not know that seven days is the most satisfactory outcome either. But at this stage we would take the view that at least it is addressing some of the complications that will arise from successive programming of a single event. In those circumstances we will support that amendment.

There are other provisions that I do not want to spend a great deal of time on. The cross media provisions between satellite licensees generally make sense. So I will come to what really is the vice of this legislation—that is, the notorious `Get Packer' amendments.

Those amendments typify all that is wrong in the Labor Party's approach to media policy. I do not for one moment believe they are the work of Michael Lee who is essentially a political doormat to the dominion of his master's voice. The architect of these disgracefully grubby changes is the man who has driven Labor's media for mates policy over the last decade—the man who uses media policy as an instrument of patronage to punish his enemies and reward his mates. This is a classic example of the politics of vengeance. Paul Keating has consistently corrupted public policy principles in this area and this is no exception. It was only yesterday that we saw him stoop to new depths of political amorality in simply ignoring very explicit findings that one of his ministers had lied. But I do not think any of us were surprised that his standards led him in that direction.

This change is simply another example of using the media rules as not only a personal plaything but as a political weapon to bludgeon the proprietors, reward the good and punish the bad. We now have a situation where the Prime Minister is simply pursuing a vendetta against one media baron whilst desperately trying to not upset another. Of course, they have both made it clear what they really think of the government's performance in recent years; one having said that there was a time for a changing of the guard, the other in effect saying that the state of the economy was a disgrace. They have both put very significant nails in the Prime Minister's coffin but, once again, we have differential treatment when it comes to changes to media rules.

The cross-media rules were designed to ensure plurality and diversity. But these proposals do nothing; they simply impose an arbitrary 15 per cent irrespective of the notion of control—in fact, they ignore that. So you have this nonsensical situation where Prime television is in excess of 15 per cent as far as Sunshine is concerned; Seven is clearly in control because it has in excess of 50 per cent; and yet Prime would be deemed to be in control under these arrangements. No discretion, simply two quite conflicting commercial interests, yet both regarded as being in control—an absolute nonsense.

In the same way, when the ABA made its findings in relation to Packer not being in control of the Fairfax organisation, they did that on the basis that Conrad Black was in control, as everyone in the country knows, as Mr Black himself has asserted many times, and that was the fact. The government was clearly hoping that the ABA would do its dirty work for it and make an adverse finding. When it did not, the sky fell in and we had the politics of retribution.
One only has to look at recent statements on this matter to realise how farcical and totally insincere these amendments are. In August 1994, Michael Lee was saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's cross-media ownership rules are working well.
February 1995:
I'm quite happy to leave the responsibility with the ABA.
On AM on 20 February this year:
Control is the key. Control is fundamental to promoting diversity and under the act control is the trip-wire. In some ways it doesn't matter whether somebody's above or below the 15 per cent.

That is precisely right: what is the relevance of 15 per cent? It is an entirely arbitrary and capricious concept. It is meaningless, other than throwing a dart at the dartboard, if you are not concerned about control. And cross-media rules are all about trying to ensure that people are not in a position to control more than one market. So this is simply an abdication of all of the underlying principles of cross-media rules and transparently an example of where politics has overtaken policy once again.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that Michael Lee was utterly humiliated on all this. Not only having said that the rules worked well, he was aware of his master's voice back in late 1994 on Lateline saying:

SPEECH.PARA: You can't even try to be confident about resisting the shift of these technologies. I mean, it's not going to be very long. Here's News Ltd with Star TV. What are you going to do about that? Poke your tongue at it? Throw a bill up in the air? Table a motion in the House?

In other words, Mr Keating was quite relaxed about the need for an overhaul of the existing cross-media rules and, indeed, Michael Lee himself was promising that earlier this year. We are told there will be a review this year. Of course, there should be and that review ought to precede any of these changes. These are not even bandaid changes; these are simply mogul specific changes.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lee said back in February this year that it was up to the ABA alone, that the government was not going to intervene; they would make the decision. They did, but they made the wrong decision as far as Mr Keating was concerned. That is why we now have this transparently political attack.

The high watermark of hypocrisy in this whole debate arises when one realises that two press releases were put out by Michael Lee, one on 3 May and another on 27 June, in which it was said that the 15 per cent fixed ownership limit would be applied to the control provisions in the act. It was also said that company interests currently caught by the act would be widened to include interests that are linked to company performance and that this would also apply to future foreign interests. There would be grandfathering arrangements.

Despite all of that, those provisions are not in this bill. They have simply been put to one side. A spokesman for Mr Lee said on 25 October last month that the amendments to close off the debenture loophole were proving hard to draft. I do not think there is anyone in the country who believes that proposition. There is nothing difficult about this proposal. It is simply being deferred for political reasons. Obviously it would accommodate the concerns of CanWest which, whilst accepting the grandfathering rule in principle, is concerned that any subsequent changes in the structure of Channel Ten would mean that it might lose the protection of grandfathering. But to justify omitting something that the government solemnly said would be in this legislation on the transparently unbelievable basis that the provisions were too hard to draft simply exposes this whole legislation for what it is.

We were told, if you read the Sydney Morning-Herald, that the minister still has plans to have the subsequent amendments passed before parliament rises. We only have two further weeks. There is no indication on any running sheets I have seen that we are going to get any such amendments. I would say it is London to a brick on—and if Senator Collins wants to have a bet on that, I would be more than happy to accommodate him—that there is nothing more certain than that we will not see those amendments before the parliament rises. In other words, we will be left with a stark naked proposition simply directed at one media proprietor, conceived in vengeance, as I heard Don Watson say the other day in another context, designed entirely to overturn not only the ABA but the whole concept of control, the whole principles upon which cross-media rules have been based in this country for almost a decade and entirely in the context of remarks which Mr Packer made some months ago. Mr Packer having had the gall to say that John Howard would make a good Prime Minister, Paul Keating has been hell-bent ever since on exacting revenge.

I do not need to go into all the examples that are on the public record of the way in which the Prime Minister treats media policy, or what Max Sutch said about interviews with him, how his conversation is littered with references to `our crowd' and `getting even', or what Shawcross said in his magnificent biography of Murdoch about how Keating deliberately went over to the ski slopes of Aspen to inform Mr Murdoch and, indeed, separately Mr Packer of changes that he had in mind. But he did not tell the Herald and Weekly Times about those changes.

When the ABA would not do his dirty work, the man who invented cross-media rules to get his enemies in Flinders St is now changing those rules to get his enemies in Park St. Less than three months after Mr Lee claimed the cross-media rules did not need modifying for two or three years, and said that control was much more important than any number of shares that someone might own, suddenly we have the government up to its usual tricks of putting personalities and political paybacks before the national interest, not prepared to try to fix a third world media ownership regime that was fast becoming the laughing stock of the region but simply pursuing a political vendetta for the obvious motivations that have always driven the Prime Minister.

So we will not be supporting these changes. We make it perfectly clear that if the government is in any shape or form serious, which is it is not, about having an effective cross-media regime then it ought to do what the act requires and what they themselves have promised, and that is commence the review under the Broadcasting Services Act, take account of what is happening around the world not only in the UK right now in terms of share of voice and cross-media exchange rates but legislation which has recently gone through the US Congress and which has liberalised these rules in a number of respects.

That is the sensible and proper course to take. If you are interested in governance, you go through those processes and you do your best to come up with public policy solutions. This is simply yet another classic example of the way in which Paul Keating plays the game. It has nothing to do with Michael Lee. Michael Lee is, as always, a mere cipher in this portfolio. This is the Prime Minister at his worst, doing what is now second nature to him. He is using the media laws for naked political purposes, and we will not wear it.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Before I call the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I remind the honourable senator who has just spoken that it is courtesy to use proper titles when we are referring to our colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston is just a big bully. I will speak briefly in respect of the amendments that the government will be moving during this debate. I will briefly address the concluding remarks of Senator Alston. I hate to destroy a terrific conspiracy theory, but I am afraid that I am going to have to blow a hole in the one that has just been advanced by Senator Alston.

PARA.TAB: The amendments on the 15 per cent ownership rule are not anti-mogul or to get Mr Packer or anything else. They also have nothing whatever to do with any view that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) may or may not have on this issue. They in fact have everything to do with the position put to cabinet by the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee. As someone who was actually there listening to the arguments at the time, I can, in fact, give you that from the horse's mouth. This conspiracy theory has of course been given a great run by Senator Alston, but it is nonsense.

The reason that it is a nonsense is actually on the public record. The facts, rather than a conspiracy theory, are a matter of public record. The ABA itself advised the minister earlier this year that the current ownership and control rules have been perceived as causing a certain degree of public uncertainty. The reason for that public uncertainty, of course, is obvious. The provisions in the act for anything over 15 per cent relate to a matter of judgment. Someone else in the ABA would have to decide whether control was exercised.

The Australian Broadcasting Authority, not Mr Keating or anyone else, pointed out to the minister that this was causing a certain degree of public uncertainty. The ABA also advised the minister that there had been a possible lessening of public confidence in the predicability of those rules, partly because the ABA is required to exercise judgment in determining control, as I have just said, and partly because investors have been able to structure substantial holdings of quasi-equity interests in Australian media companies so as to comply with the control provisions of this act. The establishment of a 15 per cent fixed limit will overcome these difficulties.

It just needs to be firmly placed on the record that the conspiracy theory is a load of opposition nonsense. The ABA's advice to the minister is in fact well known. It is directly on the basis of that independent and expert advice from the Australian Broadcasting Authority to this government. In order to restore that confidence and predictability in the 15 per cent rules, which of course already are the threshold, and in order to stop the quasi-equity provisions from circumventing that rule—based directly on that advice from the ABA—the minister in fact proposed these changes.

It was interesting to hear Senator Alston talk about the predictability and certainty in respect of broadcasting. As the Hansard record and the press record will show, Senator Alston stands alone in adopting more positions on media policy than a white ball in a snooker game. You have only to look at all the things Senator Alston has said on that question of pay TV, which he touched upon, to see that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that you would want to go back over that.

—I do not mind. It needs to be firmly stated that this conspiracy theory that Senator Alston advanced about the 15 per cent is a nonsense. The 15 per cent rules are before the Senate because of very direct advice provided by the ABA to Minister Lee about the perceived uncertainty, lack of confidence by the public in these rules and the quasi-equity mechanisms that were being used to circumvent them. That is why the amendment is before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: In response to Senator Alston's query about the further amendments in respect of this matter, I am advised that it is the government's intention to have these introduced into the parliament in the communications and tourism legislation which will come before the parliament. I have not checked, but I think it is No. 15 on the Notice Paper. They will be dealt with when we get to that.

Since the introduction of the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill it has been subject to scrutiny by the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communication and the Arts Legislation Committee. The committee's report, which was tabled in the Senate on 2 March 1995, recommended that the bill proceed without further amendment but advised that some aspects of the anti-siphoning provisions may require further attention in due course. I am grateful to Senator Alston for his indication that the opposition will support the government's amendments in that regard.

On resumption of the debate on 16 October Senator Tierney voiced several concerns which he had about the anti-siphoning legislation but indicated the coalition's support for the bill. The government welcomes that support.
Senator Bourne also spoke on the bill and said that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is a timely attempt to make the anti-syphoning laws in the Broadcasting Services Act more workable.
She obviously considered that the bill did not go far enough. Her amendment indicates that.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to update the situation mentioned by Senator Bourne about cricket. Events in the 1994 Australia-Pakistan test and one-day cricket series were removed from the list on 11 May 1955 via a notice published in the Gazette. The government considers it appropriate to take this opportunity to introduce further amendments to improve the effectiveness of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. As a result, these amendments will deal with further operational aspects of the anti-siphoning provisions affecting the acquisition of broadcasting rights by pay TV licensees; cooperation between satellite subscription television broadcasting licences A and B; the allocation of second commercial television and radio broadcasting licences in solus markets; and a 15 per cent deemed control rule for the purposes of control limits in the act. Again, in order to be courteous, I acknowledge Senator Alston's indicated support for three of those four points.

In order to expedite the passage of this bill through the Senate I will attempt to resist all temptation to respond to Senator Alston if he continues to run the conspiracy theory during the committee stage of this debate. I will try to be brief.
Details of these amendments are contained in the revised explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. They begin with provisions for additional services in poorly served communities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.
