The government considers it appropriate to take this opportunity to introduce further amendments to improve the effectiveness of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. The government's proposed amendments to the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill are designed to: streamline the allocation of second commercial television and radio broadcasting licences in solus markets; clarify the ownership and control provisions of the act by deeming a person to be in control of a company if that person holds company interests exceeding 15 per cent; further improve the operation of the anti-siphoning provisions dealing with the acquisition by pay television licensees of broadcasting rights to events listed under section 115 of the act; and ensure that satellite subscription television licensees A and B can cooperate in the way envisaged by section 116 without breaching the control provisions of the act.

PARA.TAB: The minister announced on 25 August the government's intention to amend section 39 to streamline the allocation by the ABA of new commercial radio licences in those communities currently receiving only one commercial service. I will not go into this in great detail because Senator Alston has indicated already that the opposition will be supporting these provisions.

The proposed amendment will remove the requirement for the ABA to first complete a licence area plan before allocating a second licence on application to an incumbent licensee in a solus market. This requirement has been a significant factor delaying the introduction of new services in under-served communities under section 39. Under the new provisions, the ABA need only examine frequency availability in the market. A deadline for section 39 applications will avoid delays to any subsequent allocations by the ABA of licences for independent services.

Opportunity has been taken to amend the eligibility requirements where two solus markets overlap. This will prevent a potentially inequitable outcome where there is a substantial population difference between the two markets. Proposed amendments to the solus television market provisions in section 73 were introduced earlier this year in the Communications and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1995.

The aim was to ensure that the ABA could allocate a licence for an incumbent broadcaster to operate a second commercial television service in the solus market in certain circumstances reflecting the solus radio provisions; impose a requirement that services continue to be operated for at least two years under the parent and second licence and cannot be separately transferred within this period; conduct a price based allocation process at any time during consideration of a section 73 application; and ensure there is no interest and capacity to operate an independent service, which is the key criterion for grant of a section 73 licence to an incumbent solus licensee.

The proposed amendments further simplify and clarify the operation of the solus television provisions. They have also been made consistent, where appropriate, with the solus radio provisions. It will be mandatory for the ABA to allocate a second licence to an incumbent in the solus market if the criterion set out in the act is met. The criterion for absence of interest and capacity to operate an independent service, I might add, has not been changed.

The current limit of one renewal of a second licence has been lifted. The risk otherwise is the loss of services to a community if at the end of the period no independent operator can be found. The ABA will be able to consider renewals for five-year periods indefinitely, subject to it being satisfied on each occasion that there is no interest and capacity to operate an independent service.

In relation to anti-siphoning, a mechanism is proposed to permit after an appropriate period the automatic removal of events from the anti-siphoning list when the event has concluded. A delay of seven days from the completion of the event is proposed, as this period would under normal circumstances give broadcasters a reasonable opportunity to provide coverage of an event at a time convenient to viewers.

The proposed amendments provide the minister with reserve power to declare that a completed event will remain on the anti-siphoning list if he considers that this is desirable. It is envisaged that this power would only be used in exceptional circumstances. For example, the minister may decide to retain an event on the anti-siphoning list where none of the broadcasting rights have been made available to a national broadcaster or a commercial television licensee prior to the event occurring, but the minister is of the opinion that retaining the event on the list is likely to have the effect that the rights will subsequently be offered in a way which will maximise the chances for free to air coverage.

The amendment to the licence conditions set at paragraph 10(1e) of part 6 of schedule 2 was designed to ensure that the anti-siphoning regime cannot be circumvented through the acquisition of rights to an event only by a small regional broadcaster, thereby limiting free to air coverage of an event, which is not the intention of the anti-siphoning provisions. The proposed amendments provide that subscription television broadcasting licensees will be prohibited from acquiring the rights to televise a listed event unless a national broadcaster or commercial television broadcasting licensees who together have licence area populations that exceed 50 per cent of the population of Australia have already acquired the right to broadcast the event.

The proposed amendments also include a minor technical amendment to ensure that the acquisition of radio rights alone by a national broadcaster will not trigger the provisions of clause 10, but will enable a subscription television broadcasting licensee to acquire television rights to a listed event. An amendment to section 116 of the Broadcasting Services Act is necessary to allow satellite subscription licensees A and B to enter into cooperative agreements for the shared use of facilities without breaching the control limitations in section 110 of the act.

The amendments put beyond doubt the ability of licensees A and B to enter into such agreements in relation to matters currently set down in section 116 of the act. Senator Alston knows from those previous prolonged debates that was always the intention. The proposed amendments also include a minor technical amendment to schedule 1 of the act to remove any doubt that the proposed provisions in the schedule dealing with concepts of control and tracing of company interests apply to subscription television broadcasting licences as well as to commercial television licences.

I have simply canvassed, for the benefit of the committee, the government's support for those amendments which Senator Alston has indicated his support for, at least at this stage. I will delay my remarks on the 15 per cent until the appropriate time in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the 15 per cent company interest control test. I do not see this as a get anyone specific amendment; I see it as a get anyone who is trying to get over the rules amendment. If someone has a lot of money—as many of the media proprietors do—and he is trying to get around the rules, as media proprietors constantly do, surely one has to expect that the ultimate regulator, the majority of the elected representatives in the parliament of this country, is going to try and stop him doing that. The rules have been put in place by this parliament and they say that 15 per cent should constitute control unless the proprietor can prove otherwise.

PARA.TAB: Fifteen per cent seems to me—and I think it would seem to most people—to be a reasonable limit. We have to provide a limit and it has to be plucked out of the air. This amendment will stop anyone else who is not over the 15 per cent now from going over the 15 per cent because that would impose control. It would be a limit of control. It gives a technical advantage to anyone who is currently over the 15 per cent because Senator Alston is not going to oppose the grandfathering clause. The grandfathering clause would be in there no matter what. Whoever is over the 15 per cent now has an advantage and will retain that advantage. Whoever is over 15 per cent now is not disadvantaged by this clause. I do not think that that is a particularly good thing.

I would like to see everybody taken back to 15 per cent but I accept that I am not going to get that. I accept that that is not going to happen because neither side is going to vote for that. So I am just going to leave that one alone. This is a matter about which I certainly said a great deal in television and radio press interviews. After all, having very clear guidelines is something that we definitely wanted, and those clear guidelines have to be put in legislation and stuck to. I thought that Senator Alston at the time said he wanted clear guidelines too.

We now have clear guidelines. These are clear guidelines. I am going to vote for clear guidelines. The only problem I have with this amendment is that it is in the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill and it is not where it was supposed to be in the communications omnibus bill as part of a package. I had expected the two issues of control—closing the 15 per cent, which we have here, plus widening the definition of `company interest' to include economic interest—to come up as a package. I was told they would come up as a package. Indeed, as everybody knows, they were originally in the communications omnibus bill. Now, one of them has been taken out and put here. I can understand the urgency for that but I think there is an urgency for the other one as well. I am certainly going to vote for this amendment. Once I see the other one and look at it, I am more than likely to vote for that as well.

If Senator Alston looks at it, he will see that the amendment does include foreign ownership as well as limits on control over commercial radio and television. What it does not include is widening the definition of `company interest' to include economic control and that is what I would like to see as well. I would like to see that here. I had no luck behind the scenes trying to get these two bills put up together. I was not supported by either the government or the opposition for quite reasonable reasons. I could see both of their points of view but I was not supported in that. I wish I had been, but we do not see it here.

My only problem with this amendment is that the other amendment I had expected to be with it is not with it. But I think the one we have here in front of us is a good amendment. It gives us clear guidelines, and that is what we needed. There was a real problem with those other guidelines in that they were not clear and media operators, who have a lot of money, were able to get over them. I mean any media operator; I am not talking about Mr Packer here. Just because he happened to do it in the first place does not mean that every single other media operator was not going to do it tomorrow. I am positive that behind the scenes there were a lot of lawyers working on how to get around this, and the only question was who would do it first. Somebody did it first, but it has now been

SPEECH.PARA: brought back. The person who did it first has an advantage out of this. I do not agree with that advantage, but it is going to stay there.

PARA.TAB: We will now have, I hope—I will see how everybody else votes—a clear limit of 15 per cent. It will be clear, and that is the point about this amendment. That is why I am voting for this amendment. I would have liked to have seen the other amendment up at the same time because I think it is a package. I would have liked to have seen the package together. But, given that we are expecting the communications bill to be debated in the next two weeks of these sittings, we will expect to see something then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I respond to some of the logic that has just been advanced in support of the government's amendments. As I heard Senator Bourne, she said that what we now have are clear guidelines. But they are not guidelines; they are arbitrary rules. The problem is that she also said that she had supported arrangements which said that 15 per cent was deemed to constitute control unless you could prove to the contrary, and that has been the law since 1991, I think.

PARA.TAB: The fact that you were able to exceed 15 per cent as long as you could demonstrate you were not in control has been a matter of public debate for at least 18 months. That is the precise point of the inquiry that the ABA conducted into Packer's control of Fairfax—to use shorthand. The problem is that at all times the government had made it quite clear that the whole purpose of the act was to ensure that you could not control two areas of the media—television and print in this instance—and control was the operative concept. As Michael Lee said:

SPEECH.PARA: Control is the key. Control is fundamental to promoting diversity and under the act control is the trip-wire. In some ways it does not matter whether someone is above or below 15 per cent.

That is what Michael Lee was saying back in February this year—that control was what it was all about. In order to determine whether someone was in control, if there was evidence demonstrating that it was below 15 per cent, you were presumed not to be in control. If you had over 15 per cent, you were presumed to be in control.

PARA.TAB: The ABA, as we discovered fascinatingly in estimates the other night, has actually been looking at this issue in relation to CanWest and Channel 10 for about four years. But they only took, from memory, seven weeks or five weeks in relation to the question of whether ConsPress was in control of Fairfax. They did precisely what the act required them to do; what everyone understood the act to mean; what media commentators had canvassed for 12 months or more in advance.

You cannot say you are getting around an act if you are simply using the clear terms of the act. We actually inserted a control test into the Broadcasting Services Act some years ago. We did that because we recognised the primacy of control, and we did it because we also accepted that arbitrary percentage figures do not prove anything. As I have said many times, if you were really fair dinkum about the proposition that you should not control, or have an interest in, more than one area of the media—and even Senator Bob Collins will recall that in relation to satellite subscription television licences there is a prohibition on crossholdings of more than two per cent between the A and B licensees—that effectively says, `You can't have shares in both. There might be some accidental crossholding. We are prepared to tolerate it at that level.' But if you were fair dinkum about not wanting people to be in both, then you would not allow crossholdings of any magnitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your position?

—If that is what it is all about. What I have said consistently is that there is a hell of a lot happening around the world in terms of new technologies. These cross-media rules are a dog's breakfast because they do not apply, not only to telecommunications but also to magazines or to pay television. There is so much happening that you need the review that you have talked about for so long. What we have said consistently is that you do not pre-empt the review by coming up with arbitrary bandaid propositions that are unrelated to control, and I gave the example of Prime Television. Once Prime got over 15 per cent, under these new rules it is deemed to be in control—automatically; no argument.

PARA.TAB: What does `control' mean? `Control' means you call the shots, but they cannot because Channel 7 has more than 50 per cent. So, by any test, they have the numbers on the board, and they are in absolute and total control for those purposes. So how can you have two players who have conflicting commercial interests both in control of the one organisation? It is a nonsense; it is a non sequitur. It simply undermines the whole concept that is supposed to be what the cross-media rules are all about.

I simply say that this is not a question of redressing some sort of hitherto unrecognised loophole. This is a matter of rules that have been in place for some years that have been applied. We very much supported the ABA; in fact, I have been critical of the ABA and its processes for not having speedy hearings, for not having public hearings, for not always requiring evidence to be taken on oath, and for simply accepting letters from solicitors saying, `My client denies the allegations,' and then leaving it at that. They seem to have gone further, from what I learnt the other night, in relation to Channel 10. But the fact remains that if you are going to take three or four years to complete an inquiry, or to have a role in monitoring an inquiry, again I do not think you are acting in the public interest.

What you need is what happened in this instance. They had a quick inquiry in five or seven weeks. They made a judgment as to whether control was constituted by 17.2 per cent, and they decided it was not. The minute that decision was announced, the minute the rules worked the way they were meant to work, all of the government's rhetoric went out the window. What Michael Lee had said about control being the key, control being fundamental, the cross-media ownership rules working well and their being quite happy to leave it to the ABA—all that went out the window. That is not coincidental. It is purely and simply because the government thought the ABA would do the hatchet job. When they did not, the government stepped in and did it for them.

So let there be no misunderstanding. We are very much in support of a comprehensive overhaul of the cross-media rules. The government has promised it for months, indeed years, and has not done it. The sooner we get on with looking at all the different concepts that are applying elsewhere the better. It is not an easy issue. No-one pretends there are magical solutions, but to think that somehow you can pluck a percentage figure out of the air and end up with this nonsense where two diametrically opposed interests are both deemed to be in control is absolutely ludicrous. An arbitrary 15 per cent will not solve anything; it is not a clear guideline, it is an arbitrary and unworkable rule. It totally pre-empts the review.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing arbitrary, as Senator Alston knows, about the 15 per cent. A lot of consideration was given to setting that threshold. For these reasons a limit below 15 per cent was not considered practical or realistic.

However, the government also considered that limits over 15 per cent would actually constitute a relaxation of the current rules when all the evidence that is around, and there is a lot of it, indicates that in fact those rules need to be tighter. A 15 per cent limit was chosen because it is an existing ownership threshold in the act, and the removal of the discretion for persons to prove they do not control a company at levels in excess of 15 per cent toughens the effect of this threshold, and that is what we are unblushingly doing. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to lead for the opposition in the Senate on the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995. We are opposed to this bill and will be dividing on the bill. Our opposition to the bill is strong and unequivocal. This legislation has been put up to set up yet another rort for the Maritime Union of Australia—the great friends of the ALP mates, especially the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton.

PARA.TAB: The principal effect of the legislation is to provide $19 million to the members of the Maritime Union of Australia. This bill is dipping into the pockets of Australian taxpayers and taking out $19 million. The taxpayers are having this money ripped from their pockets because the Keating government wants to solve a domestic union disagreement with the union. We should focus on the shonky reasons that gave rise to this bill.

This deal was struck to try to resolve an industrial dispute. It revolved around the privatisation of ANL. We recall the strike last year by the MUA when the government said it would sell its share in Australian Stevedores, which is owned by ANL. The strike cost $60 million and many more millions in indirect costs and enhanced Australia's reputation for unreliability on the waterfront. Coming out of this dispute is this tax funded deal for the ALP's mates at the MUA. Close study of the bill reveals this $19 million tax funded subsidy to the Maritime Union.

The explanatory memorandum says that this is all about placing Australian shipping operators on a more equal footing with their overseas competitors in relation to crew costs. This is said to provide incentives for Australian shipping to develop new international trading opportunities. We need to improve as Australian flag ships carry only four per cent of Australia's foreign trade. This minister's rationale for the legislation is dishonest nonsense. The explanatory memorandum misrepresents the purpose of the bill.

The effect of the bill is to provide an incentive or a sop in the form of a taxable grant payable to the employers of Australian seafarers on Australian operated ships engaged in international trade. The amount of the grant will be equal to the notional tax payable on the earnings of the crews serving on that ship. To qualify, the ship must be Australian operated, its crew must be employed by an Australian employer and the ship must spend no less than half its operational time in a year on international voyages.

This grant solution proposed in this bill was not Minister Brereton's original plan. Mr Brereton advocated a proposal that the government would not levy PAYE tax on these crews. Minister Brereton backed away from this advice when the Australian Tax Office wisely said that it would create a very dangerous precedent for other industry employee groups. This measure that we are now considering provides a grant in the form of a recognisable subsidy to the Australian shipping industry. The Australian Shipowners Association supports this for obvious reasons. Why would it look a gift-horse in the mouth?

The coalition has told that association that we do not support it. Without other wide ranging reforms envisaged in the Taylor recommendations, including the opening up foreign crewing and the removal of cabotage protection, this bill is an expensive farce to cover up the government's incompetence in managing the sale of the ANL. Again, the raw power of the AMU is clear as the union continues to veto the sale of the ANL to P&O.

The cost to taxpayers and Australia's competitiveness of this sweetheart deal and other measures to the AMU is enormous. Some $19 million will blow out as Australian operators put up more ships to qualify for this grant. The government says it will be one additional ship per year, but that is an underestimate. The extra cost of one ship would be $400,000 per year. On this basis, the net impact of this grant over five years will be a total of $59 million. This will be much more if more ships qualify for the grant.

What about other costs where this Keating government has bowed to the desires of the AMU? You can add up the account for the Australian taxpayers: $19 million for this measure, $145 million for the fiasco at ANL and nearly $1 million for the services of the mates of Brereton, Wran and Turnbull for their part-time consultancy of two days a week—and that is not a bad little earner for anyone, is it? On the waterfront itself we have $450 million paid to the 4,000 retiring wharfies over and above their superannuation benefits under the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority program—all this largesse for the mates.

It is a great pity that Minister Collins has just walked out of the chamber because he was the main one responsible for setting up that last sweetheart deal I mentioned. Now we have yet another one, all of this at a time when we are supposed to be improving efficiency on the waterfront, improving efficiency with our shipping, and we find that the government is paying off its mates yet again.

The coalition strongly opposes this legislation. Australia has had enough of this featherbedding of government interest groups. What about the farmers? Compare the treatment that the government is handing out to its mates with how it has treated the farmers over the last four years. On this basis, we oppose this bill.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to highlight the absolute crisis which this government has allowed to occur in our vital tuna fishing relationship with Japan. For some time Australia and Japan have enjoyed a mutually beneficial relationship on the tuna industry. It is a relationship which returns to Australia $100 million and a considerable amount more in the provision of invaluable scientific data.

PARA.TAB: In fact, in my own state of Tasmania at the techno-park at Glenorchy, one of the firms has manufactured devices which are implanted into the tuna to allow scientists from Japan and Australia to actually study their migratory patterns and, hopefully, understand their breeding and growth habits for the good of the industry. It is a very cosy relationship, or it has been, between the Japanese and the Australian government as far as the scientific side of it goes. But this relationship is in tatters because of a boycott of Australian ports by the Japanese over catch quotas.

Whilst the federal government continues to allow this matter to go unresolved, Japanese vessels will be visiting Bali, Singapore and South Africa for their port calls. Australia, Japan and New Zealand are joint signatories to the Commission for the Conservation of the Southern Bluefin Tuna. The commission is responsible for setting a worldwide limit on what these three countries can catch. At present, Australia's allocation is 5,265 tonnes, Japan's allocation is 6,065 tonnes and New Zealand's quota is 420 tonnes. The Japanese scientists argue that the parental biomass of tuna has recovered to the point where it can sustain an increase in the Japanese quota of between 1,000 and 6,000 tonnes.

It is important to recognise that almost all the southern bluefin tuna caught throughout the world finds its way to Japan, where the Japanese are prepared to pay premium prices for what they regard as a precious product. It is not unheard of to see some of this tuna selling for thousands of dollars in the Japan fish market. Australian scientists are perhaps understandably cautious as to the potential of the biomass to recover and, to date, are not prepared to endorse the claims that have been made by the Japanese scientists.

The situation is that the existing quotas are to expire in January 1996. With little evidence of a genuine effort by the Australian government to resolve the issue, the Japanese have taken the step of withdrawing their tuna boats from two Australian ports which act as bases—namely, Fremantle and Hobart.

I want to make the point very clearly that, in raising this matter in the Senate today, I am not taking sides and offering support for the views of the Japanese scientists any more than I am expressing the views of our own scientists. I am saying that this whole matter should not have been allowed to deteriorate to this position. As my colleague Senator Denman from Tasmania would know, the visits by Japanese tuna vessels to the ports of Hobart and Fremantle are an essential component of the financial lifeblood of those ports. Under those circumstances, the federal Minister for Resources, David Beddall, should have intervened before now to resolve this matter.

Ministers in this government are supposed to lead. They are not supposed to sit back and watch a crisis unfold before they become involved. Unfortunately, we have seen that far too often lately. For instance, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, sat back and watched ANL get to the situation where it is virtually unsaleable. He sat back and watched this crisis developing in the industrial relations area where my state and other states will be held to ransom by rolling strikes. In this particular case the Minister for Resources, David Beddall, has sat back and watched this happen and we are at a situation where the President of Tuna Boat Owners of Australia, Mr Brian Jeffries, said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: It—
the boycott—
is a major blow for the ports—there's no question about that.

Nowhere is the effect of the boycott and this government's ineptitude being felt more severely than in my own state of Tasmania, particularly in the port of Hobart. It is estimated that between now and the end of January that boycott will cost the Tasmanian economy more than $6 million. For the small port of Hobart, that is quite a significant amount of money, seeing that we have just lost a contractor ship out of Hobart from ANM. That has gone to Senator Denman's home port of Burnie. Nevertheless, the Japanese fishing boats coming into Hobart are very significant. Had the federal government not allowed this boycott to occur, around 45 Japanese tuna boats would have visited the port of Hobart over the coming months. When you consider that each vessel can spend up to $150,000 on fuel, fresh food, fruit and vegetables and other provisions and services, you get to picture the full impact which this boycott is having.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the Hobart Marine Board has estimated that the loss of the Japanese tuna boats will cost the board at least $50,000, mainly in pilot fees, by the end of January. I have been reliably informed that the future viability of up to three businesses operating in the port of Hobart have been threatened by the boycott. Sources within that industry have predicted that unless this matter is resolved immediately 15 very precious jobs will be lost.

Through all of this, the voice of the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has remained silent. As is usual, he has been unseen and unheard while a vital Tasmanian opportunity, not half a kilometre from his office, faces devastation. Like all his Labor colleagues in Tasmania, Mr Kerr has once again demonstrated that he is not prepared to fight for local issues on behalf of his constituents if it means upsetting his political masters in Canberra. At the end of the day, if it takes my pushing to get Mr Kerr to react, then so be it.

I believe it is important to place on the record that here we have a lucrative opportunity for Tasmania ready to disappear down the drain, yet we cannot see one Labor member or senator who is prepared to do anything about it. The federal Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, must intervene to resolve the impasse which currently exists and he must do so immediately. Every day this government fails to respond costs the Tasmanian economy hundreds of thousands of dollars. The Japanese boycott of our ports is further evidence that this is a tired government unable to offer answers to problems of any substance.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Do you accept that, to quote Commissioner Marks, `there is more than one aspect to untruthfulness by elected public figures', that `it damages not only the trust of the people in their representatives, but also their trust in the representative system'? Why should the Prime Minister allow Australians' trust in the representative system to be further eroded by keeping Dr Lawrence as a member of his Cabinet? Does he not as Prime Minister have a duty to protect and enhance Australian's trust in our system of government rather than letting that trust be eroded even further than it already has?

—One thing the Prime Minister will not allow himself to do is to have his judgment dictated to by a partisan Western Australian Premier. He would not take any notice of a political exercise run by Mr Court.
—That is just offensive to the royal commission.
—Senator Hill says that is offensive—
—You are saying the royal commission is run by Mr Court.

—A wholly owned subsidiary of Mr Court, from start to finish. Therefore, in terms of Mr Marks's definition and many definitions of what is truthful and untruthful that is as competent a one as I have seen, but there are many others. It is who draws the judgment and on what basis they draw the judgment that the Prime Minister will make any decision.

—I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you asserting in your answer that Commissioner Marks failed to bring to his task any degree of credibility, that he failed to bring the expertise from his years as a judicial officer and that he acted improperly? Is that the allegation you are prepared to make—that Commissioner Marks acted improperly, that he did what he was told by the Western Australian Premier?

—Mr President, I said yesterday that Commissioner Marks had a very limited purview of a total subject. That is in the terms of reference. He was given a limited terms of reference. I also said that I and many others in the government were not satisfied as to the running of that commission in terms of the ordering of witnesses and the treatment of Dr Lawrence.

—I take a point of order. The question was not what Senator Ray said yesterday. It was directed to his comment that Mr Marks was a wholly owned subsidiary of the Premier. That is clearly the most direct attack on Mr Marks's integrity. The question is: do you argue that Mr Marks did not act objectively, that he was simply doing the bidding of his political master? If you say that, let us have it on the record. Let us say it here and outside.
—There is no point of order. I am not in a position to direct the minister how to answer the question.
—There is clearly no point of order at all.
—Thank you very much. He gives you a hand as well, Mr President.
—That is right. All it was was an intervention in this debate to make his argumentative points. It had nothing to do with the standing orders.

—We will do it without your constant interruption as well, Senator Hill. As I was saying, Senator Vanstone, it is the contention not only of myself but of many others in this government that the royal commission was set up on restricted terms of reference, unfair terms of reference, No. 1—
—But you said he was a wholly owned subsidiary.
—What I have said is that he had restricted terms of reference. The way the commission has operated—(Time expired)

—Mr President, I take a point of order. My point of order is a new one. It is against standing orders, as I understand it, for any one of us in the Senate to reflect upon a judicial officer or a commissioner conducting a royal commission. On that ground I ask that Senator Ray withdraw the offensive remark that he was a wholly owned subsidiary of the Western Australian Premier.

—On the point of order: Mr Marks is no longer a judge. He runs a mediation service in Melbourne. In fact, he no longer holds a judicial office. I just make that point to you, Senator Teague, in case you do not know.
—Even in his role as commissioner he was not covered by that standing order.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of Australia's reputation as a world leader in climate research and of the federal government's provision of funds for further research in this area. Can the minister advise the Senate of any progress in climate research effort, particularly as it relates to drought, both in Australia and overseas?

—Australia is at the forefront of climate research, particularly in the effect and predictability of meteorological phenomena such as the El Nino southern oscillation index, which of course affects a great deal of the world apart from Australia. This morning I opened the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation's conference on managing with climate variability.

PARA.TAB: This government has allocated around $7 million for climate variability research since 1992. One of the purposes of this conference that is being held at the moment is that it is the halfway point in that major research project on the prediction of climate for a greater tool for management of farming and the protection of the environment. That was funded with a $2.1 million research grant from this government. In the drought package that was developed by the government, a further $5.1 million was provided to extend that research.

No-one needs to be reminded of the regular and often devastating impact that drought has on our farmers, their families and their communities—and I might add the significant impact on the environment. What we can do about it and what we have been doing is to recognise that we have a highly variable climate in Australia—one of the most variable in the world—and to develop better ways of coping with it. This is also the reason behind our strong support of and commitment to the establishment of an international centre for climate prediction. This proposal has been put forward, and a recent meeting was held in the United States to establish such a centre. It was heartening to know that there is international recognition for Australia's expertise in this regard. Our delegates to that conference made it clear that Australia will support the establishment of such an international centre of climate predictability. A working party has been established to set it up, and Australia will continue to support it strongly, including the necessary financial support if it should eventuate.

As a leader in climate research, Australia will be able to make a significant contribution to international cooperation in this area. We are not only pioneering the development of new scientific techniques; we are well ahead of the rest in providing this information to farmers to help them plan their farming strategy. That advice is very important to profitable, sustainable farming.

It is a fact, as indicated by the research documents that have already been produced, that across the board in Australia you get three decent years out of every 10 on average. In those 10 years you get three or four reasonable years and two or three very difficult years indeed. Meteorologists, in conjunction with the CSIRO and primary industry departments across Australia, are developing systems that will give farmers better information to predict the odds on these climatic events.

Just recently, a number of farms in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales were adversely affected by frost. It greatly interested me that, with the groundbreaking work being done at centres such as those in Toowoomba, with a combined CSIRO and Queensland DPI operation, growers in that region were given warning that that frost was coming based on the SOI information. In fact, that prediction proved to be accurate. I understand that a number of growers in that region took that advice and delayed plantings. As a result, they escaped most of the damage from that particular event. That is just an indication of how this is now being used to directly help growers.

The Australian government will continue to provide the substantial support for climate research in Australia. In addition to the substantial sums of money that I have just mentioned, this government is also providing in excess of $16 million for research into the greenhouse effect.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. The government wants to pay $620,000 towards Carmen Lawrence's legal costs. Yet even the most expert, expensive lawyers in the land could not get her off from lying. Doesn't this show that the Australian people can have confidence that the institutional system of law is a fair one because neither money nor political influence can hide the fact of guilt?

—One would certainly hope so. One would hope that all the legal processes in this country are fair and come to a proper judgment. One would hope that every time a case is taken, either by way of court or by way of inquiry, they will be approached in an objective manner. The best way of ensuring that is to divorce the political process from the judicial process.
—Which government has not set up a royal commission?

—Senator Hill intervenes again. When one goes back through the history of the nature of royal commissions, one finds that the one Senator Boswell refers to is a unique one because it was set up to look into cabinet deliberations; set up in the middle of an internal fracas in the Liberal Party in Western Australia; set up as a diversion by Premier Court to cover up his own internal problems; and set up with restricted terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: All those things occurred, Senator Boswell; things you never acknowledged.While the principles you have enunciated should always apply, I do not believe they applied in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that Carmen Lawrence lied to the Australian people?
—That is a judgment—
—Just answer yes or no.
—You ask for a yes or no answer. I will rephrase your question. Do I trust Carmen Lawrence's veracity? The answer is yes.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—I said—I put on the record then—I believe in her veracity. That is what I have said. So there is no need to try to recast that. I have answered the question. I believe in her veracity.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. Can the minister advise the Senate about an announcement earlier this week by the Treasurer of a $400 million investment by BHP in a blast furnace at Port Kembla? How did the Commonwealth encourage this investment? Is this indicative of a generally positive outlook on investment?

—This is some economic news, and very good economic news. The Development Allowance Authority approved an allowance for BHP's support of Port Kembla steel works. This week the Treasurer announced it. BHP is investing $400 million in a blast furnace at Port Kembla. Up to 3,000 people will be employed on this at peak construction time; 900 people are employed currently. It is the first blast furnace made in Australia for 23 years; the last one was in 1972. It will be operational in March next year. It will replace two smaller blast furnaces with state of the art technology.

PARA.TAB: The development allowance was first enunciated by the government in the One Nation initiative. It is a stimulus to national investment. It provides a tax deduction of 10 per cent of the capital expenditure incurred in the acquisition or lease of new plant and equipment for projects with a capital expenditure of $50 million or more. So far 270 projects worth $75 billion—that is, $75 billion in new investment—have been registered for the allowance.

I mention in association with this that the Access Economics quarterly economic investment monitor reports that there is $123 billion worth of investment either actual, under construction, in planning or projected for Australia at the present time. That is a huge boost in capital investment and major projects for this country. The competitive test, under which the allowance authority provided this write-off for BHP, requires applicants to demonstrate that their industrial relations practice is at the world best practice level and that the cost of inputs is both economic and efficient.

So we have an allowance that levers major national investment, creates a basis for Australian industry to grow and to expand, and also creates a climate in which there can be cooperation developed in the workplace between the work force and the companies concerned so that that investment is able to be worked at the most productive level. World's best practice in industrial relations is part of this. It is in contrast perhaps to what has happened in other parts of this industry elsewhere in Australia.

The steel industry, for which this investment is destined, is one of the core industries in the national economy. Nearly over a decade ago, just before we came to power, BHP were openly talking about closing down their steel industry. During the period of the Fraser government it had become inefficient. When we came to power, we created the Button steel plan, which was based on tripartite consultations between the unions, governments and the companies. As a result, in the last 10 years, productivity in steel has trebled. In 1983-84 production was at 175 tonnes per person; last year it was 618 tonnes per person. In 1984, we exported less than one million tonnes; last year we exported 317 million tonnes. These are indications of progress in the industry.

During the last 10 years, BHP has invested over $6 billion in the domestic steel industry. All this comes from the basis we created with the Button steel plan, which enabled this core sector of the Australian economy to rebound from being on the ropes and going out backwards to being one of the most competitive and profitable industries in Australia. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Robert Ray, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, Royal Commissioner Marks found that Carmen Lawrence lied. Do you accept that the royal commissioner was an objective adjudicator of the facts?

—Based on the terms of reference and based on the ordering of the witnesses, Mr Marks is entitled to his opinion and other people are entitled to theirs. I have not gone through the whole transcript of evidence, so I cannot make a personal judgment and arbitrate myself.
—That hasn't stopped you over the last few days, sport!

—I have gone to the methodology of the commission, Senator Vanstone. You have never gone to that. It is irrelevant to you what the methodology and the intent of the royal commission were and what the perverted political process that led to it was. As far as you are concerned, you have amnesia when it comes to those particular issues. You do not make any objective comments on those, because you don't want to. The question Senator Hill has asked me—
—Get on with the answer, sport!

—Oh, thank you for permission, Senator Vanstone! How gracious of you to give me permission to answer Senator Hill's question! Senator Hill asked whether I have confidence in Mr Marks's objectivity. I believe he was set a very difficult task with restricted terms of reference in a political process. The one part of the transcript I have read is some of the angst he expressed at the task he was given.

PARA.TAB: It was his job to make his own judgments as to the evidence. It is also our job in government to make our judgments. There was conflicting evidence from a variety of witnesses. I am not in a position to say what weight I give to one specific lot of witnesses as opposed to another. If you wanted to have a proper inquiry, Senator Hill, it wouldn't have been one initiated in the method that Richard Court used to appoint that royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from what you have said that you accept the objectivity of the royal commissioner. If I am wrong, no doubt you will correct that. In acknowledging that you did not have the witnesses appear before you, don't you recognise that the most appropriate person to make the findings is the objective commissioner who heard the evidence? Shouldn't that assessment, therefore, take precedence over your politically convenient judgment? Will you not accept, inviting you to be objective for one minute, that the overwhelming evidence supported the finding that he made?

—I repeat what I have said here many times before: this royal commission was conceived in political malice; it was set up with restricted terms of reference; and it was set up primarily to divert public attention away from an internal and abrasive Liberal Party brawl over preselections and other matters. From any inquiry set up in those circumstances one is entitled to be dubious about any conclusions it draws.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the cabinet decision to fund Dr Lawrence's costs. I ask the minister, first, was it a carte blanche whatever it takes decision? Second, what did the government do to retain control of the costs by way of authorising or even monitoring decisions which would affect the level of expenditure of the public funds it was committing? Third, and in particular, did the government authorise the appointment of interstate lawyers and the ensuing travel and accommodation costs? Fourth, what did the government do to place upper limits on the rates charged by counsel and other personnel, and on administrative costs?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Spindler's question is no. On the second, the government has always said that before any bills are paid all costs will be properly certified by the Solicitor-General in accordance with normal commercial practice. With regard to parts three and four of Senator Spindler's question, the personal and administrative costs will be scrutinised by the Solicitor-General in determining what are reasonable costs. The answer to question five, which you did not ask—should the Western Australian government have made proper arrangements for the funding of legal representation when it set up this commission—is that they did not. If anyone wants to look at the miserable, stingy attitude of the Western Australian government, they should know that when Dr Lawrence asked for a copy of the report she was asked to go and buy one at the government bookshop.

—In view of the minister's answer, can we infer that the minister and the government are happy about the charge of $500 per hour and up to $5,000 a day for Mr Gyles QC, with a total of approximately $300,000?

—Not one person in this chamber probably would express happiness at the amount QCs are paid. It is not really for me to express angst on legal charges other than to know that there were no excessive payments made and that it followed normal commercial practice. That is the critical thing. I do not think anyone is particularly happy with the extent to which legal representation and costs are incurred in this country. I understand that a Senate committee has been looking at that for some years.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Senator Schacht. I understand that decisions were made last week regarding the 1996 funding of vocational education and training. Can the minister inform the Senate as to the amount of Commonwealth funding for 1996 and whether there were any difficulties in settling these arrangements with the state and territory governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Childs for his important question. This is an area where last week the government made a major announcement at the National Training Authority's ministerial council meeting. It decided that next year $875 million of Commonwealth funds will be allocated to vocational education and training in Australia. That is an increase of $90 million from this year and it will generate 40,000 additional student places for vocational training in Australia. It brings the increase in Commonwealth spending on vocational education and training since 1992 to 80 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth now contributes 35 per cent of public funds to vocational education and training compared with 17 per cent in 1992. As Senator Childs has asked, I can indicate that in his own state of New South Wales the Carr Labor government will increase its real recurrent expenditure on vocational education and training in 1996 by $8 million. Commonwealth growth funds in 1996 will build on this by generating nearly 12,500 additional student places in New South Wales, bringing the total number to 383,000, which is a big improvement on the situation under the previous state Liberal government.

Unfortunately, I must inform the Senate that a number of coalition state governments were identified by the National Training Authority as not maintaining their expenditure on vocational education and training. The authority reported that in 1996 Victoria plans to cut real recurrent spending on vocational education and training by two per cent or nearly $9 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—A cut of $9 million by the Kennett government in Victoria. Apparently that government is spending the money on sporting events instead. My own state of South Australia, unfortunately, plans to cut $10 million, or seven per cent, and Western Australia plans a cut of $500,000. The Commonwealth has had to use its increased leverage in funding of vocational education and training to, unfortunately, coerce these uncooperative coalition state governments to meet their responsibilities under the ANTA agreement. For example, in my own state of South Australia the ANTA ministerial council determined that payment of Commonwealth growth funds to South Australia were subject to:

ANSWER.PARA: South Australia's commitment to maintain the provision of the levels and quality of vocational education and training with progress on that provision reported to ANTA by 31 March and 30 June 1996

The government will be considering these reports closely. My message to the premier of my own state, Dean Brown, and to Dr Such, his minister, is that the Australian government will do all that is necessary to ensure that it and other coalition state governments keep their side of the ANTA bargain.

PARA.TAB: I must point out that, only recently in my own state, Premier Brown was making great play of the fact that there would be increased expenditure to get more qualified computer scientists and computer technicians in South Australia to meet his demand for an information technology future. Yet the area where these people would be trained in ANTA is planned to be cut by his own government by $10 million. It is a disgraceful proposal by that government and by the other coalition governments. I can assure the Australian people that we will meet our commitments and, above all else, will make sure these measly state coalition governments do not get away with their penny-pinching against vocational training.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. You stated in the Land newspaper on 17 August that the Wheat Board's special status as Australia's only wheat exporter would remain `while ever the industry continues to demonstrate that the AWB is a positive for Australian wheat growers'. —I am delighted to get this question from a National Party senator.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell interjecting—

—I am directing these remarks to Senator Boswell. You stay in the playground where you belong, Senator Campbell.

PARA.TAB: It is not in conflict at all. This matter, and it is an important issue, is well advanced. What I said to the Land is absolutely correct. I will send you a copy of the speech that I delivered in April to a major grains conference in Queensland, with a roomful of grains participants, in which I made a specific reference to the fact that all of this industry—not just the Wheat Board but everything, including state marketing authorities—had to have arrangements at the end of the day that were consistent with the agreements that have been struck by heads of government, irrespective of their political affiliations: that is heads of government across Australia, both Labor and conservative. I might also refer you, Senator Brownhill, to something that your shadow minister for primary production is clearly not aware of in terms of the endlessly silly statements that he puts out on this issue. Have a look at the material that went out to growers prior to the 22 meetings that have just been held. But have a look at the wishy-washy, wimpy, two bob each way rubbish that the coalition is running on this subject, and this is just the latest that has been put in front of me. This is what your shadow minister, John Anderson, said on this issue when he was first interviewed by a journalist about this matter—I was highly amused when I had to be interviewed in response. He said that the coalition would guarantee the retention of the single desk for 10 years with no strings attached. Within 30 minutes of making that statement, your shadow minister contacted the journalist and downgraded that to seven years but then, 24 hours later, it was five years. In the latest statement that he has made it is qualified with the statement that, of course, it would have to be consistent with the position taken by other shadow ministers in other portfolios after he has a yak with them after the election. This is the latest coalition position. You have a hide to even ask this question, Senator. What John Anderson has said is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I asked him about the Wheat Board. I did not ask him about John Anderson; I asked him about the Wheat Board.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I will conclude by saying this: John Anderson's latest statement is that—talk about two bob each way—yes, he fully supports the Hilmer competition policy, but it has to be applied with commonsense. Well, well, well. My statements on this publicly, as the grain industry knows, are completely consistent.

PARA.TAB: I had another meeting with the President of the Australian Grains Council on this issue only yesterday. I will have many more. From day one everyone has been advised by this government that this has to be consistent with the agreements reached by all heads of government, irrespective of their political affiliations. The only problem you lot have got, Senator—and I know—is that you are having a huge internal brawl with the Liberal Party over this very issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —If, as you claim, the industry was aware of the Hilmer implications from day one, why was it only last week that you hastily requested a meeting of industry representatives in Sydney so that they could be told by your department officials that single desk selling might contravene Hilmer? When were you first aware of that advice?

—That is a piece of absolute nonsense, Senator. There have not been any hasty meetings convened by anybody. There have, in fact, been hundreds of meetings on this issue. They are continuing. Can I say, Senator Boswell, good luck at knocking off Tim Fischer. If you ever did get into government, having him as a trade minister for Australia would be a profound embarrassment for this entire country. Good luck, Ron.

—My question is to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Minister, can you advise the Senate about a new scheme to provide temporary child care for parents undertaking training or labour market programs?

—Yes, I thank the senator for the question. This is a very exciting announcement that has come through today, and it has been in response to the identification of the lack of affordable and accessible child care to some of the labour market participation programs.

PARA.TAB: Today, Minister Crean has announced a significant new initiative to assist labour market participants to find affordable child care. It is based on the very successful jobs, education and training program—that program which made sure that people, particularly single parents, who were looking to get back into employment through a training program should be assisted with child care if they were unable to find their own child-care places. It has been a very successful program to the point where it is now being used as a model well outside of the needs for just single mothers. The program will assist people participating in the labour market programs to find child care and, in areas of short supply, will provide additional child-care places for fixed periods.

The CES offices providing information on child care will include location of the services to families. As well, when a family is unable to find care, the Department of Human Services and Health will assist by finding an arrangement of temporary add-on of places to an existing centre or by seeking to find a permanent place. This is very much the pattern that is currently the case for jobs, education and training. As I say, it is now being extended to other people participating in labour market programs.

It is a very important initiative for parents who have the responsibility of caring for children and who are actually wanting to participate in labour market programs. We have found on the evidence that it is child care that is the biggest obstruction to many of them being able to get that extra participation. So today the announcement is very successful news of a very considerable extension to that program, to provide the flexibility that those people need. It is a very ringing endorsement of the JET program. It is also a very considerable ringing endorsement of Working Nation and our labour market programs. We know in this place that child care is the absolute critical factor in those people being able to participate.

The other thing is that, whether you are training for a job or participating in the work force, when you get into child care, what you want to be sure of is that those places are actually quality child care. I take the opportunity to remind the opposition that their farcical campaign against quality child care is only going to come back to haunt them should they ever get into government.

Yesterday we had Senator Troeth raising the very interesting spectre of why. I would like to ask the opposition why it is that, when 3,600 child-care centres are participating, it is going in to bat for the 10 centres holding out?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: Senator Crowley has apparently asked me a question and I seek leave to answer the question.
—I will ignore that.

—I think we all should, but I have to say that that is a measure of the desperation of the opposition when it comes to child care. You want to barrack for the support of 10 centres that are holding out against 3,600 that are participating in the process. You want to support that tiny, small part that is not committed to participating in the quality program. You do not seriously want to say to parents about assurances for quality, `Well, through our labour market programs—with this great commitment to expansion of child-care places, with our JET program, with our parents participating through occasional care—wherever there is child care this government is committed to quality.' You continue to be opposed to it.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is there a program to reseal the hard stand area at Canberra airport? If there is, which companies have been invited to tender, from the ACT or from outside the ACT? What substance is to be used for the resealing joints? Is it Australian-made or imported? When will the work commence and when will it be completed?

—I have not got the slightest idea. I have not got a clue who is sealing the tarmac at Canberra airport or who the contractors are or what the bitumen mix is, but I understand your electorate interest in this matter and I will refer the matter to the Minister for Transport and get you an answer.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health and relates to the combined World Health Organisation and UNICEF program to promote breastfeeding before new mums leave hospital. This program has over 2,000 hospitals worldwide now involved but only two of those are in Australia. I ask: why has the issue of free and low-cost supplies of infant formula not been resolved here in keeping with the World Health Assembly resolution, considering the significant decrease in the incidence of disease in both mums and their babies if infants are breastfed? Secondly, why has the Australian government not fully endorsed and financially supported the baby friendly hospital initiative in this country? Finally, why do we not have a sector specific agreement on the promotion of bottles and teats in Australia as required by the WHO code and promised by this government at the signing of the Australian agreement in May 1992?

—The Commonwealth government certainly does support and encourage breastfeeding. The point you make is very well taken. There is a much lower incidence of childhood diseases if babies are breastfed. That government commitment is promulgated in both the dietary guidelines for Australians and the dietary guidelines for children and adolescents. It is certainly the government's commitment to see the expansion of the baby friendly hospital initiative in this country.

PARA.TAB: In August this year, it was announced that the Australian College of Midwives was to be the coordinating body for the carriage of the WHO-UNICEF baby friendly hospital initiative in Australia. This decision was reached following the decision by UNICEF to review its direct involvement in developed countries and to restrict its involvement in Australia to the tune of some $10,000. So there has been a bit of a gap in the process towards accreditation of baby friendly hospitals. Despite the fact that there are only two accredited in Australia, many more are in the process of meeting the criteria in their objective to become accredited.

The cessation of free and low-cost supplies of infant formula was placed on the agenda at the Australian health ministers conference in June 1995. After lengthy discussions what was agreed was that an appropriate strategy would be for all state and territory governments to encourage the individual state and territories to address this in their respective jurisdictions.

There is some concern under the Australian Trade Practices Act that there could be collusion aspects whereby agreements with individual manufacturers to enter a separate agreement with government might be contravening the legislation. Despite the legislation constraints, some manufacturers have individually ceased the supply of free and low-cost infant formula to hospitals and community health centres. I think that is a matter we should acknowledge and appreciate. It is also an area of some difficulty but while manufacturers are proceeding that way, that is the way the government would prefer to see us go.

As to your question about sector agreement on the promotion of bottles and teats in Australia, the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs is currently negotiating with the Baby Products Association on the development of an agreement based on the WHO code. In 1989, the WHO and UNICEF published a joint statement entitled `Protecting, promoting and supporting breast feeding and the special role of maternity services'. That set global standards for maternal services.

The then Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services wrote to the states and territories urging the adoption of the 10 steps to successful breastfeeding. The initiative is aimed at strengthening breast feeding and ensuring that maternity units not only know about it but also inform, promote and show support for that kind of campaign.

In relation to the specific agreement on the promotion of bottles and teats, the Baby Products Association circulated a draft for comment to the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs but there was some concern or dissatisfaction with that. Indeed the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs has developed a draft agreement. It went back to the Baby Products Association for comment mid this year. I understand that negotiation between the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs and the Baby Products Association is continuing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer but encouragement is just not working. In at least two states the impact of case-mix funding is such that mums are being pushed out of hospital earlier and earlier with no support, or very little support, and the rate of breastfeeding in this country is actually dropping. We do not even have any decent statistics now in place in most states. They just don't want to know. They don't even want to monitor what is happening. Therefore, surely it is up to the federal government to make sure—in other words, to force—states are part of a program that won't only be of great benefits to mums and babies. For example, it reduces the incidence of breast cancer and it reduces the incidence of osteoporosis in later life, and there is a list of at least two dozen benefits to babies. Surely the federal government should take a lead and ensure that states are part of this program.

—I take the point that in some of our state governments—and I can certainly think of what is happening with the cutbacks to health care in Victoria—there is a very considerable cutback in services to infant welfare services. Your point about early release and discharge from hospital means that information and other things that are attached to time in hospital or association with ante-natal visits and so on may well be falling back.

PARA.TAB: As to the figures on breastfeeding and the data collected around Australia, I do not have any of that at the front of my brain. I take your point. I have no reason to disagree with you. When we clearly know the benefits, it does seem outrageous that governments are backing away from processes to continue that campaign. I also believe it is very difficult: whenever our state colleagues get into trouble they turn to the Commonwealth, which has to try to lever them. The states demand their individual rights but then do not deliver, leaving the Commonwealth log jammed in this area, particularly, for example, in terms of agreements like Medicare—and I again cite Victoria. I will see whether the minister has anything further to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction and refers to the figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics this week, which show that long-term unemployment numbers increased by nearly 15,000 people in October to reach their highest level since February. The figures show that there are now over a quarter of a million Australians who have been out of work for longer than a year. Minister, don't these figures serve to provide further evidence that unemployment is on the rise and that your Working Nation program is failing to help those enduring long-term unemployment? Does the government have any new proposals to target the employment needs of those out of work for over 12 months or is the truth that you have simply run out of ideas after 13 years in office?

—The government, as I have explained on a number of occasions, has announced through our Working Nation statement of May last year a program to expend several billion dollars over four years on the long-term unemployed.
—But it is not working.

—It is definitely working. I would like to remind you, as I did in the Senate earlier this week, that the recent increases in the number of long-term unemployed reflect the pause—and we admit that—in labour market growth over recent months. However, the number of long-term unemployed is still 29 per cent, or 103,000, lower than the peak recorded in November 1993. It continues to fall as a proportion of total unemployment in trend terms. Clearly, Working Nation has had strong success in its first year in helping the most disadvantaged in the labour market.
—Ha, ha!
—You may laugh at the unemployed, Senator Abetz, but you do not have any policies—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Make sure it is a point of order, Senator Abetz.
—Yes, Mr President. I have been misrepresented by the minister. I was laughing at him, not at the unemployed.
—That is not a point of order, and you know it.
—The opposition is always sensitive—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Abetz was accused of laughing at the unemployed. Surely that is reflecting upon the senator and should be withdrawn. I cannot think of anything more offensive than that. He was laughing at your policies in relation to unemployment.

—That is not what Senator Abetz was asking, but if you are all so sensitive about things like that, then I will ask Senator Schacht to withdraw it. But I find that strange, because that is not what Senator Abetz was seeking.
—I have been asked to withdraw because I laughed at Senator Abetz?
—Order! No. It is all quite silly.
—What do you mean?
—Senator Abetz did not ask for an apology. He said he had been misrepresented. If he had asked for an apology, he would have got one.
—Mr President, on a point of order: I ask for an apology and a withdrawal.
—You did not ask for an apology.
—No, I am asking for one now.
—Order! Senator Schacht, for the sake of this silly bit of whimsy, would you withdraw?
—Mr President, can you indicate that in the future, if my leader asks for an apology and a withdrawal, that is of no consequence and that the senator offended has to ask for it personally?

—Mr President, on the point of order: it is quite open to Senator Abetz and Senator Hill to ask any senator in this chamber to withdraw. There is nothing in the standing orders about apologies. It is a standard practice—
—He did not ask for one.

—Senator Abetz, with due respect to you, Senator Hill, just asked for an apology and a withdrawal. Therefore, the only matter before the President is for him to ask Senator Schacht to withdraw, which he is going to do, and get on with his answer.
—I withdraw my laughter, Mr President. The government does fully—
—Senator Abetz, on a point of order; I would not press this too far, though.

—Mr President, you know very well that Senator Hill asked for a withdrawal of the offensive comment made by Senator Schacht—not laughter. In fact, Senator Schacht did not laugh at all; he made an allegation against me. Senator Hill asked that that be withdrawn, and that is what ought be withdrawn.
—Senator Schacht, just withdraw the comment and let us get on with it.

—I withdraw the comment, Mr President. But it does not excuse the fact that the opposition has no policies to reduce unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment, in this country. The opposition is a joke as a result. It creates great mirth amongst anybody who seriously studies the employment problems in Australia. You have no policies; therefore you are treated as a joke.

PARA.TAB: The government fully accepts that the numbers of unemployed, both short- and long-term, are still far too high, but it is confident that continued economic growth during 1995 and 1996 and beyond will lead to a further decline in unemployment and reduce the number of long-term unemployed.

The prospects for further reductions in long-term unemployment will also be improved by a range of enhancements to the Working Nation statement recently announced by Minister Crean. Wage subsidies are now available for job seekers unemployed for six to 12 months, and the subsidy rates for the long-term unemployed have been increased to maintain their relative attractiveness to employers. Contrary to the claim of the shadow minister, Dr Kemp, government programs are being provided to people before they become long-term unemployed. This will help reduce the flow of unemployed people into the long-term unemployed group.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, Senator Collins. It relates to the pullout of the Japanese southern bluefin tuna fishing fleet from the port of Hobart because of the failure to increase quotas and because of a divergence of opinion between Japanese research scientists and Australian research scientists. What priority is being given by the government to resolving this particular divergence of view over the stock levels of the resource? What action is the federal government taking to cushion the serious effect that this is having on the economy of Tasmania, particularly the economy of the port of Hobart? When will the Australian scientific view be placed before the commission? I hear that it is going to be before Christmas, but can that be hurried up? What action is then going to take place?

—I really cannot give Senator Harradine a precise answer to the last part of his question. I can certainly confirm, Senator Harradine, that on the advice that I have received from the Minister for Fisheries, who is responsible for this matter, it is certainly our intention to deal with this before the end of the year.

PARA.TAB: What has happened is indeed regrettable. These arrangements have been in place for some time, but always, I might add, as Senator Harradine is well aware, with a fair degree of interplay between the parties concerned. What happened is regrettable. An enormous amount of effort has been put in, as I am sure Senator Harradine is aware, and is being put in now, by Australia to try to redress the situation. We are hopeful that it will be successful and it will be resolved. I can assure Senator Harradine that the maximum effort is being put into this.

I will seek advice from the Minister for Fisheries as to the precise date when we expect to be able to put forward our position on this. In addition to that, I will ask the minister to provide Senator Harradine with a broader brief explaining to him the full nature of the Australian action on this to this point in time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Senator Schacht. In the budget forecast you foreshadowed job numbers to grow by about 240,000 over 1995-96. However, in the last four months the number employed has actually fallen by 43,700. In view of this alarming deterioration, what is the government's revised forecast for job growth and employment. If you have not yet revised your jobs forecast, are you going to continue peddling this Labor lie?

—I do not have before me information about any revised figures. Of course you would be aware, Senator Calvert, that on a half-yearly basis, and coming up in December, as is normal, there is a revised set of figures from the government on the outcomes of the budget, including employment figures, et cetera. That will be made available in December. That is a normal process this government has adopted for better management, an indication of government planning, and of course it is something that when you were last in government many years ago you never touched. You will have to wait until those figures become available in the adjustments to the half-yearly forecast.
