PARA.TAB: With regard to your remark about the government lie, I am not quite sure what you are referring to because, as far as employment is concerned, I want to point out further on the issue of reaching our target of getting unemployment down to five per cent by the year 2000 that we are maintaining the growth rates at the moment and we believe we still have a good chance of achieving that objective in a sustainable way. You on your side have not come near making any policy announcements on how you would achieve a five percent unemployment rate by the year 2000. We have not had any indication from the opposition.

I just want to conclude by further pointing out that since Working Nation was announced the assistance we have given to the long-term unemployed, for example, has resulted in 198,000 unemployed people gaining unsubsidised jobs or non-DEET education and training places in 1994-95. This is a positive outcome level of close to 50 per cent. That is one of the successes of the Working Nation statement. We still await from the opposition an indication of not only what your targets would be but also what your policies would be to achieve that target. We have both.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Once again I ask: are we likely to receive a revised foreshadowed jobs number before the election or not?

—I would hope that we would receive from the opposition some of your policy announcements. For 12 months, since Mr Howard became leader, we have not had an indication of any policy announcement at all. Will we get those before the election? I suspect not, because you have none.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—On 15 November Senator McGauran asked me a question on the Deer Park Hotel. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard. I have given him a copy in advance.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November 1995, Senator McGauran asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: Senator McGauran—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Deer Park Hotel in Victoria has struck the pub industry's first workplace agreement. Even though the employees voted in favour of the negotiated agreement and no employee is a union member, the union has protested against and blocked the agreement. Does your Government support union interference in non-union workplaces? Does your Government support union interference contrary to the democratic vote of workers? Is it not the case that enterprise bargaining has been so successful that workers are now voting with their feet away from collective bargaining and union representation? Is it not the case that such action is driving the increasingly desperate union leadership to take the only action they know—that is, holding the country to ransom?
In my reply I indicated that I was unaware of the specifics of the Deer Park Hotel case. I have sought further information and now provide the following response:

sub-section 170NB(1) of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 (the Act) entitles an organisation of employees to be heard if it is bound by an award that binds the employer in respect of work performed in the enterprise.
the Liquor Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union (LHMU) is such an organisation and exercised its right in the Deer Park case as conferred under the Act.
it made submissions to the AIRC when the case was heard in May, July and August 1995.
Commissioner Mahon, who heard the case, requested clarification in writing from the company as to the operation of four aspects of the agreement;
this clarification is to be appended to the agreement and become part of it.
Despite the requirement for clarification, Commissioner Mahon found that the agreement met the no disadvantage test.

Commissioner Mahon was unable, however, to approve the agreement for implementation because the company had not complied with paragraph 170NC(1)(i) of the Act, which requires the company to lodge the agreement with the AIRC within 7 days of the majority of employees accepting the agreement;
therefore, even if the LHMU had made no submissions to the AIRC, Commissioner Mahon could not have approved the agreement for implementation.
the Commissioner has requested that the company hold another ballot and relodge the agreement;
there is every likelihood the agreement will be approved if the ballot is successful.
More generally:
the Government supports the provisions of the Act which allows for a union respondent to the parent award to be heard,
the provisions do not confer on unions the right to prevent such agreements.
the Government notes that in exercising this right, the LHMU raised some points of concern with which the Commissioner agreed and sought clarification from the employer;
the employer is providing this clarification which will remove ambiguity from the agreement.

this is an example of how the provisions of the Act, which allow a union to be heard, and which provides clear and proper protections for employees through the no disadvantage test, can result in a better agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November 1995 Senator Parer asked me a question relating to CRA. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard. I have given Senator Parer a copy.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November 1995 Senator Parer asked me, as Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer—My question is to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray. Following Minister Brereton's obfuscation on ABC radio this morning, will the Minister categorically state whether the government condemns the secondary boycott action being proposed by the ACTU in relation to the Weipa dispute, including the crippling five-day strike on the waterfront and the proposed seven-day national coal strike next week, or is the Government so compromised by its desire to avoid conflict with its mates in the ACTU that matters of national interest are once again taking a back seat?
Following my answer to that question Senator Parer asked me:

Senator Parer—Will the minister at least confirm that the secondary boycott activities proposed by the ACTU are illegal under his legislation. If so, will the government support whatever action occurs, or is required, to uphold its own laws?
In my reply I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

The Government considers that the best way to resolve industrial problems which arise in the Federal jurisdiction is by direct negotiation between the parties in good faith or by using the processes available under the Industrial Relations Act 1988 for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

Even so, section 162 of the Act prohibits industrial secondary boycotts. Damages and injunctions are available from the Industrial Relations Court of Australia. A party who is directly affected by the action may pursue such remedies. If the alleged secondary boycott involves a Federally registered union or its officers or members, there must be up to 72 hours of pre-litigation conciliation by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as a pre-condition to bringing an action in the Court. The period may be shortened if the circumstances warrant it.
As to the Weipa matter and threatened industrial action, I do not propose to speculate on whether any parties will seek to initiate proceedings under the Act or what the outcome may be.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: South Pacific Forum

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday of this week Senator Newman asked me a question relating to the use of RAAF aircraft in connection with the Prime Minister's visit to PNG and the South Pacific Forum. Senator Newman asked how many RAAF Hercules flew in to Madang in connection with the South Pacific Forum and the Prime Minister's visit to PNG. The answer is one.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman also sought the dates of those flights and the routes taken. On 7 September equipment was transported from Richmond to Port Moresby on a scheduled C-130 PNG trainer. As I mentioned in the Senate on Monday, this aircraft flew on to Madang to conduct training activities. On 10 September 1995 this aircraft transported the equipment and six passengers from Port Moresby to Girua and from Girua to Madang. A RAAF Falcon 900 aircraft also flew from Canberra to Horn Island on 12 September and from Horn Island to Port Moresby and Madang on 13 September.

Senator Newman asked for a full inventory and passenger manifest for those flights. In regard to the inventory, Defence does not have exact details of the equipment carried, as it was packaged in crates. I understand that the equipment included photocopiers and water bottles. However, I will refer Senator Newman's question to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet for them to make a response, if appropriate.

Not all the manifests are available for the flights conducted within PNG, as they are not all retained. However, I am happy to table copies of two manifests which are available. Finally I should note that other tasks were undertaken in support of the Prime Minister's trip to PNG other than just destinations to Madang. I table two of the manifests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Watson concerning Telstra and its dividend payment. The Treasurer has provided me with additional information to answer that question. During 1994-95 Telstra earned revenues of $14.5 billion and posted one of the largest Australian company net profit results of $1.7 billion. Telstra's Group Managing Director of Finance and Administration, Mr Paul Rizzo, stated yesterday that Telstra's financial performance for the September quarter is marginally ahead of budget. He further stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The routine review of changing business conditions and the investment options available within Telstra has led to management action to rebalance some budgetary items. With this reaffirmation to meet 1995-96 financial objectives, Telstra's strong financial position is unaffected.

The government has not made a grab for money from Telstra. The government decided during the budget process to increase the benchmark dividend payout ratio to 60 per cent for all wholly owned GBEs apart from Telstra. Telstra's payout ratio is set at 55 per cent from the final dividend in respect of 1994-95 to the interim dividend in respect of 1997-98, rising to 60 per cent thereafter.

PARA.TAB: Telstra will also pay special dividends of $100 million and $150 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97 respectively. Telstra indicated at the time that the dividend rate was consistent with normal commercially acceptable bounds. Frank Blount, Telstra's Chief Executive Officer, stated that the decisions would not trigger price rises for Telstra's services or cuts to company investment or employment. He also stated that the decisions would not affect the company's long-term planning.

Telstra has advised the government that the planned adjustments foreshadowed in Mr Blount's E-mail are made in the context of meeting all customer demand for product and services and the continuous improvement of customer service. Telstra has further advised that the foreshadowed adjustments will not in any way affect the achievement of its target for 100 per cent network digitisation by the year 2000 and that network digitisation is currently on target, including in rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza has requested some additional information from me with respect to an answer I gave today in question time regarding climate predictions. I mentioned during that answer that the authorities in Queensland had provided a frost warning alert based on the data from the southern oscillation index. Senator Panizza asked me how far in advance of the frost that prediction had been made.

PARA.TAB: The advice I have received is that the frost alert was released on 31 May to growers in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales and the frost struck at the beginning of September, as predicted. I am advised that a number of growers did, in accordance with the frost alert, delay plantings and that as a result they escaped some of the more severe damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 November Senator Chamarette asked me a question about HIV-AIDS and testing of drugs, and I have some further information. Combination therapy with zidovudine and zalcitabine, which is also known as DDC, is already in approved use in Australia for some patients with advanced AIDS. The results of two international studies of combination therapy, known as ACTG 175 and Delta, are said to support more liberal use of combination therapy, including as initial therapy in some patients. The Therapeutic Goods Act requires that an evaluation of the supporting information be made before an approved use of a drug is extended.

PARA.TAB: The Therapeutic Goods Administration has initiated discussions with the Australian sponsors of three drugs used in combination therapy. The manufacturers have indicated that they will submit promptly detailed information for evaluation. In the case of ACTG 175, applications are expected before the end of this year. In the case of the Delta study, it is understood that the doctors who undertook the study will not produce a detailed report of their study for several months. On receipt, the TGA will evaluate the information as a priority. In addition, the pharmaceutical benefits branch will consider the possible subsidisation of combination therapy for expanded groups of patients in parallel with the evaluation by the TGA.

In relation to an internal audit of drug evaluation, registration and listing, a draft report is being prepared at the moment and will be finalised before the end of this year. I understand that, in addition to the department's current internal review of approval processes, the Australian National Audit Office is intending to conduct an efficiency audit which will cover subsidisation of drugs through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to table a copy of the report from Western Australia of the Royal Commission into Use of Executive Power. I believe some of my colleagues on the opposite side would benefit from a full reading of it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Vanstone this day, relating to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the findings of the Western Australian Royal Commission on the Easton matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon we had one of the most disgraceful attacks on a man, now a former royal commissioner, that I have ever seen. In defence of Commissioner Marks, now Mr Marks, I think it is appropriate to let his own words speak for himself. He says what we all know, that:
The investigatory process aims at discovery of the truth and is a valuable tool of democratic government for peace and good order.
I do not know that anyone could possibly disagree with that. He goes on to say:
The investigatory process—
which is what a royal commission is—
should not be abandoned nor fail to be used only because a disadvantage might flow to a political party and an advantage to another.
He adds:

The preservation of our system of government depends on preservation of public power to learn the truth of events in which there is a community interest. The power needs to be strengthened not weakened.
I do not know anybody, even on the other side, who could possibly disagree with that. But we might come to a disagreement on this point: Commissioner Marks says, and he is right in saying so:
It is accepted as fundamental to the administration of justice that impartiality of the decision maker and confidence in that person by parties—
that are before him or her—
and by the public depend on his or her freedom—
that is, the decision maker—
(and also that of witnesses) from intimidation or pressure . . .

There is no point in having a fact-finding exercise, be it a court or a royal commission, if the decision maker and the witnesses before that decision maker are in any way intimidated or pressured. The royal commissioner goes on to point out the sort of intimidation that he had to suffer and that members of the commission had to suffer under this government.

PARA.TAB: As we know, as soon as the commission was announced, this government did not worry about whether they liked the terms of reference. Even before they knew them, this government decided they would rubbish the commission from beginning to end—not just the people involved, but the terms of reference, the whole lot.

The government has sought to make much of the fact, for example, that Mr Gyles asked the commissioner to disqualify himself. Let us see what the commissioner has to say about that. He points out that, on the particular day application was made to have him disqualify himself:

SPEECH.PARA: The grounds were without substance but put forward, as is a common experience for a Royal Commissioner—
this is not something unusual, it is common experience for royal commissioners—
as part of a perceived protection against the risk of adverse finding. Moreover,—
in this case—
its timing coincided with activity outside the Commission in response to widely publicised evidence capable of doing damage to particular interests.

Anyone can tell you what the commissioner is saying there. He is saying that if you want to continue to be able to use royal commissions, if you want to have a fact-finding mechanism that is outside the parliament, one that reduces the political aspect of a fact-finding process by going outside the parliament, then you have to protect it. You cannot start rubbishing it from day one and continue to rubbish it; you cannot keep intimidating the decision maker and the people involved. That is what has happened here. Personal attacks were made on the commissioner, on counsel assisting the commission, and it goes on and on.

PARA.TAB: It appears, after Senator Ray's disgraceful contribution today, that this man, this senior citizen—I think he is in his sixties—who has made a long and valued contribution to the legal profession and the justice system of this country, will be hounded to his grave. Why? Because he participated in a royal commission, and the Labor Party does not happen to like the findings. What do you do? You pursue someone—not just threaten them not to take the job, not just abuse them when they are in the job, but get stuck into them when they finish the job. You chase them down to the grave. That is what will happen to this bloke. Senator Ray's example today was a disgrace. He stood up in this place and said that the royal commission, ipso facto the commissioner himself, was a wholly owned subsidiary.

I would like to hear what Senator Cooney has to say about this man who has served the legal profession well and against whom there are no allegations of bias. We will hear over the radio tomorrow and see in the papers tomorrow that he is a wholly owned subsidiary. You know what that means. It means that he is under direction. It means he does not follow an independent mind. It means he is on the take from the Premier. Any of you who stand behind that disgraceful attack on the commissioner today stand to be condemned as well. When will you let this matter rest and accept that an independent finding has been made? One of your colleagues lied. All your colleagues in the west know it. The sooner you accept it, the better.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of Australia are searching for the truth in relation to the very unfortunate circumstances that led to the suicide of a young women in Perth some years ago. They would not have gone about that search for the truth by setting up the Marks royal commission with those narrow terms of reference. The narrow terms of reference clearly set out from day one that this is a political witch-hunt. I have never used that term before. I know that there are witches in our community, but I do not believe the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, is a witch. She was the person that this inquiry deliberated targeted.

PARA.TAB: This a political vendetta against a leader of a political party who was defeated in an election. Mr Court, the Premier of Western Australia, was not satisfied with defeating her and her party in an election. He wanted to do further damage to her such as question the perceived power that she has.

This royal commission was not a search for the truth. The report that was tabled in the Western Australia parliament two days ago does not show the truth of this matter. We have not got the truth. I have stood in this chamber before and made statements that I would join with my colleagues on the other side to seek an inquiry into all of the circumstances in this case, but I mean all of the circumstances.

There are people in our community—some of whom hold very high public office—who know a lot more about the events that led to the death of Penny Easton and have never been brought before any of the Western Australian inquiries. They have never been brought before either of the two inquiries in the Western Australia parliament and, indeed, they have not been brought before the Marks royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name them.
—I am not going to be that low.
—There are witnesses but you don't want to tell us who they are. They should have been called but you don't want to tell us who they are. Get real! Nobody is going to believe that rubbish.

—If they were looking for the truth in this matter, the people who set up the inquiries would have called those persons. Why have they not called them? The question those in the community are asking is: why has this vendetta carried on for all these years and when are we ever going to get to the truth of the matter?

PARA.TAB: Should it be this parliament or this Senate that goes out and searches for the truth about the events that led to the death of Penny Easton? I hope not. I hoped it would have been done in the proper manner by a judicial inquiry, a royal commission, with proper terms of reference and not by the partisan inquiry that Mr Justice Marks presided over for the past few months. Unfortunately, Mr Justice Marks has been a very big loser as a result of what has happened. He accepted a brief with very narrow terms of reference and he got paid for accepting that brief. He has a quarter of million dollars in his bank account. I do not know how he is going to live with his conscience after what he has done.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to comment on the answer given by Senator Robert Ray today in response to Senator Vanstone's question, particularly in reference to the comments that were made with regard to the royal commission being a subsidiary of Richard Court, or words to that effect. In doing this, the best way for me to respond is to read into the record some comments of Mike Seccombe from this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. The heading is `Labor shoots messenger: typical, but it won't work'. We have been hearing this now from the Labor Party for a significant period of time. The article states four steps to discredit an inquiry:

SPEECH.PARA: One: Attack the process by which the inquiry was established, preferably even before it begins—
that is what they did—
Two: Attack the credibility of those giving evidence—
that is what they have done, and we have heard it again today—
Three: Attack the motives of the commissioner and/or the counsel assisting—
that is what they have done, and-
Four: Refuse to accept the findings, on the basis of the alleged corruption of all of the above.
Yet we read a little bit further—and I think there are some very telling comments in this particular article, and it will not take long to go through them—where it states:

PARA.TAB: But the Marks report did not rely on hearsay to show Lawrence as a liar. It relied on the first-hand evidence of her colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor colleagues.
—Her Labor mates. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The final report shows nothing but a forensic piecing together of damning detail.

Once again, we have heard those on the other side of the chamber claiming today and yesterday that the report did not go into detail. It would be wise if the people on the other side of the chamber took the time to read the report, and then they would find out what was in there. Further, the article says:

PARA.TAB: While Marks's comments in defence of the commission's establishment were laughable, his report could have brought no smiles to Labor faces. He nailed Carmen, but good.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a brilliant article in summing the whole thing up, and I will read one final comment from it:

PARA.TAB: There is just no getting around it. Carmen Lawrence lied, Kenneth Marks proved it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone has started to direct attention to a very important area which should be discussed further, and I hope Senator Ellison follows on from what I am about to say. They are talking about the process that was used in this royal commission and I think it is timely that we started to look at the process. As Senator Vanstone said, the process that was carried out by Mr Marks of Her Majesty's counsel was an investigatory process, and that is a matter of concern. It was an extraordinary investigatory process, one which was not normal and which did not have attached to it the protection that normally goes with this process.

PARA.TAB: I know Mr Marks has written a very learned article which says that the right to silence is not something that should be allowed. That is a respectable intellectual position to take. It is not a position I take and I know it is not a position that Senator Ellison takes, yet it is a position that was put into practice in this particular instance. This inquiry was about whether or not Dr Lawrence told the truth—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or acted improperly.

—Or whether she acted properly or improperly. The sorts of investigations that were carried out were not the sorts of investigations that would be carried out on anybody else in this chamber if the same sorts of accusations were made about them. Let us hope that it would not be. Let us hope that the process does not become one where people are put before a royal commission to test whether they are telling the truth or whether they have acted properly on a particular occasion. Once we go down that path, we will be going down a path that does terrible damage to the democratic system under which we live.

PARA.TAB: The democratic system requires that people should be protected from untoward investigatory processes. We have the right to silence. We are about to debate in this chamber the forensic testing bill, which sets up protection, as Senator Vanstone so well knows, from people who are under investigation.

The democratic system requires that we go about the investigation of people in a proper and right way. In this particular case the investigation was not gone about in a proper and right way. It is said there are extraordinary circumstances where a royal commission is called for. For example, it is said that the royal commission now being carried on in Sydney is a correct process. Nevertheless, even in such a situation where the New South Wales police are under investigation, it is proper that proper protection be given to people. That was not done in this case because royal commissions do not give that.

Undoubtedly, this process is an executive process, not a judicial process. The mistake is made again and again in this argument to suggest that somehow a royal commission is akin to a court. Indeed, Mr Marks, whose judicial learning I have great respect for, falls into that error. He was not carrying out a judicial function or even a quasi-judicial function. He was carrying out an executive function. As he himself said, he was carrying out an investigatory process, and that should be made quite clear. Dr Lawrence was subjected to an extraordinary means of investigation—the sort of investigation to which no-one in this chamber, as I say, has been subjected and, in my view, should never be.

Royal commissions should be used very sparingly and, in my view, for particular purposes and not the sorts of purposes for which it was used here. It is the sort of thing that Sir Adrian Knox as Chief Justice of the High Court realised and that is why he—(Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I put to the Senate that the reason for the calling of this royal commission was founded in long-held principles recently enunciated by the High Court. I refer to the case of Theophanous and the Herald and Weekly Times, where the High Court stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are legitimate reasons why the claims of the holders of high office in a representative government must be subordinated to the need for open and effective scrutiny and discussion of their official conduct and suitability.

This royal commission was to look into whether there was an improper or inappropriate use of executive power. And that, I would put to the Senate, is a thoroughly reasonable foundation for the calling of a royal commission. So when we look at the reason for the calling of this royal commission, we do not see any witch-hunt, as Senator McKiernan said; we see thoroughly well-founded principles.

PARA.TAB: As for the process that commissioner Marks pursued, it was again one which was proper. In fact, he did not rely on hearsay evidence. I refer to his report where he was looking at direct evidence. In relation to the infamous meeting of cabinet, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There were 16 persons who might have been present. The Premier was one, the Secretary Kobelke another and 14 members of Cabinet. Eight of these persons testified—
I stress `testified'—

that Dr Lawrence initiated discussion about the sponsoring of the Easton allegations. These eight were unanimous that it was Dr Lawrence who raised the matter. Dr Lawrence denied that she initiated any such discussion and denied that such discussion took place at all.

You cannot get it more direct than that. Commissioner Marks was relying upon direct evidence of people who were there—people who had no reason to give evidence contrary to Dr Lawrence. In fact, eight of them were from the cabinet over which she presided as Premier. So when you look at it, Commissioner Marks relied on direct evidence and believable witnesses. And, as well as those eight, there were another six who testified against Dr Lawrence.

PARA.TAB: Not only did Commissioner Marks engage in proper process; he gave Dr Lawrence's counsel every opportunity to cross-examine these witnesses. What is more, Dr Lawrence's counsel were given more than adequate opportunity to challenge this royal commission in the Supreme Court of Western Australia and the High Court of this country. I do not know how much more Dr Lawrence needs by way of assistance. You only have to look at her legal fees—$619,000 of assistance from the Commonwealth Government. That represents seven per cent of the Commonwealth's total funding for legal aid. It represents 13 per cent of Commonwealth funds attributed to the Aboriginal Legal Service for one year in Western Australia. That is what Dr Lawrence got in one bite.

And not only that. Dr Lawrence was given funding for her solicitors plus two counsel. I put it to the Senate that that is unreasonable, that a person in that situation does not need two counsel. That is extravagant on the part of the government. The funds involve a sum of $243,000 for the challenges I mentioned—$243,000 of Australian taxpayers' money was spent in challenging the royal commission.

But the worst part is still to come. Dr Lawrence lost three challenges. The question of costs has still to be determined, but there was a cost order against her in the High Court. The government cannot tell the people of Australia whether it is going to meet those costs. I put it to the Senate that it is thoroughly inappropriate that this government bear the costs of audit against Dr Lawrence for her futile challenges.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —Under our constitution the parliament is sovereign. It alone is elected by the voters, albeit we make them compulsorily vote. Ministers are held accountable to the government through parliament. If ministers are shown to deliberately lie to parliament, they face instant dismissal. All parties agree to this across-the-board. I do not think there is any dissent in that regard. Given that we all accept that, in this circumstance a royal commission has found that a minister lied to parliament. Unequivocally the royal commission found that. You can argue about the politics of it. You can argue about the constitution of that royal commission. You can argue about whether it was politically motivated. The facts of the matter are that the health minister, as a minister of the Western Australian government, lied to parliament.

PARA.TAB: So this issue strikes at the very essence of our constitution. If parliament cannot have the truth from its ministers then parliament itself is irrelevant. That point has been overlooked in the whole matter. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) must be held accountable for this because he has ignored that issue. I would like to put that on the record. This politician, this minister, who has been prepared to lie to parliament, has involved herself in a breach of her most fundamental public obligations. In turn, that makes the attitude of the Prime Minister even worse in this regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Abetz this day, relating to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put on the record the facts of how successful the government's Working Nation program has been. For the year 1994-95, 377,000 long-term unemployed people were put under case management. The outcomes for that were that 156,000 of them were kept in the employment they started off with in the training programs.

PARA.TAB: Some 61,000 have got full-time jobs. Another 21,000 actually found themselves jobs, even though they may not have got a job directly as part of their retraining program. About 2,000 went back into full-time study and another 52,000 either have found work, have gone back into study or no longer collect the jobsearch allowance.

I have heard the opposition on many occasions claim that these things are not working. They are always on about the dole. You people were going to take people—the long-term unemployed and everybody else—off the dole after nine months. That is your policy. You have not espoused another policy since Jobsback. You were going to take them off the dole after nine months. Jobsback is still the policy of the opposition.

The reality is that, for the 12 months to March this year, there was a decline in the number of long-term unemployed of 25 per cent. Since figures have been kept in this country, that is a record. There was a 20 1/2 per cent fall in the number of people unemployed for more than two years. They are significant gains in terms of the people that have suffered long-term unemployment problems. This clearly states that this government's policies are working. You only have to go out and talk to a few people who actually have got jobs as a result of the training programs and the money that we have committed to unemployment programs over the course of three years to 1997 to know that it is working.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't be there in 1997.

—Yes, we will, Senator Ferguson. A little bit earlier in the week we also had this business of claiming that unions are responsible for a significant decline in employment in the housing industry and in the house building industry. One of the members opposite—I think it was Senator Baume—came in here talking about the HIA, the forecast for south Queensland and so on. I went and got a copy of the October-November 1995 report of the Housing Industry Association of New South Wales. I wish to discuss where they think the industry is heading in terms of employment. I also want to make a couple of points about what Senator Minchin thinks we need to do to alleviate unemployment in this country.

PARA.TAB: There is an expectation on the part of builders nationally that through to 1996 there will be an increase of four per cent. Those opposite seem to blame the unions for a decline in the house building industry. But let me tell you this: I am not aware of one worker who is a member of a union and who works in the house building industry. They are mostly subcontractors. I do not know how you can blame the unions for a decline in the industry.

Senator Minchin is reported to have made comments in the Sunday Telegraph of 12 November about cutbacks in immigration. He says that we need to cut back immigration because of its implications on unemployment. The Housing Industry Association of New South Wales says that immigration is a boost to housing. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: New settlers add to the demand for housing and new home building, but for the housing industry it is the balance of new arrivals over departures (the net gain from overseas migration) that is more relevant. While the Government can largely determine the number of arrivals by setting the number of visas to be granted, there is little it can do about the number of Australian residents leaving the country. The level of permanent and long-term departures generally—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the limited time left I wish to refute the nonsense put forward by Senator Murphy and by Senator Schacht earlier. The Senate standing committee has had a very hard look at long-term unemployment over the last eight months. It found that Working Nation is not working around this country.
—On a point of order: there was not a majority finding by that committee.
—It was a majority finding, five to three. That is a majority.
—You put the facts as they are; do not misrepresent the Senate committee report.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—That is disgraceful. You want to cover up the real situation with regard to long-term unemployment in this country. Working Nation has failed. Clearly, long-term unemployment has gone up. Even with the numbers which you have taken off the list by definition, you are just churning the job queues. You are putting people into training. Half of those people do not get any work when they have finished training. What do you do then? You put them into another training program.

PARA.TAB: One witness said to the committee, `You would be better off leaving us in the gutter than picking us up and dropping us back in again.' What a damning indictment of the government that comment was. We heard evidence right around the country, including in regional areas, that your programs are not working. It is a disgrace. Working Nation is not working.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement by way of personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, under standing order 190.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, on Tuesday, 14 November, you ruled from the chair that standing order 190 had not changed since 1903. I did not dissent at the time. With the greatest respect to your office and knowledge, I would like to point out that it has changed. In the 1977 book on standing orders, the opening part reads `by indulgence', and it has now been changed to `by leave of the Senate'. Technically, I was correct in my claim.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Hill proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to protect ordinary Australians from the consequences of the industrial thuggery and chaos being driven by the national officers of the ACTU.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —We raise this matter of public importance today because of the seriously and rapidly deteriorating industrial relations situation in this country, clearly being driven by the leadership of the ACTU and certainly with no response from the government to rein in the excesses.
—Haven't you caught up with it?

—Yes, I am right up to date. I just got the last fax off the screen. Senator Ray may be unaware that the union leadership within the last couple of weeks blockaded the state of Western Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was called upon to respond.
—You asked me a question on it, remember?
—Madam Deputy President, do I have to cop this all the time?
—Why not address your remarks through the chair?
—The Prime Minister was called upon to condemn that blockade. He refused to do so.

PARA.TAB: What did the president-elect of the ACTU, Jennie George, say at the conclusion of that blockade? She said it was the start of industrial action that would be carried out right through till the election campaign. We might have been able to treat that as a one-off instance if the leadership of the ACTU had not come out within the space of a week or so and said that we will experience the worst industrial relations strife in this country for years.

We woke up this morning to these headlines: `ACTU orders shutdown. Strike chaos spreads. Power, ports, transport now under threat'. If Senator Ray does not know, let me tell him that the waterside workers started walking off this morning. They have joined the several thousand coalminers who were already on strike. The situation around the country is very serious.

Employers and, more importantly, employees are worried about the future. Employees are worried about their jobs. This industrial relations turmoil is being driven by the ACTU head offices. With the tacit support of this government and this Prime Minister, it will put an already very fragile economy at greater risk.

The many hundreds of thousands of Australians who are hanging on to jobs will be in danger of losing their employment because this government is not facing up to the fact that the economic situation is very worrying. There are already 740,000 unemployed, which the government will not acknowledge or take responsibility for. Economic growth is already starting to reduce. We already have growth under the figure which, on the government's own acknowledgment, is sufficient to pick up some of those unemployed.

So the situation is deteriorating. Unemployment in this country is going up again. Youth unemployment has just gone up from 27 per cent to over 28 per cent. In some parts of Australia youth unemployment under your government is already 40 per cent or 50 per cent, and the situation is worsening. That is the background against which we see this growing industrial turmoil around Australia at the moment.

We were expecting—obviously, without basis—to see some real leadership from this government to rein in the excesses of union leadership. The Prime Minister, as I said, refused to condemn the blockade of Western Australia. He refused to condemn the ACTU's action in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —You always take the employers' side, don't you?

—Just as well. It is interesting, Senator Ray. This dispute has been off and on for two years. Eleven thousand of the 16,000 CRA employees are already on individual contracts. Why is it that all of a sudden the ACTU is now implementing nationwide industrial pressure to achieve certain outcomes? What has happened in the last two years? What has happened is that they believe they have the opportunity to apply greater political pressure at this time.

PARA.TAB: Can we expect the Prime Minister to stand up to these excesses? Of course, we can't. All we got from the Prime Minister last night, finally—and he won't condemn the action—was that he was prepared to make a few phone calls. As he flew out of the country today he said he thought the matter would be solved by midday. Of course it hasn't. If you read the latest reports, it still hasn't been solved. People like Jennie George are saying they hope they are at the start of the process of negotiation.

I am pleased that CRA and the unions are talking. I don't want to see this industrial turmoil continue. I don't want to see more Australians suffer. They have suffered enough under this government. What have they suffered? They have suffered low wages. Average weekly earnings have fallen under this government's industrial policies. So they have suffered that, and 740,000 of them are out of work. That is an appalling situation. I do not want to see that worsen; I want to see it get better.

Why won't the Prime Minister show some real leadership so that in the next few months we don't get what Jennie George is promising us—increased industrial turmoil? He won't do so because in effect the government is accountable to its trade union wing. Even the Prime Minister is not prepared to take a different point of view.

What is happening out there at the moment is really quite fascinating. The rhetoric of the union movement has changed in the last few months. Under its new leadership it is now back to the old-time rhetoric, the old-time class warfare rhetoric—the continuing struggle between capital and labour—the discredited language of the past.

It is a background of alarm for the union movement. Why is it alarmed? Because the work force is walking out on unions. Less than a third of the work force are now members of a union. Why are they walking out? Because the union movement has let them down. It has let them down in terms of low wage outcomes. It has let them down in terms of conditions. What the workers of Australia have realised is that they can do better by themselves. They can do better if they go out and negotiate individual contracts or if they negotiate enterprise contracts.

The unions, of course, had the opportunity to adjust to the new opportunities, but they were not capable of doing so. They have not been able to respond to the changing industrial relations environment. Therefore, the workers have deserted them, because they have been able to do better by themselves. The return to the class warfare rhetoric has been linked to the unions' effort to reassert collectivism as the best means of industrial relations.

Senator Murphy knows it well. So many union leaders have been pensioned off because they have not been able to cope with the change. Too many of them have been pensioned off to the Labor side of this chamber. Collectivism is an alternative but if the workers can do better through individual agreements or if they can do better through enterprise agreements, why shouldn't they do so? Why should they be forced back into the old ways of the collectivist processes of the past?

That is what this government and these former unionist leaders opposite do not seem to understand: workers have been voting with their feet. Rather than facing up to the need to change and to adjust to the new opportunities and challenges, the union movement has decided to resort to the old tactics of thuggery, bringing the nation to heel. They want to take out the waterfront and the building enterprises—each of the industries that are threatened: the mining, building, chemical, transport and manufacturing industries. Did you hear Jennie George listing them the other night, saying that one by one they will be taken out and the country will be brought to ransom until the union movement has reasserted its traditional power base?

That is what it is all about; it is not about the interests of or benefits to individual workers, workers who have voted with their feet and got out of the system for something better. They are going to be dragged back, to their detriment. Sadly, what this government has done through the accord is link in the whole of the economic policies of the nation to the lowest common denominator outcome of collectivism in bargaining. Basically, the workers have done badly under the unions' preferred alternative. This government has locked in those outcomes through its accord with the ACTU leadership: government in partnership with the union movement to produce low and disappointing outcomes for workers.

Workers vote with their feet. They want to get out and make their own agreements. Take CRA as an example. Eleven thousand out of 16,000 workers have already seen the benefits of getting out of the old system and into a new system where they can work together with management and where they can adapt to a different workplace environment where they could build productivity for mutual the benefit of the worker and the company.

That is the sort of language you people opposite do not understand. You have been left behind by the work force; you have deserted the battlers of this country. Battlers under you have seen average weekly wages fall. That is why they are determined to get out. This government should be condemned for not standing up to this union thuggery. Particularly, Mr Keating should be so condemned.(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution from Senator Hill in part was a rerun of the debate we had yesterday. I have to say that there was nothing new from Senator Hill—nothing new from yesterday, nothing new today, nothing new on the rhetoric of the last 13 years while they have been in opposition—and, significantly, it was very repetitive.

PARA.TAB: Before I get into the detail of this dispute I want to make one point about the background of some members on this side of the chamber. Yes, I am a former trade union official, as is Senator Murphy. A number of us are former trade union officials. We do not apologise for that and we do not see the relevance of it. Every time someone from a rural background—a farmer—gets up on your side to speak, do we say, `You are driven by the vested interests of your rural background?' Do we say that the National Party runs your policy all the time? We know it is the reverse, in fact. You are running the National Party's agenda. It cannot get anything up any more. So it is irrelevant to talk about the background of senators and where they come from. It is typical of the approach you take today to politics and is one of the reasons you are in opposition. I make no apologies about my background or about where I came from, what I fought for and what I still fight for.

To turn to this motion today, it refers to the alleged `failure of the Prime Minister . . . to protect ordinary Australians from the consequences of the industrial thuggery and chaos'. First, this dispute had its genesis four or five years ago but it has come to a head in the last two days. The widespread industrial action that has occurred and is threatened to occur commenced two days ago.
Here we have the opposition, two days later, condemning the Prime Minister and alleging that he has done nothing to protect Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he do before last night?

—I am about to get to that, Senator Hill. The opposition expects the government to intervene and resolve this dispute in a day or two. Well, history may show that that is what may happen. We do not know at the moment. There have been some significant and constructive discussions. Last night the Prime Minister, as I understand it, contacted CRA and officials of the ACTU and had a number of discussions. I am not privy to those discussions but the Prime Minister, on recognising the significance and the difficult economic circumstances as a consequence of this dispute—
—You got rid of Senator Hill. He's left.

—Senator Hill is leaving. He does not want to hear about the discussions and the importance of the Prime Minister's actions. The Prime Minister acted immediately to contact the various parties to this dispute. In the last few hours the chief executive of CRA, Mr Leon Davis, has issued a statement welcoming the Prime Minister's intervention in this dispute. In his media release Mr Davis said that the company would be stopping the legal actions that it commenced against the employees at Weipa and that the company was prepared to attend hearings of the Industrial Relations Commission to address the disparity between award workers and workers on staff contracts.

PARA.TAB: I digress slightly here. It is not as Senator Hill alleges. He said that the union movement is intent on bringing back to the field the workers on individual contracts and to lower the playing field. In fact, it is the reverse. One of the critical issues in this dispute is that the workers at Weipa have been denied—and are taking industrial action, in part, because of this, which is their right—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a free world.

—Exactly, it is a free world and it is their right to take industrial action to try and achieve the same outcome that other workers have apparently achieved as individuals. That is what they are intent on doing. CRA's belligerent and over-the-top response to that has been, in part, to initiate legal action. I have to say that CRA has been reasonably effective in recent years, if you measure the time and the cost of going through the Industrial Relations Commission, of initiating proceedings in the commission. CRA has been spinning out the time matters take in the commission by a variety of legal strategies to frustrate the activities of the trade union movement and workers who want to receive a reasonable outcome in the various negotiations that have occurred at Weipa and at other sites around Australia.

PARA.TAB: Here we have an opposition that expects the Prime Minister to resolve a very deep-seated industrial dispute overnight. It is a deep-seated industrial dispute which has existed for four or five years at other places apart from Weipa. Industrial relations does not work like that. The opposition is showing its ignorance if it thinks that the Prime Minister, or a union official for that matter, can snap his fingers and everything is resolved overnight. It does not work like that.

We are dealing with human beings involved in very, very complex sets of negotiations. Not even the Prime Minister can make a quickie phone call and everything is right the next day. Hopefully, today or tomorrow we will see what success of the Prime Minister's activities have had. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) yesterday and today has had meetings with the company and with the ACTU. He is satisfied that the parties are negotiating in good faith.

Some of the detailed matters in these discussions have to be finalised before the Industrial Relations Commission. The commission is not irrelevant to this issue. It has a very important role. Both the parties have indicated a willingness to attend hearings that the commission convenes and that the commission has been holding over some time. So I think the indications are reasonably good. We do not know the final outcome, but I think the indications are reasonably good. Certainly, the Prime Minister has played a very effective role in negotiating with the parties and bringing them together.

If we look at our record while we have been in government, the level of industrial disputes in this country over the last 12 or 13 years has reduced very significantly. There are a range of reasons for that but, certainly, one of the reasons has been the effectiveness of the accord relationship with the trade union movement. We have only recently seen what the outcome will be under the opposition. We have only got to see what occurred in Western Australia recently with the total backdown there of the Liberal Party state government. The level of industrial disputation in this country over the last 12 or 13 years has declined significantly. It has more than halved.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have doubled the number of unemployed.
—In part, Senator Abetz, it is because unemployment has gone up. There is no doubt there is a relationship between unemployment and industrial disputes. But even before unemployment commenced—
—Commenced!

—Even before unemployment increased significantly, even before it started to rise six or seven years ago, the level of industrial disputes in this country was declining anyway because of the accord relationship.

PARA.TAB: What I think this dispute highlights is that the approach by CRA at the Weipa site and at other sites throughout Australia to exclude the trade union movement has been unproductive. It contrasts with the role of, say, BHP which has a very productive relationship with the trade union movement. BHP has involved the trade union movement in its reform process and has achieved very significant outcomes in terms of productivity.

This matter of public importance today is totally unnecessary—we are having a re-run of the debate yesterday—particularly in criticising the Prime Minister. The fact is that he has taken effective action and he has contacted the parties directly. How many political leaders around the world contact both the industrial trade union leadership and the company leadership within a day of a dispute commencing? There are very few who would do that. In fact, most do not get involved at all in this sort of dispute. So the Prime Minister has been effective. I am confident that the outcome of these discussions in the next day or two will show just how effective the Prime Minister has been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we can all say that we are pleasantly surprised by the good news that Senator Sherry has brought to the chamber today. If the management of CRA can issue a statement which indicates some degree of satisfaction with the progress so far and if the ACTU can indicate that it is willing to attend further Industrial Relations Commission hearings, then we in this place should not be so arrogant as to suggest that no progress has been made just because we refuse to see it. The trouble with conducting this debate in this chamber today is that really is what the case is: we are just demonstrating our blinkered vision and our refusal to recognise just what is going on out there.

PARA.TAB: I think that conducting this debate in this chamber today really does not contribute to the resolution of the problem at all. The conducting of the debate by the two representatives of the opposing theories in this area was expressed very well in an article under the headline `Bovver boys play hardball', which was written by Michael Millett in today's Sydney Morning Herald. I will continue with how he expresses it because I think it is quite instructive. He writes:

The dramatically escalating Weipa dispute has focused attention on two of the key players in next year's Federal election campaign—the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, and his Opposition counterpart, Mr Reith.

SPEECH.PARA: The pair are the archetypal "bovver boys" of Federal politics.

It is really about this shaping up, this sabre rattling and this taking a symbolic position, rather than looking at how the actual situation can be resolved. I ask the Senate: will this discussion today do anything at all to resolve the actual dispute? What is the coalition actually trying to achieve by proposing that this particular matter of public importance be discussed? Is it trying to escalate the problem or is it actually doing anything to protect the ordinary Australians from the consequences of industrial action, as is expressed in the proposition?

PARA.TAB: I would like to see more efforts being made to encourage the disputing parties to return to the only forum in which resolution can be effected—that is, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; not here, there. I suppose, if we are not going to do that in this chamber, the other positive thing that we might be able to do is to improve the legislation, because the claim is that this situation has arisen within the present laws.

As Senator Ray told us yesterday, the government's position was that this dispute has arisen not because of the law but in spite of it. Nevertheless, it has occurred and, as Jennie George suggests, the law could be improved. In yesterday's Age, Kenneth Davidson suggests that the legislation could be improved. He suggests:

That legislation could take the form of a prohibition on employers offering individual contracts to employees, if acceptance of those contracts meant the employees were unable to bargain collectively through their union.
The legislation could be ratified under the 1949 ILO Convention—to which Australia is a signatory—which protects the rights of employees to organise and bargain collectively.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not suggesting that that is necessarily the way to go but, if we are to do anything in this place, we would be more productive in debating that sort of question rather than the question that we have before us at the moment, which is simply a political point scoring exercise and which actually does not do anything to resolve the problem. The problem that we have before us is the previous couple of days where, rather than discuss and rather than try to seek a resolution themselves, the parties involved have been taking pot shots at each other. That does not resolve it, nor is it resolved by us in here conducting the same sort of exercise. We are just hearing, as I think Senator Sherry said, a repeat of the standard position, the pro-forma debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing?

—I am certainly not involving myself in that at all. The continuation of yesterday's debate does not do anything at all to resolve the situation we have today. I think that a continuation of this debate here is being seen by Australians as doing nothing—to use the words of what has been submitted for discussion—to protect ordinary Australians from the consequences of industrial action which is proposed and which is, in fact, taking place to some extent already.

PARA.TAB: This is a forum in which we ought to be doing a darn sight more than name-calling and seeking to blame somebody. Here all that we are doing in this particular discussion is seeking to place blame on one particular person. That is a ridiculous proposition. We know that there is more than one person responsible for bringing the situation about as we have it, and we ought to ask and seek vehicles for those people to be encouraged to sort out their differences in the correct forum—the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks made by Senator Hill on this matter of public importance. Firstly, let me say, Senator Bell, there is more than one person involved. Although the matter of public importance talks about the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), there is more than one person involved in this whole operation from start to finish. Historically, the unions' position has been to fight for the rights and conditions of workers, for better pay and entitlements, but things seem to have changed in latter times. They are far more involved in political activities and making sure that actions take place at the right time in order to improve any electoral prospects that they might have.

PARA.TAB: Here, for the first time, we have the ACTU declaring war on Australian industry because for the first time in history they see the writing on the wall and their future somewhat endangered. Individual workers have negotiated better terms and conditions by being contracted to CRA than anything that the ACTU or the Kelty award system could do for them. In the Australian Financial Review today the economics editor said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is far from clear that CRA is discriminating against award workers by paying those on contracts more to do the same job.

PARA.TAB: The workers on individual contracts are employed under an arrangement that the company expects to be more productive over the longer term. They have, allegedly, agreed to work without the artificial constraints previously imposed by the award and the unions and—more importantly in the long run—to have their pay rises set according to merit.
That's why CRA is prepared to pay these workers more, and why it certainly should pay more.

If the arrangement between CRA and its workers leaves precious little role for the unions, that's the union's bad luck. No-one has forced the workers to accept individual contracts. More importantly, no-one has forced the workers to give up their union membership.

SPEECH.PARA: This strike has nothing to do with the rights of workers to better pay and conditions. It is aimed squarely at the fact that the ACTU has finally found itself in a position of irrelevance in this case and it does not like it because those workers at CRA are getting a better deal without the influence of the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: To add further insult to ordinary Australians, the Prime Minister has failed to condemn the proposed week-long strike that is intended and which will cost the coal industry dearly.
In the same paper the Australian Coal Association boss, Mr Pinnock, said:
"As usual, the timing of a possible strike at the beginning of the coal negotiations with the Japanese would leave them—again—with the impression we are a strike-prone industry," he said.

"The average earnings in the coal industry are $72,500 a year and coal workers should think seriously about what they are inflicting on other workers who earn on average half their take-home pay," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many people in Australia earning far less than half of the take-home pay of those people in the coal industry who are getting $72,500 a year. Mr Pinnock also stated:

PARA.TAB: "Clearly, they hope to scare away other companies, other industries and workers from seeking to improve their earnings without using union negotiators."

SPEECH.PARA: This proposed strike comes at a time when other sectors are trying to battle out of years and years of financial difficulties. I speak with some knowledge of the difficulties that have occurred in the primary industry sector which, after many years of hardship in some parts of Australia, is just starting to turn around. We might hear of concessions for primary industry, that things will be taken on an individual basis and that there is a possibility that it will not affect primary industry in the same way as it has affected some other industries. But there is no certainty in that. Just at a time when things are starting to turn around and some people are looking like having a chance to get up off their knees, the ACTU moves in to try to kick them down again—with the apparent blessing of Mr Keating and his Labor government.

PARA.TAB: These are the people that the Prime Minister says he cares about. We have heard him on television saying that he cares about these people and what is happening to them. But these are the people who will, ultimately, pay the price if this thuggery means that they will not be able to get the expected prices for their products, which are at last becoming available to primary industry and primary producers, because they cannot get them off the wharves.

Where is the government showing leadership in this case? This is another opportunity for the Prime Minister to show how much he cares about the plight of ordinary Australians. But what do we hear? Silence. This series of strikes will cause massive damage to the Australian economy which is already plagued by massive debt. Mr Brereton's comments about the strike being a sign of things to come under a coalition government are just pathetic. This nation is facing a serious crisis and all Mr Brereton can do is try to run down the coalition and deflect any criticism away from himself. It is his set of industrial relations policies and he is the minister. He should set about taking some action, not sit about taking cheap political shots. If this strike goes ahead, it will cost Australia in loss of confidence among overseas markets and consequent long-term loss of trade as Australia becomes known as an unreliable supplier and international importer of goods, and people look to other markets.

This government should be condemned by all Australians who believe in a fair go for all. There is absolutely nothing fair about the strike action that has been condoned by the ACTU. It is not fair on the workers. It is not fair on employers and it is not fair on Australia and the future of Australia. If the union movement in Australia was genuinely concerned about the pay and conditions of workers, it would wholeheartedly support these outcomes of negotiated settlements such as those at CRA.

Unions have been watching their memberships fall dramatically over recent years, but the one thing they have failed to see is that not all workers want to be a part of the collective bargaining system. As mentioned by Senator Hill earlier, some 11,000 contracts have been signed by CRA workers. Why have they waited until there are only some 75 contract workers left at Weipa to try to do something about contract workers. I think that speaks for itself. Ultimately, this strike will cost the ACTU and the union movement far more than the employers and the workers that it seeks to attack. It is their marginalisation in industrial relations that is at stake. The one thing that we need to remember is that the unions were not rejected by the company. They were rejected by workers who sought individual contracts for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that Senator Ferguson does not understand what is happening in this dispute. The hypocrisy of the opposition in relation to industrial relations knows no bounds.
—And you do?

—Yes, I do, Senator Herron. Senator Ferguson has just said that the workers at Weipa sought individual contracts. That is completely and utterly wrong. If you know anything about the history of the dispute involving CRA you will know that it was the company that effectively blackmailed a lot of workers into taking huge wage increases and thereby abandoning their award entitlements.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that, notwithstanding the strength with which people may hold principles, eventually if you offer people enough money you may actually be able to buy those principles off. Of course, you will not always be able to buy everyone's principles off. What we have at Weipa is a number of workers who have held out for some time against this intimidation, against this blackmail, and are seeking to assert their democratic rights to remain members of a union, to have collective bargaining, to have collective representation and to be treated equally and not discriminated against because they adopt that attitude.

Senator Ferguson also asked: why did the ACTU wait until this time? For your information, this matter has been on foot for well over two years and there have been extensive and lengthy proceedings throughout the industrial courts and commission. All of those proceedings were initiated by the trade union movement. It was seeking to protect the rights of those workers who wanted to remain, who did not want to take up the individual contracts and who sought to resolve this dispute. Throughout that entire period and many lengthy proceedings, the union movement has sought to negotiate a settlement.

At the end of the day, you reach a position where there may be only one action left. No union official—and I know a lot of them—wants to see industrial disputation, but eventually you may only have one weapon left. When you talk about industrial thuggery, the real industrial thuggery that has been perpetrated in this country has been the recent actions of the Kennett government in Victoria and the Court government in Western Australia. What you have seen there is governments, in both cases conservative governments, seeking to use legislation to impose a system upon the workers of those states which destroys their rights.

For instance, what did we have in Victoria? We had legislation by the Victorian government which effectively abolished the Industrial Relations Commission of Victoria and which abolished the awards which forced all of the trade union organisations and employees to have to make applications back to the commission for registration and to start all over again. They tore up that history of regulation through the Industrial Relations Commission and made everyone start again. In doing so, they made it very patently clear that anybody who sought to maintain a position under the award was going to be discriminated against vis-a-vis those who may end up on individual contracts. Again, that is exactly what has happened in Western Australia.

This is the approach of conservative right wing governments throughout the world. We saw it in the US during the Reagan years. We saw it in the UK under Thatcher. We have seen it in New Zealand. If you cannot get your way, you tear up the existing legislative framework and impose a new system which clearly discriminates against organised labour and trade unions and drives their conditions and wages down.

What is the philosophy of the coalition? They say we should leave all of this to the marketplace, deregulate industrial relations and abolish the Industrial Relations Commission. But the moment there is an industrial dispute, what do we hear you calling for? We hear you calling for government intervention, but the sort of intervention you want is for government to come in with a big stick and beat the workers and the unions over the head and tell them, `Get back into your place. Don't fight for your wages or to protect your working conditions.' That is the sort of government interference that you want, and that is what real industrial thuggery is all about.

In contrast, what has been the approach of the Labor government? The approach has been one of cooperation through the Accord. As Senator Sherry said, you have seen a dramatic decline in the level of industrial disputation in that time. I have checked out the figures on this and in the last period those opposite were in government, back in 1981, in excess of 700 working days were lost per thousand employees. That number declined dramatically to 108 in 1993. Industrial disputes and working days lost now are at an all-time low for the last 40 years in this country.

That is the record of the Labor government's approach to industrial relations. That is what we have been seeking to have applied throughout this dispute, not the processes of the big stick and not governments coming in and beating unions and workers over the head but rather endeavouring to get the parties back to the negotiating table. It certainly demonstrates that the system can work if there is goodwill on both sides.

It is very pleasing to note that in the developments last night and today the company and the ACTU are heading towards a situation where they will be prepared to sit down and work this matter through. That is what we all hope will happen. That is what should happen. It should never have got to this stage in the first place where a group of workers were going to be discriminated against simply because they wanted to be members of a union and be collectively represented. We also hear Senator Hill talk to us about low wage incomes and the decline in average weekly earnings. That is a complete distortion.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it's not.

—It is a distortion, Senator Ferguson, because average weekly earnings are not average award earnings. Average weekly earnings were going up quite strongly a number of years ago because of the growth in non-award executive management salaries. At least we have seen some halt to that through the recession, but it has not stopped a lot of companies giving huge increases to their directors.

PARA.TAB: But look at what has happened to award wages, particularly for the low paid in this country. Throughout the Accord process they have seen massive improvements in their award rates of pay to get them onto decent minimum award rates such as in the textile industry, the metal industry and other industries. This has also happened through the processes of the social wage.

We get sheer hypocrisy from the opposition. They come in here and lecture us about award rates of pay for battlers. This is the opposition who opposed every single national wage increase except the last two. The only reason they supported the last two was simply because they had no other choice because the great mass of employer organisations out there were supporting them as well. But every single national wage increase bar the last two were opposed by you people. You took every step to try to stop workers on low minimum rates of pay in this country from getting wage increases through the national wage processes. That, of course, sums up your approach.

There is no doubt that if ever your side of politics achieved government in this country—and that will not be for a very long time—you would seek to bring back the industrial chaos, the industrial thuggery, that existed during the years that you were in office. I remind you: what was the last significant thing that Malcolm Fraser ever did on industrial relations when he was Prime Minister of Australia before 1983? He implemented a wage freeze. That was your legacy to the battlers of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear Senator Forshaw carry on again about principle. I wonder what the union movement would say if CRA went back to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and said they wanted to do away with the individual contracts that were paying people up to $20,000 a year more and return to the award. There would be wholesale outrage—at least from the workers, I do not know about the ACTU; but if the ACTU had any integrity there would be wholesale outrage.

PARA.TAB: Of course, what is going on here has really nothing to do with the rights of workers, of individuals. Instead, what we have here today is the debut of Jennie George as the ACTU president. She needed a big explosion. She needed to burst onto the scene with a bang to let everybody know that she had arrived. What an arrival indeed!
