Because the consequence of this strike is quite simply this: 32 bulk carriers will be paralysed in east Australian ports if this strike continues—32 bulk carriers will either be tied up, incapable of getting out of port or incapable of getting into port.

Lest anybody in this chamber or elsewhere does not believe that figure, my office has been phoning every bulk carrier terminal in Australia on the east coast today and these are the facts: in Gladstone one ship is ready to go; in Hay Point five ships are ready to load; at the Dalrymple coal terminal two ships are due tonight; at the Abbott Point coal terminal one ship is due tomorrow; at Port Waratah coal two ships are currently loading, two ships are ready to load and nine further ships are due to anchor by 21 November; at Port Kembla there was one strike affected arrival today, two ships are ready to load and one further ship is due tonight; and at the Queensland sugar terminals six ships are currently loading, which of course will also be strikebound and incapable of getting out of port. That is a total of 32 bulk carriers on the east coast alone.

But that is just the start of the cost of Jennie George's debut, because on top of that dozens of general cargo ships will be either incapable of getting into ports in Australia or stuck in ports in Australia. I take the opportunity to draw to honourable senators' attention a press statement issued today by the Port of Brisbane that said that eight vessels were likely to be affected by the strike action. Some were already in port. For example, the Tasman Venture is due to depart at four o'clock this afternoon. Other ships like the OOCO Educator are due to come into port. They will not get into port because of this action. This is what the union movement is inflicting on Australia. The average demurrage cost for each of those ships is $17,000 to $20,000 a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for the discussion of the matter of importance has now concluded.

To expedite the consideration of the documents I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of 10. Documents called in each group to which no senator rises will be taken to be discharged from the Notice Paper. Documents not called today will remain on the Notice Paper. Is there any objection?

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz—On a point of order, could I with due respect suggest that you take documents Nos 1 to 4 because documents 5 to 29 deal with bilateral and international treaties. I think a number of us would want to talk about treaties and it may be better to quarantine the first four.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October 1995, on motion by Senator Baume:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been a member of the Archives Advisory Council since its inception, as has Mr Colin Hollis from the House of Representatives. The Archives is an institution in which I take a great interest. I wish to say a few words this afternoon about this report and the work of the archives. In doing so I refer initially to the mission statement of the archives referred to at the beginning of the report. It says: `to preserve valuable Commonwealth records as part of the archival resources of Australia, and make them accessible to present and future generations'. Then it talks about how they would set out to achieve that mission statement.

PARA.TAB: I have the greatest respect for the director and the staff of the Archives. I think we have an archives second to none in the world in the work that it has done. There are a few things that I would like it to be more involved in than it is. It is not fault of the Archives that it is not. I refer to retaining census records. I personally believe that the census records are an enormously important part of Australia's history and heritage.

I regret the destruction of records that has taken place to date. I reject the concept that people would not give accurate information if they thought it was to be kept. In fact, there may be part of the records which could be dispensed with. But I believe there is other valuable information which should be retained for historians and Australians in the future to be able to have access to social information about the country and the way that it is functioning. I just mention that in passing as one thing that I would really like the Archives to do.

Some people seem to think the keeping of Commonwealth records, archives, is pretty boring and dull. But that is until they understand what it comprises. If you ever have the opportunity to visit the Archives repository at Mitchell or in any of the states you will, I suggest, be astounded and amazed at the valuable material and information stored there—not just documents, many of which in the end may well be destroyed as not relevant to be kept, but so much material which is of enormous value.

In the mission statement I read out, I referred to the keeping of these records to make them accessible to present and future generations. They are accessible but not in quite the way I would like them to be; I would like them to be much more accessible.

I regret that, as yet, we still do not have an archives building in the parliamentary triangle. I see it as being a building which is important to be in the parliamentary triangle, like the National Library, the High Court, the Art Gallery—those great buildings which are there already. I really do look forward to being at the opening of the archives building at some time in the future.

The Archives has put on many exhibitions in recent times, which senators no doubt have seen, mainly in the Old Parliament House. They have been great exhibitions and those that were held during the year under consideration are referred to in the report. But, in my view, that is not the place for them to be held. They should be in an archives building and they should be able to travel, as some of these do. But there is such a wealth of material that has been collected that should be made more readily available, not just to those who apply to get it out for the purpose of research but also to the rest of us so that we can see things on display and have a greater appreciation of the heritage of this country.

There has been talk of an archives building for a very long time. What I would like to see, if we cannot have a discrete building, is for it to be in the old administrative building—and I hope that the government will soon tell us what it is planning to do with that building. I know that Treasury and Finance, whilst they are being refurbished, are to move in there after Foreign Affairs has moved out. Hopefully after that, if no building has been made available for the Archives, there will be an opportunity for them to be given that building as an archives building to be used for the work that they do and for the sorts of displays of material that they have so that it will become available.
We seem to be missing out on heritage every way you look at it—the museum is being abandoned, which is something that is beyond my comprehension. But at least we need an archives building.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: List of Multilateral Treaties Under Negotiation or Review

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Ellison:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five minutes have been allocated to me to speak on this matter. The people of Australia may be interested to know there are 24 treaties before us. This document is a list of multilateral treaties under current negotiation. Those treaties are separate to the other 24. We have a range, from memory, of in excess of a dozen treaties currently under negotiation.

PARA.TAB: More and more of our domestic law is being impacted by this federal government's insistence on engaging in international treaty making without being concerned for the domestic consequences. When we on this side of the chamber complain about that and highlight the difficulties that will be occasioned to our domestic legal system by that, we are criticised by the other side of the chamber.

In recent times the High Court of Australia has come down and supported the view being put by people such as me that the signing of an international treaty does impact on domestic law. That High Court decision is referred to as the Teoh decision. There is currently a bill before us to deal with the High Court decision which basically says that if a federal government signs an international treaty it is appropriate for the people of Australia to anticipate that the terms of that treaty will impact on domestic law and that the citizens of Australia have a right to rely on that.

It is interesting to see how the Australian government deals with international treaty making. Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I come from Tasmania. We had a situation late last year, about this time last year, when our state government's legislation was overridden by the federal government legislating on the basis of the federal government having an international obligation and that it had to legislate; it had an international duty to legislate.

Isn't it amazing that when the High Court makes a ruling that the federal government has an international obligation to apply international treaties to the federal government's domestic law, the federal government runs into this parliament with legislation to override the international treaty. It does not want the international treaties affecting its laws. If it can affect Tasmanian laws, the federal government has this international treaty responsibility. It says, `We will beat our collective chest and we will say we have to override the Tasmanian parliament.' If it happens to override federal law, the Labor Party won't have a bar of it. That shows the hypocrisy and the duplicity of the government in dealing with international treaties.

This is a matter of concern to a number of people. I know that at this very moment, as I am speaking, colleagues of mine are meeting in the Legal and Constitutional References Committee, which is dealing with the external affairs power. A very lengthy and detailed report will be presented. I am sure it will be of great assistance to the people of Australia when it is brought down, hopefully later this month.

My time is running short. The brief contribution I sought to make was to highlight yet again the way the federal government approaches, in a very ad hoc way, the process of treaty making within this country and the hypocritical way that it approaches treaty making. When it is for its benefit, it will use the international obligation argument to override the states. When the international obligation argument overrides the federal government, it quickly introduces countervailing legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally I would not enter into the debate at this stage, but it ought to be put on record, so that there is no misunderstanding, that the legislation which Senator Abetz referred to was the privacy legislation dealing with human rights.
—It was called the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act.

—Okay, we will get the title right. Thank you for reminding me of that. The point of the legislation was it had to be carried by this parliament. This parliament voted to uphold that legislation. Senator Abetz, you may have been on the losing side on that occasion, but do not say it was done without the parliament approving it. The parliament approved the legislation in both houses.

PARA.TAB: You may not like that outcome, but you should not keep going around saying that that issue took place without the parliament voting and that the government signed a treaty that automatically overrode Tasmania's law. It only did it after this parliament by a majority vote in both houses carried the legislation. We asserted our sovereignty as a parliament on that.

If the bill had been defeated, it would not have overridden Tasmania's law. But it did not override Tasmania's law till it was carried through this parliament. The sovereignty of this parliament was maintained. You and others should not go around trying to create the impression that the sovereignty of this parliament is being overridden on these issues. It is not. The parliament decides the issue, and that is the way it should be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Baume:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the National Library of Australia's annual report for 1994-95. I have had the privilege of serving on the council of the National Library of Australia since 1991, and have had my term recently renewed. It has been a great honour to serve on a body which is one of the national icons in the parliamentary triangle, which Senator Reid was discussing earlier this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: This institution is in some ways misnamed because it is certainly more than a library. It is a repository of the cultural heritage of Australia; it is not just an institution full of books. I had the opportunity about three months ago to take half a day to go through the National Library to see what it held in its collections and to see what it was doing about creating new collections.

One of the unique features of the National Library as an institution is its use of devices such as oral history. This is where they bring in very famous people and get them to discuss on an audio record the events of their life. This becomes a priceless treasure for future researchers. Imagine if we had the records of what people had said back in the last century about the events that were happening in that century. Of course, we do not have that, but we do have it for the 20th century for people of the future.

The papers of famous people are collected, sorted and stored. Again this is a great repository for future research. The library also has a magnificent repository of materials of nations that are near Australia. It is a major bridge builder to other nations and assists other nations in their development of their library activities.

The National Library is the leader of Australian libraries. It undertakes a great many activities to assist the development of those libraries. It has the distributed national collection. This means that all the materials are not located in Canberra but are moved out on occasions to other places around the country. People in the major cities of Australia and in regional areas can access that material a lot easier when the National Library goes on the road.

Apart from the materials I have discussed so far there is also the art dimension. The National Portrait Gallery in Old Parliament House is under the control of the Australian National Library. In the last two years I have been delighted to see a number of the exhibitions that they have mounted. This has become a major attraction for tourism in Canberra. There was one exhibition on political portraiture, including the cartooning of Australian politicians over the years. This was a fascinating exhibition.

The new technology that is developing across the country with the information superhighway has given the National Library a new impetus in terms of distributing its materials across the nation. Eric Wainwright, to whom I would like to pay tribute as the Deputy Director-General, is a national leader in terms of information technology. I had the honour, together with another member of parliament on the council, to jointly launch the server of the National Library, which is a gateway between the internet and the rest of Australia.

Through this means it is quite possible now for the treasures that exist in the National Library to be distributed around Australia and into the hands of people in the universities and community centres. It is sometimes a criticism of the National Library that it is an institution solely based in Canberra, but it will become truly the National Library of Australia as the materials are distributed and people right around the country have access to them.

Finally, I would like to pay tribute to the Director-General of the National Library, Warren Horton, who has shown great leadership and vision in the development of this great national institution, the National Library of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Communications and the Arts

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Baume:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I restrict my comments to the Department of Communications. May I bring to the Senate's attention again the lack of communications in the Pilbara and Kimberley regions of Western Australia. I have asked the government time and time again to look at those areas where there is no basic radio service. One of the things that anyone in Australia—
—No Triple J.

—No, there is no Triple J. It is only for the high population places in Australia. But I believe that no matter where you are in Australia you should at least have access to a basic phone service—and that can go by the board—and a basic radio service should be available to everyone in Australia. I have said ad nauseam in this place, but I will say it again, that there is an area of north-west Western Australia—I wish the government would finally take note and do something about it—bigger than the size of New South Wales that has not got a basic radio service; it has not had one for nearly two years. The VLW short-wave transmitter at Carnarvon was closed down because it was too old and it was unserviceable. It used to carry the normal ABC programs out to those areas.

PARA.TAB: That transmitter was 30 years old and it would take only $1 million to replace it. In the budget of this government or any other government, $1 million is a very minimal amount to service an area as high in producing income for Australia as this area is. It has all the iron ore, various other mining enterprises, the pastoral industry, Aboriginal communities and so on. But this government sees fit not to give them a basic radio service. What reminded me was that during the week a question was asked of Senator Collins, I think, regarding Radio Australia transmission of programs into Indonesia.

I am a supporter of Radio Australia broadcasting overseas. It is a very worthwhile service even if it is only for the few Australians who are overseas. The point is that we have our own people living not far from Indonesia who do not have that basic radio service. That is inexcusable in this day and age. The argument I get from the government is that people can buy an earth station. You can buy an earth station for about $2,000 and set it up via the satellite and in that way pick up the ABC radio service. But that is loading $2,000 onto a station, a mining camp, a private household, or whatever, and it is totally ridiculous. People are entitled to have this service.

Even if you do want to go down that line you cannot use an earth station as a mobile unit when you are on the move. You cannot put one on the back of your utility or on a roof of your car and tour around with it because it has to be set up to face the satellite. This system does not operate on a ship, either. It is no good in most places because of movement. For the simple cost of $1 million this government can switch back this basic radio service to that area. Senator Abetz mentioned Triple J and all the other FM radio stations in the high population areas of Australia. We know that the SBS service is available throughout most of Australia. There are some areas of the country yet to be covered by SBS, but it is getting around the nation.

This is a high production area which is a quarter the size of New South Wales and it has no basic radio service. It is time that the government took notice of this issue. The amount of $12 million was mentioned as the cost to remove the transmitters for Radio Australia from Carnarvon to Darwin. If this government can spend $12 million to broadcast into Indonesia, it should spend $1 million on the Pilbara. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Australian Industrial Registry

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October 1995, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent times the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Australian Industrial Registry have been faced with a huge overload of work as a result of the government's unfair dismissal legislation which, hopefully, will be amended in due course. Part and parcel of this overload that the commission and the registry face was the unfair dismissal claim against the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) which had to go right through the system before it was finally settled.

PARA.TAB: It seems somewhat incongruous that the first parliamentarian to fall foul of this legislation should be a minister of the government which introduced the legislation. That highlights, once again, the duplicity of this government. The government is strong in rhetoric but its actions are the exact opposite. Even when a minister of the crown falls foul of the legislation, unfortunately the taxpayer has to foot the bill. That is not the situation with the hundreds of thousands of small businesses right around this country who face these claims and, as a result, are put to considerable expense.

But worse than providing an overload to the commission and to the registry and adding cost to small business, it is proving to be a positive disincentive to small business to employ new staff, because they are so concerned that they may well, if they find the need to dismiss someone, fall foul of the legislation. It is so very easily done, as Mr Sciacca himself has shown to this parliament and to the nation with the unfair dismissal claim against his office. There have just been so many—literally thousands and thousands—of these unfair dismissal claims made in recent times that there is this huge backlog, and claims are being delayed. Of course, justice delayed is justice denied to so many of the small business operators who have to face these claims.

Part of the problem as to why the commission is facing so many of these claims is that, even if a spurious claim is made and is finally dismissed, there is no way that the small business person can then reclaim the costs associated with defending the claim. Therefore, often the small business operator, after the matter has been in the Industrial Relations Commission and in the registry for a while, makes the decision to pay a few thousand dollars to the worker just to get rid of the case, although the operator would have won it. For the small business operator to have defended the matter in the industrial relations system and win it may well have cost them $5,000 or $6,000 but they could not then claim the costs against the person who brought the action. So, from a commercial decision point of view, they take the view that it would be a lot better to pay some small amount of money, which, of course, is an unfair bonus to the person bringing the spurious claim.

With the legislation that will soon be before us, I trust that the workload of the Industrial Relations Commission and the Australian Industrial Registry will get back to normal, that these outrageous claims and the outrageously high number of claims for unfair dismissal will be reduced and that the legislation will then ensure that people, even such as Mr Sciacca, do not find themselves in breach of their own legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I have read some of the report and skimmed through the rest with some interest. It does make interesting reading. However, I want to confine my remarks today to a matter that I have raised a number of times in this parliament, dealing with the surveillance carried out by the Coastwatch branch of the Customs Service in so far as it relates to the Torres Strait Islands and Far North Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I am still concerned, in spite of a number of issues that have hit the headlines in recent months, that there is still very minimal staff in the Customs Service in that area of Australia. I think eight or nine customs officers out of a total of 4,500 are stationed in that area. The significance of the Torres Strait and Far North Queensland is that it is the border of Australia that is closest to a foreign country. One of the islands in the Torres Strait, Saibai Island, is just a matter of a stone's throw from the mainland coast of Papua New Guinea. It is really just a short distance across the narrow stretch of water to get to Papua New Guinea.

Papua New Guinea does not have the same sorts of quarantine regulations and it does not have the same sort of law enforcement that we have in Australia. It is perhaps the most vulnerable part of the Australian coastline because it is so near to another country. Yet, in spite of recent occurrences and in spite of warnings that I have raised in the parliament—warnings that, I might say, have been treated by the minister with some disdain and laughter; he seems to think it is a laughing matter usually—I am very concerned about it, because I, like you, Madam Acting Deputy President, come from that area. You and I actually live closer to Indonesia and Papua New Guinea than we do to Canberra, so things that happen there are of fairly great concern to me.

I am aware that recently there has been a change in the Coastwatch contract up there. I notice in the report that there are some details of border administration and drug seizures in 1993-94 and 1994-95. As I read them, the seizures in 1994-95 increased quite dramatically in relation to cannabis. In 1993-94, the number seized was 1,038 and the weight was 50.8 kilos. In 1994-95, there were 1,091 seizures, but the weight was 6,449.7 kilos. I suspect, without having been able to locate this in the report, that that probably relates to that aircraft full of drugs which was apprehended at Bamaga.

The only reason I raise that is to say that the reason that aircraft was apprehended was not because of customs surveillance, not because of the watching capability through Cape York, but because people in Mackay reported that someone had purchased a plane with cash notes. That is what put the authorities onto it. My concern is that that aircraft full of drugs came right past Thursday Island and Horn Island, landed at Bamaga, dropped someone off, I think, and went back to Thursday Island and came back to Bamaga. I am not sure of the actual details, but it was a bit of a Keystone Cops sort of thing. It went close to the surveillance points and was not apprehended. That is what my concern is.

I have more detailed concerns, which I do not have time to relate now, and one of them is the Queensland's government's proposal to block off sections of Cape York. Without going into the environmental aspects of that, I do have a concern as to the law enforcement aspects of that proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer in particular to the `Chairman's report to the minister' on page 4 of that report. He says:

While the final recommendations of the Industry Inquiry have yet to be made public and your Government has yet to consider its response to them, uncertainties remain as to the tax regime to be imposed on the industry and its organisation structure.

The chairman, of course, in talking about that wine grape and wine industry inquiry and the extraordinary uncertainty that was at that stage, in October, prevailing in the industry was echoing comments by Mr Brian Croser, a very well-known wine industry figure and a member of that particular inquiry. On 10 October, the Advertiser reported this:

Mr Croser . . . said the hold-up was stalling valuable investment in the wine industry.

`The inquiry has been finished for 3 1/2 months and there is absolutely no reason the Government shouldn't get it out, comment on it and allow the industry to get on with planning its future,' Mr Croser said.
Given the state of the industry, we've been the victim of Government action and inaction for three years and it's time they let the industry get on with business.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a damming attack, by one of the industry's most prominent figures and a member of the government's own inquiry, on the government's treatment of the wine industry. Of course, three weeks after those comments by Mr Croser, the government finally released the report on the wine industry on 2 November, with the government's response—over four months after the report was given to the government and while the industry was going through an enormous period of uncertainty and all investment had been put on hold.

But the move by the government does not hide the fact that there has been a very significant increase in tax on this industry in the last two years, and it certainly should not give anybody any confidence that a re-elected Labor government—God forbid—would not increase the tax after the election. The government's treatment of this industry has been dreadful. The tax on wine has increased by one-third since the last election, despite the government's having spent the last election campaign running around the country attacking our proposition for a GST and leaving voters with the not unreasonable presumption that the government was opposed to any further increases in indirect taxation.

But then, of course, not long after the election, we had that infamous 1993 budget, which destroyed this government's credibility forever, in which the wine tax was increased from 20 per cent to 32 per cent—over a 50 per cent increase in the level of tax on wine. We indicated that we would strenuously oppose that ridiculously massive increase on this industry, and the government negotiated a compromise, with the agreement of the Democrats, to bring the tax back to 26 per cent. But that represented a one-third increase in the tax on the industry.

This industry has been a great Australian success story. With exports and growth, it has been doing very well. But, of course, under this government, once you start succeeding you get clobbered by something like a one-third increase in the amount of tax you have to pay.

This has just happened to another South Australian industry: a very successful product called Two Dogs lemonade has just had a massive increase in tax placed on it by this federal Labor government. Another success story has been whacked just as it was getting on its feet.

This tax has been particularly damaging to my state of South Australia, the home of the wine industry and where over half of the wine of Australia is produced—significantly more than the next most populous wine state, New South Wales. The wine industry is much more important to South Australia than to any other state and my state has been badly affected by such a significant increase in tax.

This government has attacked the other great South Australian industry, the car industry, which has suffered a huge increase in taxation since this government was re-elected in 1993 on a promise not to increase tax. The car industry tax was one of the all-time great broken promises—an absolute breaking of the promise made in 1992 not to increase the tax on cars. In fact, there was an added tax of $1,000. What this government has done to two great South Australian industries—wine and cars—has been absolutely reprehensible, and the voters of South Australia will express their horror at the forthcoming federal election.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This document reports on the work of NBEET. I want to speak in particular about the work of one of the councils of NBEET, which is the Schools Council. A key aspect of the council's role is educational accountability for the moneys spent by the Commonwealth government in the schools sector.

PARA.TAB: This ALP government has set a very poor record in this area. This came out earlier this year when the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee carried out a major study into accountability of the spending of Commonwealth funds. We heard evidence from right around Australia, and what it revealed were some very poor mechanisms of accountability as set up by the Commonwealth government. It has a great focus on inputs. But what you need, if you are to truly measure accountability, is a focus on outputs.

What the government does, after having done its measures, is to put out an authorised certificate saying that the funds have being spend adequately. But how does it know what its effects are? How does it know if the money is being spent properly and in accordance with the proper objectives of education? By measuring inputs, you do not know that. What you have to do is measure outputs. Poor federal accountability does not allow us to say whether we are basing our policy decisions for the future on the real needs of the students in our schools. We need much more work to be done on developing effective mechanisms for measuring educational outcomes.

We have identified data on inputs, the dollars spent, extra teachers and new programs. But that does not tell you how effective the system is. It reminds me a little of a program in America which was called `Headstart'. The Americans spent $1 billion on the program. It was to help disadvantaged children. But they had no way of measuring how effective the expenditure was. That was in the 1970s in America. Here we are in the nineties in Australia, and we are still using the same inadequate types of measures—measures that do not measure educational outcomes.

Another role of the government in terms of Commonwealth funding is, where it sees a need, to target particular programs around Australia into which state governments are not putting sufficient funding. This is an admirable concept. But when you come to an area such as the needs of the gifted and talented, this government amazingly—amazingly, especially after the speech by Mr Hawke in which he said we need to create the clever country—spent in the last two years, per annum, the grand total of $1 million across Australia on gifted and talented children. That is an absolute disgrace.

We had a report from a Senate committee in 1987 that came down stating that there were 17 things that the Commonwealth needed to do in the area of the gifted and talented—17 recommendations. The government acted on one minor recommendation. This is outrageous.

Two years ago the government decided that it would spend a little bit in this area. It was too ideologically blinkered to go beyond spending gifted and talented money on children from socially and economically disadvantaged families. Doing that is fine. But what about the rest of the children in this country who are gifted and talented? Why does this government disadvantage them by not putting in proper funding? The government set up that three-year program, and the miserable sum of $1 million a year was cut this year—the government has cut it out totally; it is not spending anything in the next year on gifted and talented children.

If we are to have an organisation by NBEET, it really should be overseeing what are our national priorities. It is not accounting properly for the money that is spent on education; it does not know its outcomes. And when we get to an area like gifted and talented children, it is doing nothing at all. That makes this government a national disgrace. It certainly makes a total mockery of any claim the government makes of developing `the clever country'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the authority and its members on the presentation of its report. I have been privileged in this past year to visit the Torres Strait Islands a number of times. I have been favoured to be able to have meetings with the chairperson, Mr Getano Lui Jr; the deputy chairperson and the chairman of the Saibai Island Council, Mr Terry Waia; and several other members including Mr Miseron Levi, the chairman of the Saint Pauls Community Council and a member of the authority; Mr Joey Mosby, a member for Yorke Island on the council and also the chairperson of the Yorke Island Council; Mr George Mye and also Mr Reg Williams, the chairperson of the Bamaga Community Council and a member of the authority.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to see the islands and see some of the difficulties under which they operate. Some of the difficulties which became very obvious to me were the provision of water and effluent disposal and also, on some of the islands, the airstrips, which are really the only means of communication and of travel in the islands—and certainly travel that should be available at all times is by aircraft. The day I landed at Saibai Island it had been raining and we landed on a short strip that was unsealed and full of potholes and puddles of water. It was quite an interesting experience to say the least.

The formation of the Torres Strait Regional Authority is the correct way to go. I say this in my capacity as a Queensland senator, I might say, not that this area of policy is one in which I have any particular authority. As a Queensland senator I think that the formation of the authority was the appropriate way to go. I am confident that we can expect to see a lot of progress in the Torres Strait Islands as the years progress.

One of the things the authority will have to look at is the continuing education in the islands. Again, I was privileged to attend some of the schools on the islands. I was on Yorke Island when the kids were practising for a festival in the following week. It was tremendous to see the way the kids are learning, becoming part of the community in which they live and also learning very important roles that will assist them through their lives. Some teachers explained to me, though, a concern about some of the children who had been doing very well in the island schools leaving the islands. When they reached 12, 13 and 14 and went to the mainland, they came under the influence of less desirable elements in that community and lost a lot of the training benefits and the purpose they had in life.

It is good to see that there are now schools in the major northern cities, like the Emmanuel College that I visited in Cairns recently, which are really trying to bridge the gap when the islander, Aboriginal and Anglo-Saxon children of that age group leave primary school and sometimes go astray. It is good to see places like the Emmanuel College playing a role by trying to ensure that these children do get a start in life that will enable them to lead productive and rewarding lives in the future. I hope to say a bit more on that matter on the adjournment debate today.

I wanted to briefly touch on the economic program of the TSRA. I note that one of their business funding schemes is to provide concessional finance in loans and guarantees to islanders to help them acquire and develop commercially successful businesses. I have been corresponding with Mr Tickner about a Mr Adrian Bon from the Bac-Ed Pamas Store on Thursday Island. He has had to borrow money from a bank and he is trying to get a better guarantee and a better deal from the TSRA. So far I have been unable to convince Mr Tickner that he should use his authority or influence with the TSRA to try to help this person establish his business commercially. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That seemed to me to be a rather odd way to conduct it.

I am one of the old school, where they used to count votes in the courthouse, or in a public building or public office, which you could lock. Going into a place where they are counting and pulling the votes out of a shoe cupboard and saying, `Hang on, I think the postal votes are here' struck me as a little odd. I do not know. Maybe that is something that Senator Minchin, who follows these things more closely, has looked into. Maybe it is the new style. But it seemed odd to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only in Queensland.
—Only in Queensland. It seemed a bit odd. Perhaps it is something the government should look at.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Before calling Senator Kernot, could I indicate that I understand that informal arrangements have been made in relation to the timing of this debate. I ask the Clerks to set the clock and remind honourable senators that this General Business debate will expire at 7.03 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That the Senate adopts, as a Code of Conduct for Senators, the principles set out in the document entitled `A framework of ethical principles for Members and Senators', tabled by the President on 21 June 1995, subject to the following amendments:

TAB.TAB: (a)Principle 1, heading, at the end, add "and its System of Government".
(b)Principle 1, at the end, add:

SPEECH.PARA: "Members and Senators shall act with respect towards the institutions of Parliament and shall ensure that their conduct, whether in a personal or official capacity, does not bring Parliament into disrepute, or damage public confidence in the system of Government.".

TAB.TAB: (c)Principle 2, omit the Principle, substitute the following Principle:

SPEECH.PARA: "2. Diligence and Economy

Members and Senators must exercise due diligence, care and attention, and shall at all times, seek to achieve the highest standards practicable in relation to their duties and responsibilities in their official capacity. Members and Senators, in performing their official duties, shall, to the best of their ability, apply public resources economically and only for the purposes for which they are intended, and expose fraud or corruption of which the Member or Senator is aware.".

TAB.TAB: (d)Principle 3, omit the Principle, substitute the following Principle:

PARA.TAB: "3. Respect for the Dignity and Privacy of Others

SPEECH.PARA: Members and Senators shall treat other Members and Senators, members of the public and officials honestly and fairly, and with proper regard for their rights, entitlements, duties and obligations, and shall at all times, as far as they are able to, provide responsive, effective and courteous service to all those with whom they have official dealings.

They must respect the privacy of others and avoid unjustifiable or illegal discrimination. They must safeguard information obtained in confidence in the course of their duties and exercise responsibly their rights and privileges as Members and Senators.".

TAB.TAB: (e)Principle 4, at the end, add:

SPEECH.PARA: "Holders of public office should not place themselves under any financial or other obligation to outside individuals or organisations that might influence them in the performance of their official duties.".

TAB.TAB: (f)Principle 5, at the end, add:

SPEECH.PARA: "Members and Senators shall immediately declare publicly an actual or apparent conflict between the requirements of official duty and any personal interest (whether a pecuniary interest or other form of interest), whenever such a conflict becomes known to the Member or Senator and irrespective of whether the interest involved is the subject of separate registration.

Members and Senators should take decisions solely in terms of the public interest, and, in carrying out public business, including making public appointments, awarding contracts or recommending individuals for rewards or benefits, should make objective choices on merit.".

TAB.TAB: (g)After Principle 7, insert the following Principle:

PARA.TAB: "7A. Accountability and Openness

SPEECH.PARA: Members and Senators are accountable for their decisions and actions to the public, must submit themselves to whatever scrutiny is appropriate to their office, and should be as open as possible about all the decisions and actions that they take. They should give reasons for their decisions and restrict information only when the wider public interest clearly demands it.".

PARA.TAB: (2)That, under the resolution of 13 February 1991, this resolution is an order of continuing effect.
(3)That the Senate requests the House of Representatives to adopt this Code of Conduct for its members.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been talking about adopting a code of conduct in this place for about 20 years now. I note that it began in 1979 with the Bowen committee. When the House of Representatives Committee of Inquiry Concerning Public Duty and Private Interests made recommendations, they were never formally agreed to by either house, but I understand that they have been accepted as the model for general application to all public office holders.

PARA.TAB: In the meantime, though, whenever we raise the issue of the need for a code of conduct, I am aware of a standard reaction, which has been, `Well, members and senators are already very well aware of the ethical standards of behaviour expected of them and they do not need these standards codified.' That might have been true once, but I do not think it is true any more.

We must all be aware that public faith in politicians and parliament has virtually hit rock bottom. The Morgan poll in the Bulletin published on 12 September this year revealed the depth of cynicism within the Australian electorate towards their representatives. I found the results of that poll disturbing but not surprising. That survey found that a mere

SPEECH.PARA: 24 per cent of those polled thought that politicians were usually truthful. It also found that 79 per cent said that politicians could not be trusted to keep election promises and that 84 per cent of those polled believe that politicians lie at election time to win votes.
