TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from this poll, which I said was not a surprise to any of us, the Democrats conducted a community phone-in. Out of that came some very sensible suggestions, some of which I would like to refer to. We had more than 250 calls from all around the country. The main themes that emerged from the calls were a need for greater honesty, integrity and accountability in politics. The strongest message was that people want some action taken to address what they perceive as a continuing decline in the standard of politicians in politics.

PARA.TAB: There was a strongly held belief that politicians have lost touch with their constituents, particularly in safe seats. Some suggested solutions to this—we could all have different opinions on how these suggestions would work in practice—including more public meetings; more referenda, with the public having an opportunity to input into the items on the agenda; and the greater use of technology. They are ways to give the community more input into policy making.

Suggestions for improving the behaviour of politicians included having an independent Speaker. Some people said that we should have a judge or somebody like that with more power to control the style of debate in parliament. Others suggested training courses for politicians. Others suggested a requirement that all politicians take an oath of office which would include having to tell the truth.

There was strong support for some code of behaviour for politicians that would not just stand alone but would have some provision for enforcement. A lot of people blamed the party political system. Callers suggested an end to party politics and suggested having secret ballots in parliament and more independent members. Many went on to add the things that have concerned them for a lot of years. The media also copped a lot of blame.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats in Western Australia would put an end to all that sort of stuff.

—Probably. For whatever reason, which I think the Bulletin poll encapsulates well, it is about time that we did something to put in place some rules. Codes of conduct already apply in many other professions.

PARA.TAB: The all-party working group reconvened in June 1994 and presented a draft code of conduct in June of this year, one year later. Until now, regrettably, we have not debated the merits or otherwise of that draft code. During the last session I tabled amendments which the Democrats believe will strengthen that draft code. That is what we are talking about now. Those amendments are open to discussion and further amendment. I hope that this debate will bring out constructive suggestions for improvement.

It is worth revisiting a little of the history. I mentioned the Bowen committee of 1979. The next thing that is worth noting are the events of 1986 and 1987, when the debate focused almost solely on the need for a register of pecuniary interests for senators and members. In October 1989 Democrat Senator Michael Macklin gave notice of motion to set up a joint select committee on the political behaviour of parliamentarians. The government and the opposition rejected that motion in 1989, relying on the argument that we, as members of parliament, are already aware of the political standards expected of us.

In April 1991, after the New South Wales Independent Committee Against Corruption suggested that the New South Wales parliament develop a code of conduct for its members, Ted Mack MP asked in the federal parliament whether the Commonwealth government would take up that suggestion as well. In May 1991 Prime Minister Hawke took steps to establish a working group to look at the matter. That working group did not meet until October, after the so-called Marshall Islands affair and after a further Democrat motion calling on the working group to be convened as a matter of urgency.

Another two years elapsed. In 1993, after the critical Auditor-General's report on the administration by the then sports minister, Ros Kelly, of the sporting grants program, the Democrats won agreement from the government, in March last year, to reconvene that working group as part of a package of accountability measures.

I would argue that, in the last 20 years, along with so many other changes in Australia, it does seem the rules of politics have changed as well and that the conventions of the past are either no longer relevant or are ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the conventions was about lying to the parliament. Ministers used to be sacked for that, but you said she shouldn't be.

—Yes, I agree with you. Some contemporary examples would include the tough it out at all costs model of ministerial responsibility. The questionable use of royal commissions is equally a contemporary example. Subjects such as the pressure of the cost of modern campaigning, the fact that someone in a public relations firm thought sponsorship of federal cabinet was probably okay to try as a fund-raising tool, suggest to all of us that the lines in 1995 are quite blurred and that we need to challenge them and clarify them.

PARA.TAB: The amendments I have suggested in the motion that we are debating draw on recommendations by the Queensland Electoral and Administrative Review Commission and from the code suggested by the British Nolan committee report on standards in public life. The key changes seek to strengthen the responsiveness of parliamentarians to the community for their behaviour; to require parliamentarians to avoid placing themselves under financial or other obligations which could affect decision making; and to ensure the primacy of the public interest.

Let me refer to some of the changes I have added. I come to the first matter in the working group's draft. No. 1 has as its title `Loyalty to the Nation and Regard for its Laws'. To that I have added `and its System of Government', because I think it is very important to spell out that members of parliament should act with respect towards the institutions of parliament and should ensure that their conduct, whether in a personal or an official capacity, does not bring parliament into disrepute or damage public confidence in the system of government. That is what I think is important: public confidence in the system of government. We are talking about this parliament and this system.
The second example I give is in the working party's draft code. Under the heading `Integrity' it simply says:

SPEECH.PARA: Members and Senators must at all times . . . strive to maintain the public trust placed in them, and advance the common good of the people of Australia.

I think that should be further spelt out. I think we should say, `Holders of public office should not place themselves under any financial or other obligation to outside individuals or organisations that might influence them in the performance of their official duties.'

PARA.TAB: Under the heading of `Primacy of the Public Interest', which again I think is too general and too vague, I seek to add, `Members and senators should take decisions solely in terms of the public interest and in carrying out public business, including making public appointments, awarding contracts or recommending individuals for rewards or benefits, should make objective choices on merit.'

The current draft code does not deal with the issue of enforcement of the standards. I think that must be a key issue if this process is to succeed. Too often governments seek to defend their own, regardless of the evidence, and too often oppositions seek to make political mileage without necessarily searching for the truth. That is one of the end results of a party political system. It is a natural result. It is the context in which we operate. I do not think it is necessarily the best one, but it is the context we have.

But often we go too far. In the defence of our own or in the pursuit of our opponents, I think we lose sight of how we are behaving and how we are perceived. Something is needed to ensure that in the main our behaviour as members of parliament reflects the values and expectations of the community at large. Parliamentarians need to know that, if their behaviour is deemed unethical, they will be investigated by independent, impartial officers and then brought to account through proper parliamentary procedures.

It would be really easy to say, `This is all just the nature of politics,' and do nothing about it. It is not just politicians who are held in low regard by Australians. I cite the media, banks and lawyers. But the fact that we are held in such low regard often discourages many who would otherwise consider doing so from standing for parliament. It sets an example to young Australians that certain kinds of behaviour are not just acceptable but the norm.

The fact is that we, as federal parliamentarians, have in our hands the opportunity to do something about it. So I have proposed reforms to parliamentary procedures, firstly, to establish a joint house ethics committee to develop and enforce the code of conduct and, secondly, to establish a parliamentary commissioner of standards to undertake impartial and factual investigation of any allegations or breaches of the code. I have circulated details of how both these bodies would operate.

I think these will provide the teeth that will make the code of conduct stick. We do need to do something to help restore confidence in the parliamentary processes and in parliamentarians by providing the community not just with one avenue of complaint but with input into the development of standards of conduct and the process of enforcement. In my ethics committee no political party would have a majority, but the balance of power would be held by four community representatives.

One of the findings of the Bulletin poll was that two-thirds of the people believed that neither side of federal politics has the courage to make the tough decisions required for the long-term good. I hope that on this occasion the Senate will prove those two-thirds wrong. (Time expired)

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! Before I call Senator Tambling, could I say that I find some of the interjections and the joking atmosphere of this debate fairly inappropriate, given the subject matter. I hope that all honourable senators will take this matter seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are addressing the motion by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, on the very important issue of a code of conduct for senators and members. Let me say at the outset that the Democrats stand condemned upon these very codes of conduct, not for what they have done, but for what they have not done; not for their political piousness and virtuousness, but for their cowardice and hypocrisy.
—This is the party that has police outside their meetings in Western Australia.

—Yes. Yesterday, the Senate debated the suitability of Dr Carmen Lawrence, a person found by a royal commission to have lied and to have acted improperly, to hold office as the Minister for Human Services and Health. How would you expect the Democrats to react, how would you expect a party committed to keeping the bastards honest to respond in this case? Let me tell you how they did. Democrat Leader, Senator Kernot, stood up in this place and criticised the new political morality under Labor adding that `the entire episode has brought parliament and politicians into even further disrepute'. But her indignation and her outrage lasted only until the division bells. At that point, she and her colleagues sided with the government and, in so doing, confirmed that dishonest and improper behaviour by a minister is acceptable to the Democrats. It is not, and never will be, acceptable to the federal coalition.

PARA.TAB: In spite of yesterday's charade, the Democrats are today asking the Senate to consider a series of amendments to the so-called code of conduct for members and senators. They are amendments, they say, that will strengthen the principles of the code. But I ask the Democrats: why bother to strengthen the principles when you refuse to use your basic parliamentary vote to condemn the actions of Dr Lawrence? On one day the Australian Democrats vote against their so-called principles—as they did yesterday—and the next day, today, Senator Spindler comes into this place at question time and asks probing questions about Dr Lawrence's legal fees for her cover-up actions. Come on, get real, why not act on principle?

It is evident that the Democrats do not have a monopoly on morals in this place. The need for a code of conduct originated in April 1991 when the independent member Ted Mack in the other place asked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in question time whether he would initiate the development of such a code. The Prime Minister subsequently asked the Presiding Officers to establish a parliamentary working group and the matter rested until the Marshall Islands affair involving former Senator Graeme Richardson broke in 1992.

The furore subsided and the matter stalled again. Then, in 1994, Ros Kelly hit the headlines over her administration of funds under the community, cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program. The working group was reconvened and the work on the codes began in ernest. At this point, I would prefer to say that public trust and confidence in the institution of parliament was restored but that would ignore the subsequent controversies over Graeme Richardson's book, Alan Griffiths and Dr Lawrence.

The members of the cross-party parliamentary working party included a cabinet minister, Senator Robert Ray; his Labor colleague Senator Jim McKiernan, who I note will speak today; the Democrat Senator Vicki Bourne, who I note will not be speaking today—she has obviously been gazumped by her leader; the Greens Senator Christabel Chamarette; the Independent member Ted Mack; as well as Liberal and National Party representatives including Senator Reid, Ian Sinclair and me.

The so-called codes of conduct are in reality two sets of principles that set minimum standards of behaviour for members of parliament, ministers and Presiding Officers. These principles do not and cannot prescribe or legislate for integrity or honesty but send an important message to the people of Australia that we share their concerns about abuses of parliamentary standards. Here we must ask the important question: why is it that today's Democrat motion addresses only the draft framework of ethical principles for members and senators with a number of amendments that they have brought forward when, at the same time, the Democrat motion ignores the companion document entitled A framework of ethical principles for ministers and Presiding Officers? Is this just another example of the cosy relationship between the Democrats and the ALP—pious preaching and feather duster politics?

The omission again reveals the hypocrisy and cowardice of the Australian Democrats. What a shame that Senator Kernot's team has shown up as opportunists and lacking in consistency or fibre of character. Why isn't Senator Vicki Bourne, the member who participated in the development of these codes of conduct, participating here today in this debate? She has obviously been nobbled by Senator Kernot.

It is academic to ask whether the implementation of such codes of conduct would have prevented or limited the damage inflicted on the integrity of this parliament in recent years. But it is appropriate to look at how the code would work.

I turn to the so-called sandwich affair which involved then minister Alan Griffiths and led to the Prime Minister establishing an inquiry to examine: firstly, whether there was any conflict between Mr Griffiths's private interests and the performance of his public duties; and, secondly, whether he authorised or condoned any inappropriate, improper or illegal activities by any of his staff in relation to the conduct of his private interests. The inquiry found that there had been no direct conflict or personal breach, but:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there has been conduct on the part of Mr Griffiths which does not meet standards which might reasonably be expected of a minister.
And, in relation to three specific matters:
. . . the inquiry finds errors of judgment and/or a want of diligence.
The report from which I am quoting was released in August this year. As well as the Alan Griffiths affair it lists a who's who of Labor misadventures.

PARA.TAB: There is Young in the Combe-Ivanov affair, Young in the Paddington Bear affair, Dawkins in the mother's shares affair, Young in the election donation affair, Richardson in the radio 2HD affair, Richardson in the Marshall Islands affair, Kelly in the sports program affair and Collins in the pay TV affair. I might remind Minister Collins of the Senate select committee's report into the pay TV affair which called for a `form of guidelines against which a minister's exercise of responsibility can be assessed'. Those guidelines now exist on paper. The specific code for ministers and Presiding Officers reads, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers and the Presiding Officers are responsible for the competence with which they handle their public duties, the relevant actions of their personal staff and their departments, and their personal conduct insofar as it affects their public role.

Subject to action taken by the Prime Minister and Cabinet, each House of the Parliament may consider matters raised by Members and Senators under this framework and a majority of two thirds of Members of a House will be necessary to resolve a matter.
It is worth speculating how Dr Carmen Lawrence—and her memory—would stack up against just two of the principles outlined by the parliamentary working group:

Honesty. Ministers and the Presiding Officers must be frank and honest in their public dealings and in particular must not mislead intentionally the Parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently by a Minister or Presiding Officer must be corrected at the earliest opportunity.

Use of Influence. Ministers and their Presiding Officers must not exercise the influence obtained from their public office to further their personal interests, obtain any improper advantage or benefit for themselves or another, or any promise of future advantage.

Yes, the codes of conduct are long overdue. For too long we, as elected representatives, have allowed the sins of a few to undermine the public's trust and confidence in the integrity of the parliamentary institution. The two sets of principles—one for senators and members and the other for ministers and Presiding Officers—are integrally linked in and to this parliament. Today, the Australian Democrats are attempting to separate them, to pull out the one which embarrasses them and look only at the one over which they want to make some publicity and some pious dealings and ignore the other one that is currently causing embarrassment to the Australia Labor Party. They stand condemned. The credibility and reputation of the Australian Democrats has been wrecked by their crass and flawed approach to this important issue. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —An important debate is occurring in the Senate this afternoon on the matter of a code of conduct for members and senators, the elected public office holders of this country. Reference has been made, both in Senator Kernot's motion and by previous speakers, to the work of the working group set up by this parliament to look into a code of conduct for senators and members. The working group came up with two documents which have previously been tabled in both chambers. The first one is called a `Framework of ethical principles for ministers and presiding officers' and the second one is called a `Framework of ethical principles for members and senators'.

PARA.TAB: I had the honour—I am not saying it was too much of a pleasure but I certainly had the honour—of serving on that working group with my parliamentary colleagues Mr Ted Mack, an Independent from New South Wales; the Hon. Roger Price, an Australian Labor Party member from New South Wales; Mr Les Scott, a Labor Party member from Queensland; the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, a National Party member from New South Wales; the Hon. Senator Robert Ray, a Labor Party senator; Vicki Bourne, an Australian Democrats senator from New South Wales; Senator Christabel Chamarette, a Greens senator from Western Australia; Senator Margaret Reid, Deputy President of this Senate and Liberal Party senator for the ACT; and Senator Grant Tambling, a country Liberal Party senator from the Northern Territory.

When you go through that list of names, I now find it amazing on reflection that the committee actually got as far as it did in developing a draft for discussion by this parliament on a framework of ethical principles for ministers and presiding officers and a similar document for members and senators. All of us who served on the working party come from diverse backgrounds and, indeed, have diverse political experiences. Some of us have been in parliament a little time; while others have served at cabinet level, very high office level, in the governments of the country, both present and past.

We come from a variety of political parties. I am from the Labor Party, like some of my colleagues; others on the working group represent the Liberal and National parties as well as Senator Vicki Bourne from the Democrats and Senator Christabel Chamarette from the Greens. We approached this matter from a whole range of political perspectives and we have got some degree of unanimity of where we go. In the working group, from my recollection, we did not say, `We are here developing a bible which will be the be-all and end-all for the behaviour of all members and senators in this parliament.' What we did come up with—in the circumstances I think they are two very good documents—were frameworks for further deliberation and further discussion by the House of Representatives and by the Senate.

This is not new. It is not—as Senator Tambling said—something that arose in recent times in that, all of a sudden and out of the blue, there was a need for a code of conduct for members of parliament and for senators. The need for a code of conduct has been in existence ever since a parliamentary democratic system of government evolved, and that is now some thousands of years ago. Indeed, various codes of conduct have evolved within that period of time. I have only been in this parliament a relatively short time, but already we are getting closer to agreement on a code of conduct.

One of the very significant things that has happened in my lifetime in this parliament is the fact that a register of senators' interests came into existence in the Senate. It was not in existence when I came into the parliament in 1984, but it is here now, and it was this chamber that decided it would come into existence. For all the high moral ground that Senator Tambling seeks to take here in the chamber this afternoon on the amendments proposed by Senator Kernot and on the draft framework that the working group presented to the parliament earlier this year, I do have to remind him that his side of the parliament opposed that register of senators' interests, as indeed his side of the parliament opposed a similar sort of register to register the interests of members of the House of Representatives.

Part of the reason why I paid tribute to the working group and exclaimed some surprise that we actually reached the position that we reached is because of some of what Senator Tambling had to say. He named a number of persons in government who have, or may have, been seen by some to have got themselves into some form of difficulty because of the way that they have worked in their portfolios in years gone by.

By interjection, my colleague Senator Murphy mentioned the name MacKellar, an honourable minister who lost his ministry because of something to do with televisions. A member of the working group, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, got himself into trouble. Neither Mr MacKellar nor Mr Sinclair were mentioned in Senator Tambling's contribution here this afternoon. The reason why he did not mention them is that he is part of that political side of the parliament that they are all part of, and they will support their own, as indeed there would be an expectation on this side of the parliament that we in turn would be supporting colleagues from this side of the chamber. I know that Senator Sherry on the front bench would probably want to be making some interjections about the behaviour of one Mr Robin Gray, who was not, of course, mentioned by Senator Tambling in his contribution here this afternoon.

It is a difficult problem that we have to deal with, but it is a very worthwhile debate that the parliament is engaging in. It is something that I am sure all members of parliament, be it at the Commonwealth level or at the state level, address their minds to when they are elected to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —But MacKellar got the sack.

—Senator Panizza interjects that Mr MacKellar got the sack. Senator Panizza again has consistently failed to grasp the point that I am mentioning. You failed again, Senator Panizza. I made the point that he got himself into trouble but was not mentioned by your colleague on that side of the chamber when he was talking about ministers who got themselves into trouble.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Panizza, we are not in committee. Senator McKiernan, would you address your remarks through the chair, and I will try to keep Senator Panizza quiet.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were, Mr Acting Deputy President, distracted. I was, indeed, addressing you, even though I was trying to demonstrate to Senator Panizza how some of his colleagues come and address matters such as this one that is before the chamber now. I was actually putting my hand over my left eye, because that is the approach that my colleague Senator Panizza was taking then.

PARA.TAB: It is a difficult problem that we are addressing this afternoon—setting up a code of conduct. As the working group found when they developed the framework of principles for members and senators and ministers and Presiding Officers, there were a number of barriers and a number of hurdles tossed up to us during the discussions that we were not able to overcome at that time because there were different understandings of what a code of conduct is for different people.

There would be some in our community who would have said 210 days ago that it was incorrect for me to smoke as a member of the parliament, that members of parliament ought to set an example to the rest of the community and not smoke. Indeed, we do have to be careful about what we put into ethics and who determines what our ethics are, not only for us but also for other very prominent members of the community. I wish this debate well and hope that in the future we will be able to address it in a more constructive way than perhaps it has been addressed so far here this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate that we should be having because the issues strike at the very heart of modern politics. However, it is like a group of murderers sitting around discussing how to dispose of the corpse. After yesterday's politicised debate on Dr Lawrence, there can be no doubt that values and ethics in politics are dead. A new politics which rests firmly on the values of the community will not be born of measures like a code of conduct. Codes, rules, orders, resolutions, determinations or guidelines cannot ensure that politicians act with propriety if the system in which they operate strips them of their own personal values when they enter it. The system needs to change.

PARA.TAB: By far the worst assailant of values is party politics. The supremacy of the party over personal conscience, parliament, accountability, and ultimately community values like honesty, is the root of the ethical malaise. I used to wonder why, when backbenchers came in for divisions, they just asked which side they should go on instead of what they were voting about. I now know why, because sometimes their consciences would be extremely disturbed if they did know what they were voting for.

As I have said, the system needs to change. The roots are fed by the competition for power, position and remuneration. And, ultimately, the constant suppression of personal beliefs to party beliefs leads to the loss of those beliefs altogether. One cannot maintain beliefs the validity of which one constantly denies. Political expediency, fed by the desire for electoral survival, perpetuates the problem.

It is little wonder that the community feels so alienated from a politics which displays values so different from their own. I have a belief that a politician is as out of date as the length of time they have been in parliament. Therefore, I am now three years out of date. I derive this example from my background in the prison system, where people, because they were separated from the ordinary community and had to learn to survive in the new rules, when they left prison were out of touch; a part of them had stopped growing. I think the same has happened to politicians. That is why we cannot retain leadership. It is the community that is ahead of the politicians right now at this point in Australia's history.

The path to an ethical parliament is paved by a breaking down of the power of the party system, by bringing in proportional representation to get a better reflection of the community, by conscience voting and by a tying together of personal commitment, social purpose and spiritual meaning with the day-to-day requirements of a parliamentarian's role. Integration rather than a compartmentalisation of our values and our conduct is essential.

I ask honourable senators here in this chamber and those paying attention to this debate to consider how they bring their own beliefs and values to bear on their duties or their work as members of this parliament. I include myself in this. Do we at all times act with absolute honesty, integrity and clearness of conscience, and with a feeling that we have acted in the best possible way? When we know that we have acted against such values, do we acknowledge that we have done so and redress the situation, or do we pretend that what we did was okay?

A growing trend throughout Western society is to divorce our work from our hearts; to quarantine what we do from what we believe. I quote an excerpt from a book called The Soul of Politics by Jim Wallis, who says:

Our intuition tells us the depth of the crisis we face demands more than politics as usual. An illness of the spirit has spread across the land, and our greatest need is for what our religious traditions call "the healing of the nations." The fundamental character of the social, economic, and cultural renewal we urgently need will require a change of both our hearts and our minds. But that change will demand a new kind of politics—a politics with spiritual values.

Several decades ago, Mohandas K. Gandhi warned against what he called the seven social sins. He named them as politics without principle, wealth without work, commerce without morality, pleasure without conscience, education without character, science without humanity, and worship without sacrifice. These social sins today provide an apt description of our leading institutions and cultural patterns; they are the accepted practices of the life of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: There may be an accountability role for a broad enunciation of principles and mechanisms for making parliamentarians account for their actions. It was very valuable being on the committee that crossed all party boundaries to try to look at this problem. Certainly, changes to our processes to increase independence and reduce the adversarial nature would also be beneficial. However, without addressing the fundamental lack of personal values in the political system, any code's existence is simply window dressing on a bomb site.

PARA.TAB: The Greens support the work of the Democrats in bringing this issue into political debate and also support the release of the discussion paper. It is healthy for this debate to occur both inside and outside parliament. While we believe that this attempt to strengthen the framework of ethical principles for members and senators will not solve the problems we face, it will improve what already exists and as such is a step forward. We will support this motion, but ask all senators to look into their hearts and at their actions and judge for themselves their conduct. As feminism so rightly declares, we cannot ignore that the personal is the political.

I will conclude by referring to a wonderful article by Matthew Fox entitled `Deep politics and grace'. He says that the 15th century is when the modern era of politics began—it is not so modern after all. It started with the invention of the printing press and the introduction of Machiavelli's The Prince. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Up to this time, the theory of politics from the Middle Ages and from Aristotle was that a politician was a person of virtue who led people virtuously. But Machiavelli secularized politics.

Instead of talking about virtues of justice, for example, Machiavelli said that rules of politics should be whatever is appropriate to the situation and leads to success. He said that growth and expansion is more important than justice and constitutes the law of life. He came up with the image of what we call today the modern state.
Do we recognise this in the way our political system operates because if we do not we are blind as well as deaf. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: The movement from modern to postmodern is the movement from honoring an ego or political "star" to people empowering themselves. From ego-centric (which is always anthropocentric) to omnicentric. It is the movement from "politics as usual" to deep politics. It is the resurrection of community passion, including moral outrage at the Babylon of modern politics around the world. Deep politics is also the passion of what we really do believe in. It moves politics from game playing to the lower chakras where pain and sorrow and survival dwell. Moving politics from secularization (anthropocentric) to sacralization (holding all sacred) is the work of postmodern politics. We humans are the only species that can choose to cut ourselves off from the sacred: we have done it in politics; we've done it in science; we've done it in education; and we've done it religion and in art. This is why we elders of our society are building prisons for our young people instead of giving them spiritual opportunities. The modern world has been very hostile to the experience of the sacred. Even the churches and synagogues have run from it and have tried to sell us religion instead of awakening our spiritual empowerment. So this phrase deep politics is a turning point in four hundred years of modern politics in society and church.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that will be an inspiration for us when looking at any discussion paper or code of conduct because unless we embody it in the way we work then it will be, as I said before, window dressing on a bomb site.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the committee involved in the development of the code of conduct, which was tabled by the Presiding Officers earlier this year. I was very pleased to be a part of it and look at the papers and documents which came to us. I support the code which has been presented.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is a realistic document but I actually believe that a piece of paper will not make the slightest bit of difference to a person who is going to be dishonest and untruthful because they will probably rationalise what is in it in relation to their own behaviour and conduct. In the end, the electorate deals with all of us at regular intervals and is able to judge the sorts of people we are and the way we behave and conduct ourselves in the offices we hold.

I do recognise the reason for having the document, and I want to go through a little of the background of what the committee did in coming to the conclusion it did in presenting the document to the parliament. We considered a number of other codes of conduct that had been drafted before in considerable detail: the Queensland Electoral and Administrative Review Committee draft code, the Bowen committee report that has been referred to, and a draft code suggested by the Hon. Kevin Rozzoli. We read and looked at all of those documents in considerable detail and found a number of things in them that were good and a number which we regarded as inappropriate for what we were doing.

We had a draft brought to us which in a sense took into account the proposals in the documents that I have mentioned and we spent some time analysing it. We found within it a number of things which were so subjective that we felt it was not reasonable to bring them to the parliament. I will come to it shortly but I think the same arguments apply to a number of things that Senator Kernot has put in her amendments to our draft code, which are before us this afternoon.

We also gave the public, institutions and groups an opportunity to contribute. It was interesting to read through a resume of some of the submissions that came before us. One suggested that members should have at least one day a month when people can make an appointment to speak directly to them and comment about the conduct of question time and speeches. One said that the code must be expressed in clear English and be easily translated into the language of ethnic minorities, should be brief and therefore easily readable and must be issued to all politicians before they take up office.

Another one suggested that any code must protect the independence of all members of parliament and that restraints on members should be kept to a minimum. Another one was that all dorothy dix questions should be discontinued—that would make a difference, wouldn't it? They were some of the things we had before us. In addition to the Bowen code I referred to, we looked through the Cabinet Handbook, the rules relating to the declaration of member's interests, the situation of lobbyists, the handbook of the Department of Administrative Services, the rules relating to gifts and things of that nature.

Members and senators had an opportunity to contribute suggestions to the committee. Senator Kernot certainly did that in a letter she wrote to the Speaker on 24 November 1994. She said she was writing to him in response to the group's invitation for comment on the proposed draft code. She expressed the view that `while covering some important subject matter, it needs to be strengthened and expanded'.

She raised particular concerns such as the need for the issue of personal references from ministers to be addressed, a factor in the resignation of Senator Richardson in 1992. Overall, we decided that it should not be a document that tried to spell out every aspect of human behaviour that may arise such as if thou art a minister, thou shalt not write a personal reference, et cetera, or if thou owns a sandwich bar, thou shalt not, et cetera.

We came to the view that you could not have a code of conduct that attempted codification in that fashion and that it needed to deal with the type of behaviour that we were referring to. In her letter, Senator Kernot referred to the need for a clearer delineation between the roles of departmental staff and ministerial-political advisers. She raised issues about ministerial grants and how they would be dealt with and other matters. We considered those things and felt that, in principle, they were dealt with by the code in more general terms that we presented to the parliament. She again put another submission to us later but there really is not time to deal in detail with all of these things this afternoon.

I wish to come to the two documents in question. I share the view that it is regrettable that only one of the documents is before us. One is entitled, `A framework of ethical principles for senators and members', the other, `A framework of ethical principles for ministers and presiding officers'. For some reason it is only, `A framework of ethical principles for senators and members' which Senator Kernot is dealing with.

In looking at the amendment which Senator Kernot has brought to the Senate, I wish to refer specifically to paragraph 3 of the document, `Respect for the dignity and privacy of others'. Senator Kernot states:

SPEECH.PARA: Members and Senators shall treat other Members and Senators, members of the public and officials honestly and fairly.
In principle, one of course would not disagree with that, but if you are actually going to put it in print, it is an extremely difficult thing to adjudicate.

PARA.TAB: She said today that she would set up a committee with some members of the public on it to be the adjudicators or the enforcers of this code of conduct. But it is such a subjective test that members and senators shall deal honestly and fairly. I would think all of us do that. I would not doubt that my colleagues in this chamber deal honestly and fairly with members of the public, their own colleagues and officials. But I can imagine the sorts of situations where somebody may disagree with what a member or senator wants to do, suggests or proposes, and then claim that the issue has not been dealt with honestly and fairly. Who is going to judge? There is another part in the same paragraph of Senator Kernot's amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . shall at all times, as far as they are able to, provide responsive, effective and courteous service to all those with whom they have official dealings.

What does `responsive' mean? Does it mean, `If you, Senator, do what I ask you to do, you are being responsive'? If you say, `No, I cannot write to the Minister for Immigration and suggest that this should happen, I'm sorry', will you then be challenged, taken to court, taken to this committee, for having been unresponsive? Surely a member or senator has to make a judgment about such a thing. I have said to constituents, `I really do not agree with that. I cannot espouse your cause.' Will I then be challenged for being unresponsive as a member?

PARA.TAB: Effective? I write to the minister, I plead with him, leave a few tears on the letter, ring him up, go and see him, waylay him in the corridor and he still says, `No, I will not do what you are asking me to do for your constituent.' So I have not been effective. Who will judge whether I tried hard enough, or whether I should have done something else? I would say that I do everything I can to be effective for my constituents with the things that I believe should be pursued. Who is going to judge? And `courteous service'? Again, it is extremely subjective.

It comes up again under paragraph (f) principle 5, to act solely in the terms of the public interest. My goodness! Look at the law books. How do you determine the public interest? And `make objective choices on merit in awarding contracts'. There are other things that need to be taken into account. I cannot accept Senator Kernot's amendments, but I do suggest the Senate adopts the code.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I pay tribute to the speech just made by Senator Reid. I thought it was a very great contribution to a very important matter. I also thought that Senator Kernot in her speech raised issues that are central to what we are discussing today. Indeed, everybody has made a good contribution to the debate so far. One thing we ought to realise is that parliament is perhaps the most important institution in our democratic system. We can sometimes not understand that. One of the things we have to do if we want to make parliament better is to realise the great dignity and great responsibility of the task we undertake. In other words, we should have a pride in what we do.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette put forward the proposition that coming into the parliament divorces you from the real world. I paraphrase what she says. She criticised the party system. Arguments are often put against the party system, but a party system is central to the way our system operates. That was recognised by Edmund Burke as far back as 1770.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had the seat of Bristol and he lost it the next time around.
—I understand, Senator Crichton-Browne, what you say but I think he is seen as one of the great philosophers who provided concepts upon which our parliamentary system operates. He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Party is a body of men—
These days he certainly would have said `of men and women'—

united for promoting by their joint endeavours the national interest, upon some particular principle in which they are all agreed. For my part, I find it impossible to conceive, that anyone believes in his own politicks, or thinks them to be of any weight, who refuses to adopt the means of having them reduced into practice. It is the business of the speculative philosopher to mark the proper ends of government. It is the business of a politician, who is the philosopher in action, to find out proper means towards those ends, and to employ them with effect.
He goes on to say:
Men thinking freely—
and I hope today he would have said `men and women thinking freely'—

will, in particular instances, think differently. But still, as the greater part of the measures which arise in the course of public business are related to, or dependent upon, some great leading general principle in government, a man—
and I add a woman—
must be peculiarly fortunate in the choice of his political company if he does not agree with them at least nine times in ten.

I put forward for consideration the proposition that a party system is the one that was adopted by Australians as a whole; it is the one they want. Senator Cook gave me a page from the Bulletin of 12 September 1995 which would indicate that. The question that was under consideration was this: if a federal election for the House of Representatives were held today, which of the following would be the most important to you in deciding who you would vote for?

PARA.TAB: The question was asked with regard to the party as a whole. Fifty-eight per cent of all electors said that that was the most important thing. Of that, 56 per cent came from the ALP, 62 per cent came from the coalition and 53 per cent came from other parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that issue?
—It is from the Bulletin of 12 September 1995.
—What was the question, though?

—The question is: if a federal election for the House of Representatives was held today, which of the following would be most important to you in deciding who you would vote for? I will let Senator Crichton-Browne have a copy of it.

PARA.TAB: When we are looking at ways to improve parliament, we have to look at the realities upon which it operates. If we try to invent a system different from the one that operates and which has operated very well, we will be getting ourselves into trouble. We have to remember that the parliamentary system under which we operate has delivered us perhaps the best country in the world. Again and again, people get up in this chamber and outside it and parliament and say that Australia is a country that has a lot going for it and that it is particularly fortunate when compared with other countries in the world.

As you look around the trouble spots of this world and see the conflict and oppression that emanates from all sorts of places around the globe, you have to concede that the system under which we live here is a fine one and that the parliament has played a big part in it. So have others, such as the courts. I commend for reading a speech given by the present Chief Justice of the High Court, the Hon. Chief Justice Gerard Brennan, which was the Blackburn lecture of 7 August 1990. He criticised parliament. He went on to say that it still serves a great purpose but that it should be supplemented by the courts. That is a matter for debate. He said that the system that we operate under needs improvement and that it does not need replacing.

That theme was echoed by Sir Winston Churchill, who said that democracy is the worst form of government except for every other one that has been tried. That sums up our problem at the moment. Our problem is that somehow we have sold ourselves short. Somehow we as parliamentarians have accepted the trenchant criticism, a lot of which is justified and a lot of which is not, that puts us down and indicates to the world that somehow we are less than perfect. Of course we are less than perfect. But nobody in the world is perfect; everybody is in need of redemption. We need confidence when we go about our tasks in this place. Senator Reid is absolutely right when she says that people in this place try to go about their tasks as well as they can.

Of course they can be improved. Senator Kernot has introduced today and spoken eloquently to a topic that we should discuss not only today but again and again. A reading of the High Court says that there have always been members of parliament who have gone beyond the pale. Cases such as the King v Boston and Horne and another v Barber—there are others as you go through the High Court reports—show that there have always been people who have got out of line. That will happen in any profession. We need to improve a system that by and large is a very good one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I say that only because I notice that Senator Woods, the next speaker, is not in the chamber and, no doubt, the whip will want to phone him and make sure he is in here in a minute or two.

PARA.TAB: When I read the draft proposed by the working group I could not help but feel that the document, by and large, as best I can tell from quickly reading it, refers to and reflects upon the honesty and integrity of parliamentarians in respect of ensuring that they do not accrue benefits improperly in the discharge of their duties or as a result of having those positions and responsibilities.

I want to spend two moments reflecting and dwelling upon the ethics that, in some respects, in the chamber we should have respect for each other and for the proper functioning of the political system. Senator Cooney made the point that parliament should be the most important institution in the land.

Our quaint system of the amalgamation of the Westminster and American systems has left us, for the last few years at least, with one house of parliament which has a majority which is now accountable exclusively to the executive government. I do not make judgments as to who is better or who is worse. In many respects, the House of Representatives is simply a rubber stamp of cabinet. These days not even caucus or the coalition party room, depending on who is in government, has a say. Essentially it is cabinet. All cabinet has to do is make a decision, announce it and it is fait accompli.

I have had a moment to have a quick look at the document that Senator Cooney referred to. It says that 95 per cent agree that federal politicians should stop arguing with each other and concentrate more on running the country; 39 per cent agree that parliamentarians are looking after themselves. Interestingly enough, 40 per cent of those who believe in the good old free enterprise system are Liberals, and only 34 per cent are ALP.

Twenty-two per cent of Liberals believe that most parliamentarians represent their party. For the ALP, ever faithful unto each other, it is 26 per cent. For the Liberal Party, it is 22 per cent. Loyalty does not seem to be quite as important. One of the qualities I have espoused about the Labor Party in the 25 years I have been involved in politics is that its members are loyal unto each other, even in the most adverse circumstances; for all the wrong reasons and with the wrong results. Unless I have missed something, one example is the way the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has stuck with Mrs Lawrence. You cannot help but admire them. If it had been Malcolm Fraser and Mr X, Mr X would have been gone the first day.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was not too much loyalty to Bob Hawke, though.
—I do not know that Mr Hawke as Prime Minister sacked too many of his front bench, did he?
—No; there is not too much loyalty to him now.

—Whatever your station in a parliamentary party, when you are gone, it is amazing how little loyalty there is in a residual sense. I am sure that there are still a few in the Labor Party who have dinner with him.

PARA.TAB: I thoroughly support a code of conduct. Perhaps it is the rigid bureaucratic system that we have in this country—I suspect it is—which means that there is very little unearthed corruption in the political system in this country. When we put members of parliament in goal for ticking up a shampoo or for a car trip down the road to see their daughter in boarding school, I do not think much gets through the net. Perhaps it is the bureaucratic system whereby ministers have to go through such a long process before a decision is made in the interests of the country, never mind themselves. Perhaps we have institutionalised, by some accident, some protection against it.

What is true of our system—and many members of other parliaments make this observation when they come here and see us at question time—is the robust nature of our treatment of each other and the institution. There is nothing wrong with good, healthy, robust debate in respect of each other, but it is quite a different matter to have the capacity and the facility to damage people who cannot represent themselves, without a care or without responsibility.

I was one of those people who made representations prior to what is now the 1987 Parliamentary Privileges Act. I support the proposition that, if somebody in this place is aggrieved, they can make representations to the President and through the Privileges Committee at least have a silent voice recorded in Hansard. But it is of no great reward if the damage is on the front page of a newspaper. With due respect, there is not much censure of members and senators who get up and defame people—which they are entitled to do; the very purpose of privilege is freedom of thought and freedom of expression without fear or favour—in an irresponsible, improper, unfair and morally corrupted way; nor is there much of a filter system to ensure that they don't do it.

I suppose I am sensitive to it, and that is why I have been such a caring, sensitive and warm person in the 15 years I have been here. Before I got here I used to read about myself in the West Australian, invariably on the front page, as a result of the then Senator Peter Walsh having mixed up a pot of lies, untruths, half-truths and utter fabrications and then dumped them in the Senate—much to the amusement, on occasions, of the then Senator Chaney.

There was never a proper mechanism whereby you could respond. I found on a number of occasions eight or nine paragraphs on me and down the bottom one line, `Senator Crichton-Browne denied it'—and that was after a half-hour interview! There is no proper process, there is no proper system, whereby we have checks and balances on members' and senators' conduct towards the public.

The other risk we run with our system of parliament is that it is very easy to undercut and undermine the rights of individual members and senators, whether they be of a major political party, of a minor political party or an independent. If the Prime Minister wants to give the wink and the nod to the Speaker in the House of Representatives, who is there by his grace, you can be quite certain that anybody who belongs to the other major party which is in a minority can have all their rights undercut and destroyed.

The same thing applies in this place. If the Deputy President or the President feels under some sort of threat from his or her party room in terms of future votes for future promotion or future votes for continuation of the present position, it is terribly easy to corrupt the process, however subtle it might be. That was one of the things that always weighed very heavily on my mind when I was in the chair. I was always determined to ensure that the Senate did not end up like the House of Representatives in terms of the role and function of the Speaker. Whatever party is in government down there, nobody can be proud of the way the Speaker is able to be influenced by his own political party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did a good job in the chair.

—Thank you, Senator Cooney, for saying that. I don't know that I deserve that, given that a motion was moved from my own side to dissent from my ruling shortly after my taking on the position of Deputy President. Perhaps it says something.
—It says a lot. It says you should have taken the hint.
—Senator Hill could never understand why I was so generous to the government. I always used to say to him, `Look, Robert, they supported me when you didn't.' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess it makes me wonder sometimes when people look at codes of conduct. I thought we generally accepted that there was a code of conduct. I thought that most people, if not all of us in a place like this—and in the general community—believe that you exercise your conduct in the best way you possibly can. I do not necessarily agree that you should have to have some written form of words that is almost impossible to implement. If you look at codes of conduct that relate to other areas such as doctors, solicitors, people of the cloth and journalists, it is clearly evident that codes of conduct do not necessarily stop people from being unethical—it happens on many occasions.

PARA.TAB: I find it rather unusual that Senator Kernot is proposing this general business notice of motion today, given that the draft proposed code of conduct was tabled back on 21 June. I would have thought that, if this was such an important issue, it would have been debated shortly thereafter. If we were so serious about having a code of conduct—and in all the contributions I have heard today everybody has been saying how important it is that we demonstrate to the public that we are worthy of their support and that we can conduct ourselves in a proper way—if that was so important, why didn't we deal with it some time ago?

TALK.START.PARA: —This was our first chance this year.

—You may say it was your first chance; I do not know that I would agree with that. Where codes of conduct do apply, they do not stop people from being unethical. Those people will continue to be so. It is very unfortunate that the public's general view of politicians and the political system is very low. This is probably caused by some people who have been unethical in politics. But having another set of words is not necessarily going to solve that.

PARA.TAB: I was just reading through the draft set of words and came to No. 3 `Respect for the Dignity and Privacy of Others'. It says that members and senators must have due regard for the rights and obligations of all Australians. I would have thought that that was without question. It also says:

SPEECH.PARA: They must respect the privacy of others and avoid unjustifiable or illegal discrimination. They must safeguard information obtained in confidence in the course of their duties and exercise responsibly their rights and privileges as Members and Senators.

It was not that long ago, as I remember, that we had a Senate select committee inquiring into the Fairfax sale. It was the view of some in the opposition, joined by the Australian Democrats, that information that was obtained in confidence ought not have remained in confidence. That again highlights the problem with the implementation of any code of conduct. Who sits in judgment on all these things? Who enforces them and what are the penalties? If we go further into Senator Kernot's motion, we see what she is proposing in 7A `Accountability and Openness'. It says:
Members and Senators are accountable for their decisions and actions to the public, must submit themselves to whatever scrutiny is appropriate to their office.

What is appropriate scrutiny? It is a bit like asking how long is a piece of string. It continues `and should be as open as possible'. What does that mean about the decisions and actions that they take? It continues:
They should give reasons for the decisions and restrict information only when the wider public interest clearly demands it.

Who determines that? I heard Senator Kernot say that it really comes down to party lines. That is exactly what we will have. We will have a system where people will line up and the numbers will be played out, depending on the circumstances. The Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine might line up with either the government or the opposition. I do not think it is a fair system at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on what is right.

—That is true, it does depend on what is right. What is right is an opinion that is in the eye of the beholder. There are varying opinions with regard to what is right and what is wrong. There is a code of conduct in the English parliamentary system. I have to say that it has not done them much good. It would appear that one of the requirements in the English code of conduct is to be a cross-dresser. They pay to have questions asked and they pay for amendments. What sort of system has that brought about?
—And $20,000 to meet them?
—That's right.
—Do they do that over there, too?
—I think they do, yes.
—The same as you blokes.

—That is simply not correct and you know it. You might like to misrepresent the facts but some people do not. I suppose a code of conduct ought to apply to you. It would probably be used more in respect of you than anybody else.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day, the question of a code of conduct or no code of conduct will be a matter for the people who make the ultimate judgment. The people will ultimately judge a member of parliament as to whether or not he or she is fit to represent the public in this place.

We have seen some very stark examples. This matter has been moved on the day following the publication of the report of the Marks royal commission in Western Australia. In that instance we had a state government setting up terms of reference specifically for political purposes. That is not good enough. We cannot have that sort of system here. I do not think any senator would want to be investigated and possibly be found guilty on the numbers which can be stacked up against him or her. It would not be a fair application of justice.

I might say that I do not have a problem with having a code of conduct in which we would set down some simple words saying that senators and members must act with due diligence. If we adopt some of the measures proposed in the amendments I wonder who is going to sit in judgment. It would work really well in estimates committees. Some opposition members may think that the minister is not giving them enough information. The minister would be hauled before a code of conduct tribunal or something. Who is going to stack the numbers on that tribunal?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting the feel for opposition, Shayne.

—No, I am not. I can assure you, Senator, that we will still be standing on this side of the chamber after the next federal election. It is all very well to have these standards. They may give some people a warm inner glow. I believe Senator Chamarette made a pertinent point when she mentioned the ethics of representation. I read recently where Dr Bob Brown, who is running for the Senate, said that he may well block supply. On what basis would he block supply? We are talking about the ethics of representation where we have two senators who represent less than one per cent of the Australian population. We now have another candidate hoping to come into this chamber and he is saying that he would block supply. Where are the ethics in that?

PARA.TAB: We can have as many codes of conduct as we like but, at the end of the day, they will only be worth the amount of ethical conduct that we are prepared to apply. I think it is incumbent upon all of us to come here trying to do our best. We should act accordingly. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a couple of points in the three minutes I have to participate in this debate. One of them is that the greatest threat, the greatest danger, to the institution of parliament is the deliberate duplicity of some of the people who grace the halls of this parliament. Nothing could bring the parliament into more disrepute than a Prime Minister who promises one thing before an election and immediately following the election breaks that promise. Nothing could bring the parliament into greater disrepute than a minister who has been proved in a royal commission to be a liar, who refuses to take the honourable course and who is supported by so-called ministers of the Crown. That is the sort of duplicity that brings this parliament into disrepute.

PARA.TAB: The hypocrisy then of a party which was formed supposedly to keep the bastards honest—their words, not mine—whose whole existence was to do that, coming into this chamber and supporting a minister of the Crown who has been proved by a royal commission to be a liar. That is the party that is moving amendments to this motion. I have never had much time for the Australian Democrats, some of you might be surprised to hear, because of the hypocrisy of that party and its ideals.

The Democrats are supposedly in here to keep this lot on the other side and, I suppose, us, honest. All the way, their history has been: if the Labor Party does it, then they support them; if the Labor Party says it is right, then it is right; if the Labor Party says it is wrong, then it is wrong. This party, which supposedly was there to be an independent force and to keep the institution honest, supports the Labor Party in most important issues.

Yesterday was a classic example. Here was a minister proved to be a liar. But when the Senate had the chance to do something tangible about it, the Democrats sided with the Labor Party, protected their own and looked after their mates. But then, to my amazement, the Democrats had the gall to bring on this motion today—the very day after they have supported a minister of the Crown who has been proved to be a liar.

I wanted to say a lot of things but I do not have the time. Very quickly, I just want to make this point on a code of conduct: how can this government—how can a front bench in any ministry—be honest in its accountability and be honest in its decisions when it is beholden to the ACTU, a non-elected body? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I had the pleasure and also the privilege of being able to serve on the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, and I note that two members of the committee are in the chamber: the chair, Senator Murphy, and Senator Woodley.

PARA.TAB: The unresolved whistleblowers committee arose out of concerns, especially in the state of Queensland. Whilst we went through the hearings and discussed matters of quite some moment, emotions did run high from time to time and there were concerns within the committee as to its direction. But I am very pleased to say that at the end of the day we did come down with a unanimous report. I think it once again indicates the very real benefit of the Senate committees that are able to do very good work for the benefit of the people of Australia.

Whilst I am talking about the work of the committee, it would only be appropriate also to thank the staff of the committee and those who spent many hours travelling around the country with us and preparing the draft reports, which Senator Woodley and I went through in great detail, checking words and commas. It was a credit to the committee as a whole that we were able to come down with a unanimous report.

There are a number of elements that I would like to address in this report. It is noteworthy that we as a committee were somewhat concerned as to the way the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland conducted itself. I note that we as a committee also made mention of a particular officer of the Criminal Justice Commission and his behaviour. In particular, I refer to paragraph 4.47 of our report, which said:

In this context, the Committee notes the response by Mr Barnes to questions about political affiliations which, while being accurate, was less than helpful for the Committee's understanding of the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice Senator Murphy smiling; in my usual style of cooperation, I agreed that such a mellow comment be allowed to go in the report and agreed that I might make some other points whilst addressing the report.

PARA.TAB: The situation was that, within the Criminal Justice Commission—an organisation which is required to investigate and deal with matters of inappropriate behaviour in public offices—it is important that justice be done and also be seen to be done. Some of these inquiries were of a potentially politically embarrassing nature to the Labor government in Queensland. As a result, it was drawn to our committee's attention that certain people appointed to investigate matters were alleged to have party political affiliations. Mr Barnes was one of these people and, whilst I do not want to canvass what happened within the committee as I was trying to get responses to this allegation, Mr Barnes basically said, `Look, I'm not a member of Labor Lawyers and I have never been a member of the Australian Labor Party.' That was a completely truthful statement but, I add, a wholly misleading statement, because Mr Barnes had in fact been a member of the Association of Labor Lawyers—and to be a member of Labor Lawyers you do not have to be a member of the Australian Labor Party. But the objective of Labor Lawyers is to help implement the platform and policies of the Australian Labor Party.

We as a committee found that his response was less than helpful. I would put it a bit stronger than that because somebody who is required to make judgments and determine and investigate matters of whistleblowing ought to be beyond reproach and his words should be able to be taken at face value without the need to try to sift through them to see if there is a little hole in them or whether he has been too smart. Unfortunately from the committee's point of view, on this occasion he was less than helpful. It did no credit to the Criminal Justice Commission to have an officer at the table giving that sort of evidence.

Other matters concerned me greatly in this inquiry and a lot of those matters are mentioned in the report. But the shredding of the Heiner documents and the treatment of a Mr Kevin Lindeberg were matters of great concern to me and the committee. Those documents should never have been shredded and it really was a travesty of justice. I took great heart from the comments made by Mr Ian Callinan QC who, when he appeared before the committee, indicated that he thought there was the potential that that course of action could deny justice.

I just indicate very briefly that the documents that were destroyed were the basis for a potential defamation action, and the Queensland cabinet took it upon itself to destroy those documents so that the basis for a defamation proceeding would be denied to a Mr Peter Coyne.

If a police officer were to deliberately destroy information or evidence in a potential court case, that police officer would face official misconduct charges. Indeed, if I deliberately destroyed information on the basis that I thought I might need it in a Supreme Court proceeding or something of that nature, and court proceedings were actually under way, that also would be an offence. But on this occasion the Queensland government said that legal proceedings had not been instituted, and the reason and rationale for their saying that legal proceedings had not been instituted was that there was no Supreme Court action on foot; letters passed from lawyers to the department asking them for the documents were not deemed to be sufficient to indicate that legal proceedings were under way.

The situation is that, if the rule of law in this country is to be upheld, is to be viewed in the light that it ought be, then the Crown has a duty to be a model litigant and to always act in a most appropriate manner and not in an inappropriate manner. The destruction of evidence to avoid the government from becoming involved in a potential defamation case was below the standard of conduct that one would expect of the Crown which has a duty to be a model litigant. I believe that that reflects very poorly on the Queensland cabinet.

There are only a few minutes left, so I will briefly turn to Messrs Harris and Reynolds who were two Queensland police officers. I note that one rejoices in a surname similar to yours, Madam Acting Deputy President, but undoubtedly he is unrelated. Even if you were related, Madam Acting Deputy President, I believe you could hold your head up high because I believe police officer Reynolds acted with great propriety and was unfortunately vilified by the police department and then Inspector Huey.

In the few seconds remaining I want to comment on the fact that the Queensland government agreed to release a certain document to us to read in private, which we did, but on the basis that we did not divulge the totality of the document. Aspects of the document had already been released by prosecutions and court cases involving these officers. To only release part of the document and then claim legal privilege and confidentiality on the rest of it was in the view of the committee inappropriate and I want to associate myself with that finding of the committee. Once again the Crown has not acted in an appropriate way in Queensland. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to comment on the issue involving Mr Michael Barnes and his political affiliations. The report indicates that his answer to Senator Abetz's question was less than helpful. I do not disagree with that, but the fact of the matter is that I do not think we ought to pass judgment or carry out guilt by association. I think that at the time Mr Barnes was investigating the particular case he was not a member of the Association of Labor Lawyers. I find most of the members I know to be most unhelpful and they do not necessarily do the Labor Party a great deal of good.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to quickly touch on the shredding of the Heiner documents. It really must be put into context. There was a change of government and this inquiry was established under the previous government. As best we could ascertain, the inquirer thought his inquiry was set up under a particular act. If that had been the case, it would have meant that those people giving evidence to the inquiry would have had the right of privilege and protection. That evidence and the documents associated with it would not have been available for defamation proceedings because they would have been protected by privilege. Unfortunately, that was not the case. The new government then came in.

I do not think the committee could see—and I say this with all honesty and it is certainly my view—any rhyme or reason for the new Queensland government acting in a particular way to protect itself or somebody else. I think it acted in good faith. As it says in the report, it sought all of the information and acted in accordance with the information that it received. The report does say that it may have been more helpful to have ultimately maintained those documents. Nevertheless, I think it should not be inferred that the government acted improperly to protect a vested interest, because that clearly was not the case. That is all I would like to say about the matter.
