TALK.START.PARA: —Last weekend I had the honour and, indeed, the pleasure to visit Hughenden in western Queensland, four or five road hours west of Townsville, to participate in a very important ceremony. It was the recognition of a coolibah tree on the banks of Station Creek in Hughenden that was blazed twice by two of the expeditions who were searching for Burke and Wills in 1861 and 1862.

PARA.TAB: The coolibah tree in Station Creek in Hughenden still stands, and with a little bit of help from some tree doctors and others is now looking very fine. Without demeaning the process of historical recognition in western Queensland, I must say that it is nice to have another tree in western Queensland apart from the one at Barcaldine. This tree, which was blazed twice by the expeditions searching for Burke and Wills, does stand in Station Creek in Hughenden and will be an important tourist attraction to the west of Queensland.

It will, I might say, complement the tree of knowledge in Barcaldine and the other tourist facilities there such as the Stockman's Hall of Fame, the museum to the prehistoric remains in the Winton area and also the proposals by the Winton Shire Council and others to establish a Waltzing Matilda interpretive centre and museum in Winton. I was pleased to be able to talk to people from the Winton shire during this week about that particular proposal. All those things are attracting much needed dollars to the north-west of Queensland. It is tremendous to see, but I digress.

Last Saturday I unveiled two plaques commemorating the passage through the Flinders shire of the Burke and Wills relief expedition of Frederick Walker in 1861. Frederick Walker left Rockhampton and led a party moving towards the gulf area looking for Burke and Wills and their party or traces of them. I think they were the first Europeans to pass through that area of North Queensland. In the following year, William Landsborough led an expedition also searching for the Burke and Wills party. He started in the gulf, as I understand it, and moved south but also passed through this area of what is now the Flinders shire. Quite coincidently—perhaps it was not coincidence—one way or another they both blazed the same coolibah tree in Station Creek in Hughenden. The blaze marks have been grown over but the tree does live on.

The ceremony last weekend was attended by a number of Hughenden people and was organised by Councillor Beryl Hunter from the Flinders Shire Council and was attended by Councillor Greg Jones and Councillor Robert Tindall, also from the Flinders shire. As part of the ceremony a poster competition was held for children. It was good to be able to congratulate the youngsters, both from the same family as it turned out, who were the successful poster drawers of that particular competition.
The ceremony was followed by a luncheon in the Great Western Hotel at Hughenden. That hotel was chosen because in its original form it was the first hotel in the Hughenden district.

Although the Burke and Wills expedition was, of course, one of tragedy, these relief expeditions looking for Burke and Wills did, in fact, have a secondary purpose in that they did open up those very fertile plains in the Flinders region to pastoral pursuits and were the forerunners of what has now been established as the town of Hughenden.

The expedition by Walker and the subsequent one by Landsborough are credited as being, really, the impetus that led to the development by Europeans of that area of North Queensland and to the very wealthy and progressive community that now lives in and around that area. I was very proud and pleased to be able to be part of that.

I congratulate all of those involved, including Professor Brian Dalton of James Cook University who gave the address and the explanation of the Burke and Wills expedition and the two relief expeditions that looked for them. As I say, it was a pleasure to be there and I congratulate all those involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an unusual but very important task which I think is best undertaken in the adjournment debate. I have been given a document by a constituent. This document is to contribute to the longstanding community debate about the Orr case, a contentious component of Tasmania's social and legal history. The document is not shy, it is bold, it is brave and I will quote from it directly in order not to detract from the serious commitment with which its author, Mr Paul Berry, has presented it to me. Mr Berry writes:

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with the case of Sydney Sparkes Orr v. The University of Tasmania, No. 278 of 1956, I, Christopher Paul Berry, known as Paul Berry, of 45 Sixth Ave., West Moonah in Tasmania, make the following Accusation; viz., of the employment of crime in the course of the dismissal of, and in defence of the dismissal of Professor Sydney Sparkes Orr in March of 1956: also allegations regarding judicial conduct in the hearing of No. 278 of 1956, and on its further hearing on Appeal to the High Court of Australia in May of 1957.

I believe that I echo a disquiet which has never vanished: which has not been satisfactorily allayed despite the recourse by Professor Orr to the highest tribunal to which access could be had, within the Australian justice structure. I suggest further, that concern about this case and its implications about judicial probity has not been limited to this country.

The acknowledged tendency inherent in power, to corrupt not only those who hold it but also those who lack, is proverbial. The Orr case, I say, shows this tendency as more than proverb. The Orr case shows, I say, that within Australia justice is, or at least then was vulnerable; that justice itself is in peril from those who operate within the system. The Orr case showed that the worst can happen: the Courts of our land can be manipulated as a vehicle, not of justice, but of oppression. In the Orr case, certain judges can be seen to have acted as if they were no better than mafiosi, godfathers protecting their own. In the ultimate, I say, their priority must be taken to have been that the system and certain individuals within it should survive.

Edmund Burke I believe it was, who made the observation that all that is required for evil to succeed is that good men and women shall do nothing. It becomes accepted as axiomatic that when the courts have spoken, good men and women can do nothing. With this I would not agree. I recall recent words, if I remember aright, of Sir William Deane of the High Court of Australia, who said inter alia that the right of free speech and therefore of criticism, is implicit in the Australian Constitution. It has also been said, either by the same Judge or by another of similar standing, that in the ultimate, power resides with the people. I recognise the sanctity and authority of such sentiments.

PARA.TAB: As we, the Australian people, contemplate moving from parliamentary democracy under monarchy to a republican system, I feel it to be not only appropriate but vital, that my allegations be explored. Because I still have faith in `responsible government' which, of course, ought to mean `responsive government' I direct this statement and appended Affidavit to all Federal Parliamentary members of both Houses; of all parties and of none. The response to this will surely indicate whether we as a nation have yet developed sufficient maturity to examine ourselves and our institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The materials upon which I rely in making the within allegations are all extant. Properly examined, I claim they amount to clear evidence compelling belief as to the employment of crime by some within the profession of Law; crime committed for the express purpose of subverting justice.

The allegations which I make, I make upon oath. They are, of course, framed merely in the language of an ordinary layman. If this be a barrier to their adequate understanding, I am willing to reaffirm them should it, for the purpose of their investigation, be necessary to recast the form of their wording.

In view of what many, including our Prime Minister and others in government have maintained to be mere political ploy, in the institution of a Royal Commission into the Carmen Lawrence matter, I dare to suggest that the statement which I make cannot but be seen as warranting investigation at a similar level. Such a Commission should be set up with terms of reference sufficiently wide as to permit input from other citizens who, from their own knowledge or experience, may have similar disquiet.

As evidence of my good faith as well as by way of introducing other probative material, I include also allegations which surely ought to be regarded as of a defamatory nature, concerning two persons alive to this day. Thus it may be seen that I am not taking refuge in the relatively secure pastime of vilifying the dead or the powerless.

I state that I have already published in a manner such as to satisfy the terms of section 200 of the Tasmanian Criminal Code Act 1924, the allegations appended. Thus it will be seen that I am offering myself for criminal prosecution as well as for civil suit. My purpose in making these allegations upon oath is that I might leave myself no room for retreat from them, without their testing and their sufficient vindication. Indeed, I challenge both these persons to sue me or to prosecute me. I emphasise, however, that I hold no ill will towards either of them. I am actuated neither by malice nor by hope of gain. Indeed, I consider that my life, my liberty and my property may all hereby be placed at risk.

Mr Berry continues with an accusation which I will not read or table or attempt to incorporate into Hansard tonight but which I will bring to the Senate at a later time. He stands by this accusation. I emphasise again that he makes this document available to me and, therefore, to the Senate eventually and to the whole of Australia, in a mood of gravity and seriousness which I hope has been evidenced by the way I have read the document. I will continue this in another adjournment debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak further tonight on the unanimous report of the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, which was tabled in the Senate on 26 October 1999, and which has been referred to again tonight. The committee had strict terms of reference. There was always a will amongst the committee members that we reach a unanimous report to indicate to the community at large the Senate's desire to have whistleblower legislation that really affords whistleblowers protection, and, difficult though it may be, encourages honest people to stand up to corruption where and when it is discovered, otherwise we diminish ourselves as individuals and as a nation which purports to believe in accountability. If we cannot frame legislation to protect honest citizens alerting proper authorities to corruption, particularly in the public sector, then as legislators, I believe, we would have failed in our duty.

PARA.TAB: I touched upon the shredding of the Heiner inquiry documents in my first speech. I wish to return to it in order that the Senate understands my feelings on the matter. Some time ago I told the house that the matter remains unresolved. Indeed, it remains to be addressed by a proper authority. I pointed towards a significant submission presented to the committee from Ian Callinan QC and his junior counsel, Roland Peterson, which addressed the admissions of fact and argued that sections 129 and 132 of the criminal code of Queensland applied in this instance. They did not indicate the guilt or otherwise of the people involved in the shredding. I concurred with their arguments, but it is really a matter for the police and the courts after all.

A submission from a man of the eminence of Mr Callinan QC cannot be lightly put aside. It raised very serious and unique questions which our committee did not finally address. That has been personally distressing to me. I believe that an unacceptable precedent has been created in my state of Queensland because the Queensland crown solicitor and the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission have asserted that the shredding, although against certain uncontested facts, was and is legal.

In reaching a unanimous position within the constraints imposed on us by the terms of reference, we chose to describe the shredding as an exercise in poor judgment. The Queensland government should have heeded more the notion of the crown as a model litigant. We concluded that the documents should have been retained for the purposes of litigation.

Nevertheless, we are faced with the fact that the executive of the Queensland government, with the knowledge that the Heiner inquiry documents were required for foreshadowed litigation, secretly destroyed them in order to stop or frustrate a Queensland citizen litigating against the crown and others.

It has been argued that it was a new and inexperienced government trying to do its best to deal with a problem created by the former National Party government. I have a problem with this argument, despite Senator Murphy quite rightly pointing out that we had difficulty finding a motive for the government's action. However, if that view were to gain currency concerning litigation involving the crown, it could reduce our legal system to chaos. The crown is in perpetuity and learning curves have no standing in law, especially for the crown. No matter how new a government may be, it still has continuous access to crown law advice from day one.

This brings into play the curious role of the crown solicitor in this affair, which opens up even more serious questions concerning the rights of citizens in Queensland to litigate against the crown. Before any sort of negotiation involving access to public records which may lead to court proceedings can begin, it seems that a Queensland citizen must now serve a writ on the government to ensure the security of those records.

What is absolutely clear from the evidence is that, while the crown solicitor was considering Mr Coyne's solicitor's letters, one of which officially put the crown on notice, the cabinet decided within days to destroy the evidence to stop or frustrate Mr Coyne litigating. The question that then arises is whether this new government was acting fairly and openly. The evidence is that it was not. This is one of the fundamental reasons why the two victims, Mr Kevin Lindeberg and Mr Peter Coyne, have pursued justice for so long.

Did the government inform Mr Coyne and his solicitor that it had decided to shred the evidence to stop him litigating it, albeit to protect other people from defamation proceedings? It did not. Instead, it told him, weeks after the shredding had been ordered, that the crown solicitor was still considering their legal demands. That deception forestalled the issuance of a writ.

Did the government tell the State Archivist that it wanted the documents destroyed in order to stop them being used in evidence in known, impending litigation? It did not. It withheld crucial evidence from her. In fact, I would say it deceived her.

Did the government tell Mr Lindeberg that the government intended to shred the evidence? At one meeting on the day the documents were being examined for destruction, he was told by the government that they were safe. Several days later, when he inadvertently learnt of the plans to shred, he was immediately removed from the case, upon the insistence of a minister, and later sacked by his union over his handling of the case. From that moment it deceived him and then took his head.
Did the government allow public servants like the State Archivist and departmental advisers to attend our committee hearings to tell their story? It did not.

It is very clear that the actions of the Director-General, which our committee described as `bureaucratic ineptitude at best or deliberate deceit at worst', could not have been hers alone. She had a direct line to the cabinet. We are left with one unavoidable conclusion in this case, that she acted in the knowledge that the cabinet was behind her.

We are talking about one of the most fundamental rights cherished in our nation—the right to seek redress in the court and for the crown to be the fountain of justice, not injustice, and to act with probity and fairly;

SPEECH.PARA: in other words, to be, as Mr Callinan says, a model litigant.

PARA.TAB: We know, according to the current evidence, that cabinet ordered the destruction of known, foreseeable evidence while the crown solicitor was still considering other legal demands on the material. On the face of it, the crown solicitor inexplicably held his silence and did nothing to protect the evidence, as was his duty. Instead, he, like other public officials and members of cabinet, stood back and allowed the evidence to be destroyed.

There is another scenario which has yet to be fully exhausted. Did the crown solicitor attempt to intervene, in accordance with his duty, to protect the evidence after he learnt his client had decided to destroy the evidence? Was his final advice specifically rejected because the government was marching to a different drum?

The issues surrounding the shredding are alive and important. They are to do with justice, fair dealing and due process. It is my understanding that Mr Lindeberg, the man who brought this affair to the attention of this house, is currently considering further options with his counsel, Mr Callinan QC, and Mr Peterson.

While it may be argued that this is very much a state issue, I suggest that the Senate should not turn its back on this long running affair because it cuts to the very core of integrity in government and the rule of law, which should concern us all, whether we come from Western Australia, the back of Bourke or Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)Why does the advertised program information line for Radio National refer callers to another `0055' number?
(2)Why does the advertised program information line for Radio National also refer callers to a `0055' number for the `Gay Contact Service'?
(3) What is the relationship between Radio National and the `Gay Contact Service'?
(4) How is the revenue from calls to the Radio National program information line allocated?
(5) How is revenue from calls to the `Gay Contact Service' allocated?
(6) Is it appropriate for the Radio National program information line to also be used for the promotion of a `Gay Contact Service'; if not, what action will be taken to remedy the situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC):

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Until January 1995, the ABC conducted a Radio National listener information service, in association with an external service provider. The number for this service was 0055 22990.

The agreement with the external service provider was terminated in January. Since then, the Radio National listener information services has been conducted `in house' by the ABC. The new number is 0055 29966.
Following the termination of its agreement with the ABC, the external service provider allocated 0055 22990 to a new client—the Gay Contact Service.

When it was discovered that 0055 22990 had been allocated to a new service, the ABC made representations to the external service provider. It was argued that confusion could arise in cases where a Radio National listener, using out of date publicity material, attempted to phone the Radio National listener information services number.

The external service provider allocated a different 0055 number to the Gay Contact Service, and a recorded message was placed on 0055 22990. The message gave the new numbers for both Radio National and the Gay Contact Service.
(3) There is not now, and never has been, a relationship between Radio National and the Gay Contact Service.
(4) Revenue from the Radio National information line is shared between Telstra and the ABC, according to the normal Telstra arrangements for recorded information services.
(5) As there is no relationship between the ABC and the Gay Contact Service, ABC Radio is unable to provide an answer to this question.
(6) Please refer to the answer given to Question 1 and 2.
For Senator Newman's information, the ABC has been advised that the Gay Contact Service is no longer operating, and callers to 0055 22990 are now given only the new number for Radio National.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister of Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 3 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Does the department have a target or targets for the number of its employees (including agency board and other consultative committees' members) who are: (i) overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) can speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) if so, can details be provided.

(2) (a) How many employees of the department in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years: (i) were overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) able to speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) what percentages of total employment do the above numbers represent.

(3) (a) How many members of your department's advisory bodies and panels, agency boards, consultative committees and other tribunals or councils, in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years: (i) were overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background (iii) able to speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) what percentages of total members do the above numbers represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) My Department has no numeric targets for the number of its employees who are overseas born, of non-English speaking background or able to speak one or more languages other than English. However, one of the goals of my Department's Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) National Program and Action Plan 1994-96 is to put in place measures to ensure that members of EEO groups maintain a satisfactory level of representation, that is that staff in EEO groups maintain or increase their level of representation. Identification with EEO groups is voluntary. At the start of the period covered by the Plan, 9.95 per cent of my Department's staff were from non-English speaking backgrounds.
At 30 June 1995 the proportion was 10.09 per cent.
(b) Not available. See answer to (1)(a).
(2)(a)(i) Not available. My Department does not maintain information on employees born overseas.
(ii) The numbers of employees identifying as from non English speaking backgrounds were:
at 30 June 1994: 1629; and

(iii) Not available. My Department does not maintain information for all employees who can speak one or more languages other than English and, therefore, cannot provide answers to those questions requiring such information. Data are confined to the number of staff receiving the Community Language Allowance (formerly the Language Availability Proficiency Allowance). These staff use their language skills on a regular basis to assist clients with English language difficulties.
The number of staff receiving the allowance was 352 at 30 June 1994 and 392 at 30 June 1995. The data include staff using Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages who were not born overseas.
(2)(b)(i) Not available. See answer to (2)(a)(i).
(ii) The proportions of employees identifying as being from a non-English speaking background were:
at 30 June 1994: 9.95 per cent; and
at 30 June 1995 10.09 per cent.
(iii) Not available. See answer to (2)(a)(iii).
(3)(a)(i) There are no data available. There is no requirement to collect this information.
(a)(ii) The numbers of members of advisory boards and other bodies identifying as having a non-English speaking background were:
at 30 June 1994: 17 people (4 per cent of total members); and
at 30 June 1995: 15 people (4.5 per cent of total members).
The self-identification numbers understate the actual numbers.
(a)(iii) There are no data available. There is no requirement to collect this information.
(b) See answer to (3)(a)(ii).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 3 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Does the department have a target or targets for the number of its employees (including agency board and other consultative committees' members) who are: (i) overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) can speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) if so, can details be provided.

(2)(a) How many employees of the department in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years: (i) were overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) able to speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) what percentages of total employment do the above numbers represent.

(3)(a) How many members of your department's advisory boards and panels, agency boards, consultative committees and other tribunals or councils in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years: (i) were overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) able to speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) what percentages of total members do the above numbers represent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a)(i)-(iii) & (b) The Department has an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Program, which has been revised for 1995-1998. The Program establishes benchmark standards against which the progress of the EEO Program can be assessed. The benchmark standards aim for a general increase in the number of employees who are from a non-English speaking background to 12% for the Canberra-based Divisions, and maintenance of the number of employees who are from a non-English speaking background for the Antarctic Division at 4.1%. The Bureau of Meteorology, which is part of the Department, and which has a separate EEO Program has not set any targets for the number of employees who are from a non-English speaking background.

(2)(a)-(b)(i) In 1993-94, across all parts of the Department 111 employees identified as being overseas born which represented 5.1% of permanent staff. In 1994-95, across all parts of the Department 117 employees identified as being overseas born which represented 5.3% of permanent staff.
(2)(a)-(b)(ii) In 1993-94, across all parts of the Department 260 employees identified as being from

ANSWER.PARA: a non-English speaking background which represented 12% of permanent employees. In 1994-95, across all parts of the Department 286 employees identified as being from a non-English speaking background which represented 12.9% of permanent staff.

PARA.TAB: (2)(iii) The Department does not maintain records on the number of employees able to speak one or more languages other than English.

(3)(i)-(iii) The Department does not keep records in the form requested. However the Government's APPOINT system contains details of positions filled and appointments made to statutory and non-statutory bodies within the Portfolio. EEO target groups are identified to the extent that individuals have provided these details on appointment. In the 1994-95 financial year the total number of positions filled by people of non-English speaking background was 34 (8.4%). Details for the 1993-94 financial year are not available.
